content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
L.A. NoireI loved L.A. Noire from the minute I saw its buzzing yellow title screen on a jazz theme background. If you're even remotely interested in the detective genre, I see no reason not to give this a shot. As usual, Rockstar does a brilliant job of conveying the intended atmosphere and location, i.e. 1940s L.A. and noir genre, while bringing into play some important themes of the era. The campaign is lengthy and involving, the mechanics entertaining and addictive, and the characters flawed and believable (thankfully the likes of Roy Earle bring a bit of much needed levity to Phelps' boy scout attitude).Pros:A good variety of cases building from basic to more complex ones;Meaty, lengthy campaign with obvious replay value to uncover every detail of this solid, mature noir story;Fantastic VO performances all around, superb theme song, decent soundtrack;Looking for clues, questioning suspects and gauging their reaction is engaging and rewarding;Amazing facial animations rendered by MotionScan are a perfect fit for this genre;Handy options to do away with the action/skip to destination if you just want to work the cases;Usual Rockstar attention to detail when it comes to evocative epochal environment/context;Notebook is a clever, non-intrusive alternative to the HUD and, along with the Log, a great way to keep track of things;Change of protagonist and partner is refreshing.Neutral:Auto-turn on stairs and fire escapes is a nice touch;Interrogate half the cast of Mad Men;A bit more variation with NPCs random dialogue would have been nice ("I say we bust in there and find the goddam evidence!" x99).Cons:Even if it is the intended persona, Phelps is excessively stern and it gets old;Not a lot of (good) reasons to go exploring Hollywoodland;Uninspired/tedious collectibles;Controls feel a little stiff at times, as does the cover system;Some redundant puzzles while collecting evidence;City feels a bit empty/lifeless at times;Some cars in traffic will disappear if you turn the camera the wrong way (bit of a bother for Auto Fanatic).

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Justice always wins.At the bottom, there is a short version as a summary for those who don't like to read.Phelps, badge 1247.So.. your name is Cole Phelps. After the end of World War II you return to the country as a hero and as one of the few soldiers who deal well with the trauma of the experiences on the front lines. You have always thought that everything is either black or white and guided by these ideals you are joining the ranks of police in Los Angeles. At first, being a simple novice from the proverbial "traffic police," you manage to get promoted to the rank of detective in a special department of the LAPD, thanks to solved case. From now on, all your days will pass on briefings, visual inspections of crime scenes, interrogations and prosecutions of suspects.Mechanics of investigation looks like this: we arrive at the briefing and we learn what case are we supposed to solve. Then we go to the scene of the crime (most often we are dealing with murder), we are making an inspection of the place and we are looking for evidence that could be helpful in the case. When we are close to some significant object, the game tells us via a specific sound, so we know that in this place there is something important, of course, you can turn it off. Each of evidence gives us some new clues. After collecting relevant evidence (in which may include the murder weapon, bills, bank statements, wallets, pictures and others), it's time to hear witnesses on the scene. When you hear the answer to the question we asked, we can decide whether a person is telling the truth, if you doubt in what he/she says (though we have no direct evidence for this), or perhaps he/she is lying. After some time we reach the potential suspects, in which hearings can be supported by evidence found at the crime scene. A further order of investigation is generally subordinated to the scenario outlined by the authors, however, led by our hearings or visits to key locations can accelerate or delay the investigation. And don't worry, in the final phases of the investigations no shortage of gunfights and car chases, but if you want more shoot, invest in side missions and occupy a street crimes.When it comes to graphic design here is a little bit worse, though facial expressions and general appearance of characters fully make up for that. While the city itself has two sides of the coin: nicely presented (I mean here especially for skyscrapers, parks, alleys and smaller houses), but quite often creates the impression of a slightly extinct. On the streets moves fewer people than would indicate the size of this metropolis. And I must admit that the size of the virtual Los Angeles makes quite an impression when we launch the map available on the menu. The execution of city lacks nothing, but I would feel that it is really alive!Sound design and music is definitely one of the strengths of this production. The soundtrack is filled with 26 songs inspired by the era in which the game takes place and it is not climatically, but simply phenomenal. Subtle jazz sounds in execution of trumpets, saxophones, percussion and string instruments is a mixture, which any movie of the higher shelf wouldn't be ashamed of. A more dynamic compositions also don't stick out on a step from the rest. Equally excellent are the voices of all the characters. This game is a feast for our ears.The icing on the cake in L.A. Noire was supposed to be perfectly devoted facial expressions of the characters created by a special session of the motion-capture engulfing the faces of real actors and I must admit that it works very decently. Although facial expressions, if you can call it that way, are very stereotypical and relatively easy to recognize whether a person is calm or hiding something.SUMMARY (TL:DR)In L.A. Noire players have received what they wanted most: climate, climate and climate once more. Detective sheath, an advanced facial expression betraying emotions of the characters, crime mysteries of the City of Angels, charismatic characters and music that simply melts in our ears compensate for slightly brutal simplification of the sections of arcade and a little disappointing visuals. Sincerely, this is one of my favorite titles.

												+ Intersting Story+ Unique Gameplay- Repetitive Answers- Random Answers- locked 30 fps8/10It's a fun game about being a detective and solving crimes about finding clues and interrogating suspects. You will not find any other kind of game like LA Noire. The bad points are that the game will repeat clues, and you will notice them. Ex: * you found a clue... you should check out the Steam Cafe.      *Gabe says he works at the Steam Cafe... you should check it out.      * The Steam Cafe is located near the crime scene... you should go investigate it.Another problem is when you have to question someone for doubt or lie, you have to somehow bring up a clue that's comepletely off topic.Ex: Gabe: "I've been working at the cafe the whole time. My alibi clears me!"You: "You're lying! You're the culprit!"Gabe: "prove it!"You: you bring up Half Life 3... "Why isn't this out yet?!"Gabe: "Oh! You got me!" *correct answer*Overall, it's a good game with multiple interesting stories of crime. I completely recommend it if you're interested in solving crimes by finding clues and detecting people are lying.

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Let's start out with what you will probably be looking at the most: the facial animations are amazing and will help you decide if a suspect is lying or telling the truth. The graphics still look pretty decent for an older game and L.A. Noire has a fantastic atmosphere and a great soundtrack. Altough the game doesn't really have a main story, the individual cases are really interesting and well put together. Even if L.A. Noire is by no mean a free roaming game there are some fun side activity's to do. You can search the city for unlockable cars, view points(certain locations) and there are some side missions to do. The game also has some nice shootouts and chases!Sadly, this game also has some downsides. The city of Los Angeles can feel a bit empty at times and the cases can feel a bit repetitive after a while. After finishing about 70% of L.A. Noire (DLC included) it just felt to repetitive and my interest in the game was lost. I think this is mainly because there is no real story, just some individual cases.All together i would still highly recommend this game. It's truly an amazing expierence and well worth the money, Even if you don't finish it completely.

number of helpful: 25 of 35 people (71%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Stop. Stop reading, GET THIS GAME!This is a fantastic story worthy of being slapped with 10/10, kudos and praise. Why? Because this game is like "Guardians of the Galaxy", it has personality, action and narrative.You are Detective Cole Phelps, and are a badass at solving cases. You will run through numerous cases investigating clues and interrogating suspects, unraveling a conspiracy and a kickass story, and half the time your partners will "pull rank" or flat out refuse to do a foot chase and leave it all to you :PPros:OMG GRAPHICS. Did I mention graphics? This game has the most amazing facial graphics ever. It should be, because they use motion capturing on people's faces and you can actually see emotion in their faces!!! Once you play this game you will be disapointed with every game out there that doesn't come up to snuff. It is simply gorgeous, and groundbreaking to tell if someone is lying via actual cues in their behavior and their faces! The interactivity of the game, with player and character are grade A. The gameplayer borrows alot from GTA, with cars behaving similarly but to me feel alot better. The gun play is clunky but intuitive, it doesn't kick you out of cover akwardly or just unwieldy to do sometimes. *cough* Mass Effect *cough*. Overall, it just feels nice and awe-inspiring to see the period perfect LA, based on real cars, on real settings and with distinct personalities. From villains to partners, you will loathe, love and grumble at people who feel real and you could have sworn probably exist in real life.Con:IT IS TOO SHORT. The usual benefits of getting a game on PC are the mods. Well, it doesn't have great mod capabilities and therefore the modding community can't mod new stories and there's so little DLC. I would reccomend buying this on console unless you can find it cheaper on PC.Overall, buy it on console unless the PC version is cheaper. It's simply easier to control and feels more native on console.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												LA Noire is one of the best and most original games ive played in long long while, it has plenty of flaws but it is still very enjoyable.The game is locked to 30 fps to preserve the factions animations while are crucial while interrogating a person and this causes the game to feels slow and sluggish at times and will take a few hours to get used to.The game is set in 1940s and you play as Cole Phelps a war hero who slowly climbs the ranks from patrol to vice and near the end stages of the game you play as jack kelso a investigator who was in the war with Cole.The are 21 main cases (26 if you buy the dlc) and they average around 1 hour each or more depending upon how many restarts and retries it takes you.The 1940s settings is really amazing, the theme overall is mature and the characters are very distinct, the cases are really intriguing to solve and there is a sense of danger in the air.Apart from the main cases their are 40 mini-cases which take 2-10 mins each and a lot of collectables and for a open world games its not really something you want to hear not enough side-quests yet it fits the detective theme of the game so it gets away in that regard.This game stays true to what it is and by that i mean for the most part you will search for clues, interrogate suspects and solves cases in doing so and the combat isnt a huge factor where you mow down hundreds of people, the combat is decent enough but since its not the main focus its serviceable, you get intuition points when you rankup and these can be used to find clues or help you chose the correct response to a question asked to a suspect, the ability to interrogate suspects is the games biggest strength as different people have different tells and you have to chose if they are telling the truth or lying and if you think they are lying you accuse them by doubting them or flatout tell them that they are lying and if you select the latter then you must provide evidence of their lie otherwise you will get it wrong.You can fail cases and get wrong suspects (in cases which have multiple suspects) if you miss any evidence or dont manage to get something out of them.The driving isnt that thankfully you can skip it by letting your partner driver which will skip the driving section of the game.The NPCs always comment on your actions if you driver recklessly your partner will warn you if you run and push citizens aside they will complain,you will pickup your dropped hat, etc LA noire gets a lot of these small things right.There is an option to play it in black in white if you so desire.There is a feature called action skip where it will ask you to skip a section of the game if you fail it multiple but these are only in areas where you wont miss out anything.Overall i really found LA noire to be a mature game where cases are intriguing and is an actual detective game where you do all the detective stuff and not just shoot people, the detective stuff is basically what you will do 70% of the time.I really wish Rockstar will make a sequel one day its been years since this game release and technology has only improved.This game truly deserves a sequel not story or character wise but mechanics wise maybe a Miami Noir or something along those lines, with new tech and ironing out the rough edges of this game i hope we get a sequel but atm we dont and that makes me sad.

number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												LA Noire is a crime story set in 1947 Los Angeles. Policeman Cole Phelps, a decorated war hero, is eager and principled, and a "good caseman". Thus, he works his way up the ladder and gets to investigate in cases with rising stakes. But there is something in his past that is haunting him. Through his eyes, players experience a world gone by that is in many ways similar to ours, yet also quite different - World War II still casts a shadow over society, police work sometimes takes incredible shortcuts just so a case can be closed or what would pass for bigotry today is still widely accepted etc.What utterly fascinated me about LA Noire was the painstaking amount of detail with which the world of 1947 had been recreated: 8 square miles of Los Angeles are waiting to be explored. While it's only necessary to use certain routes to get to case locations, it's always possible (and indeed tempting) to drive around the streets to just take in the sights and sounds (e.g. the car radio plays original programmes). I cannot count how many times I had Cole stop the car so I could check what this interesting building or that odd thing were, or so I could take a screenshot. It's likely the closest I will ever come to being in the 1940s' USA, unless time machines become a reality.Sadly, one can hardly with the game's world outside of the cases; don't assume this to be like Grand Theft Auto. At least there are a few achievements to be gained for those who like to explore every nook and cranny.Phelps will work on the cases the department to which he is assigned at the time, e.g. patrol or homicide. The work on such a case consists of collecting clues at crime scenes, shootouts, fist fights, chases and tailing people by car or foot and the interrogation of witnesses and suspects. The interrogations use a (at the time when the game was made) new technology of facial motion capture that allows the faithful recreation of every small expression in the actors' faces. That is important, because most of the time, people are trying to hide something, which will invariably show in their faces. They have twitchy eyes, swallow nervously, etc.It's up to the player to judge when they're being lied to - but a lie can only be called out successfully when evidence to the contrary has been gathered before, and when the player can correctly pick that evidence from their case notes. If a lie can't be proven, one can doubt what was said. The last option is to treat a testimony as truth.This part often drove me nuts. I could see that the person was not telling the truth, but I wasn't sure what I was even meant to prove or which evidence to use against them. Example below - attention, spoiler for one interrogation question. ----SPOILER-----One example: There was a suspect with a penchant for anarchism who had probably tampered with machinery, and Cole confronted him with the accusation. The man declined. The game asked me: Was he lying? I knew I had nothing to prove he had committed the sabotage, but he looked a bit twitchy. Therefore, "Doubt" seemed fitting. Yet the correct interrogation option was "Lie", since then, Cole mentioned his political tendencies and the suspect  asked in return whether there was evidence that he was campaigning for anarchism. Okay, so, a different thing to prove.So I chose the political pamphlet he had given to his colleague as proof - after all, passing it on to someone else showed he was proselytizing. Wrong again: The proof the game wanted was the same pamphlet from his own locker.----SPOILER-----Then, there are optional sidequests called street crimes. When Phelps and his partner drive through the streets, they will often get alerted to crimes happening at that moment, and they have the choice of responding and taking care of the situation. Those missions use some of the gameplay elements from the main game, minus the interrogations and crime scene investigation.I did get bored after a while. There is a lot of content to play through, and while the cases are varied and sometimes interconnected in interesting ways, I just had had enough of the game's mechanics. Took me a long break to get back into it.But having followed Cole Phelps through all his cases, I'm left impressed. His world is a very imperfect one, where some people commit crimes for the same selfish reasons that have always driven humans, while others try to do the right thing but may well fail at that. It's indeed a noir movie's take on reality.(Notes:1. To get the Steam achievements, the game must be played online.2. Do stay till after the credits, there is one more scene.)

												AAI + GTAThirty five hours, much longer than I expected it would be. You'll probably spend most of the time driving from one point to the next, but if you ever feel like that's too tedious you have fast travel.Cases were well put together as were the investigations. Shooting gangsters was nothing to write home about, but the vehicle chase segments were fun (even if civilians saw fit to throw themseleves at the front of my car half the time).  Speaking of cars, there's 95 different varieties of magnificently archaic vehicles for you to find and commandeer if that's your thing (it should be). The game might have crashed four or five times but the autosave prevented any serious loss of time. One of the most varied games I've seen in awhile, strong on a lot of fronts and always prime to switch up on you before it gets too stale. Stout Scarab best car in the game.

Posted: December 21, 2016
												So I haven't finished this game on here yet but I accidentally left it on so lmao have some more hours then I've playedANYWAY I thoroughly enjoyed this game - it basically is a point and click but it's not really. The gameplay consists of going to a crime-scene and interrogating people, where deducing whether they are holding something back (doubt), telling the truth, or lying (when they're lying you always need evidence) - with the facial motion capture its usually pretty obvious. You gather clues by finding stuff at the crime-scene used for interrogations and to figure out the case. You drive to and fro everywhere you need to go. Ocassionally the more you get into the game, there will be chase sequences both in cars and on foot, and there will be shoot-outs, as well as when you have to tail a suspect (without being seen, which is annoying). The map is huge, and I suggest if you're an achievement hunter you drive everywhere instead of getting your partner to do it. I enjoyed the story (i guess there kinda was an over reaching one).Each case is pretty interesting, and the game feels very authentic in regards to the period.A problem I have is the FPS cap, because, come on we are on PC here guys we don't have to put up with 30FPS. There are guides to break the cap which is useful.Overall the game is pretty good, I enjoyed it anyway :) its quite a long one though so sometimes replayability (especially as soon as youve finished it, can be a bit daunting).

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												L.A Noire is a very successful hybrid between an early 90's adventure game such as Monkey Island and Broken Sword with the open world and combat/driving mechanics of GTA.You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a WW2 veteran who is trying to work his way up the law enforcement ladder of the Patrol/Traffic/Homicide/Vice/Arson division all while trying to deal with the hostility of his co-workers and the inner corruption of the police force. If you've ever watched a Detective Noir movie like L.A Confidential then you pretty much know what to expect plot wise.The adventure part of the gameplay will be familiar to anyone who's played adventure games in the early-mid 90's. You explore the crime scenes of your cases looking for items and clues that will help you in your investigation and then questioning the suspects of the case with the evidence that you have accumulated. The interviewing part is well done with some great voice acting and animation although the facial expressions can be a bit TOO subtle at times, you pretty much can't lose though as the story will still progress even if you get all the answers wrong.The driving/shooting aspect is similar to any other open world game and you will be chasing and gunning down plenty of criminals during the 20-25 hour campaign. The theme and style of 1940's LA comes across really well with a brilliantly detailed city that has plenty of locations to explore, old fashioned cars to drive and a great albeit short period soundtrack.Anyone who is a fan of Noir movies and open world games with a mix of old school adventure will have a great time playing L.A Noire.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Much to my surprise, I love this game. It's attention to detail, animation, dialogue and story reminded me of when the original Mafia was released.As much as I love it, there are lots of annoyances. I agree with others that interviews can be illogical, but any excuse for more cutscenes and dialogue. Walking and driving controls are the usual Rockstar Engine-irritating.Running around the map with no concequences for your actions, and nothing to fear in the game dissolves any real tension or excitement. Can't catch a bag guy driving away? Don't worry, eventually something is scripted to stop them.Mission failed for shooting a fleeing suspect, but its ok to kill 10 of their friends because they didn't.But my biggest gripe is how beautiful and detailed the world is, but so much of it goes unnoticed or is wasted. Some of the most detailed, true to life and beautiful buildings or interiors are hidden behind doors or tucked away in parts of the map that you're never given a reason to visit. And if you do find them, there is no reason to stay or visit again. It made me realise that I took for granted the stores and mini-games in Red Dead Redemption, for example.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												The atmosphere in this game is great, it's a sleazy 1940s LA straight out of a Raymond Chandler novel. The immersion is sometimes broken by the odd daft action sequence but overall the story is well written and executed with great voice acting and facial expressions on the models.The game is really all about the story. Although it is open world there is little to interact with - the huge and beutifully detailed game world is more there for the immersion.The main downside is that it runs horribly on PC. The game engine is locked to 30fps apparently and there are often fps drops whenever there is anything fast happening on screen. When compared to other open world games with fantastic graphics like Mafia 2 and Skyrim this game runs like a one-legged asthmatic pensioner. Seems Rockstar don't make any effort to optimise their games for the PC master race anymore.Overall I can recommend it as the techincal issues are not game breaking because 95% of the time it is exploration/puzzle/adventure type gameplay and not action/shooter type gameplay where the crappy framerate would soon give you a headache.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												An interesting idea and concept, let down by the terrible story pacing for the first 2/3rds of the main story. Not that you can discern there is one at that point. In the last 1/3, the story does finally start going somewhere, picks up the pace and becomes enjoyable. A critical part of the game are interrogations, but deciding what evidence counts as enough to expose a lie vs doubting something, or what "truth" or "doubt" will actually cause your character to do say are anybodies guess. It always felt like a total crapshoot throughout the game. Never mind that it doesn't actually matter - somewhere during testing the game designers must've realized this and you can't actually fail even if you miss all the answers.This isn't a bad game, but it isn't quite as good as the reviews made it out either. Only play it if the premise sounds enjoyable and you're willing to plow through the first part.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Do you like the 50's?Do you like Detective games?Do you like dark plottwists?Boy do I have the game for you.You Play as Detective Cole Phelps (masterfully performed by aaron Staton) who just came back from the war and became a Police officer. Your main goal is given to you by each completed (or failed) case. What this includes is checking crime scenes and finding evidence that can later help you interrogate suspects who might seem innocent on the outside but holds dark secrets for you to unfold. The game hold action such as gunfights and fist fights but the real main objective is to go old school 50's detecive way. Pros ++ Amazing storyline+ Awesome voice actors+ Great soundscore+ Stunning face movments+ Fist fights are pretty cool (some hate the fist fight scenes though guess it's up to taste)+ over 20+ hours of content (including sidequest and dlc's) the story is far and deep and will take some time for you to find all the clues or finding all the possible ways you can go about a case such as who you might want to interrogate first e.t.c+ Replayability, many games usually fail with this from my perspective. The reason is because you might fail a case and arrest the wrong guy or not finding enough evidence and might wanna solve them all or if you just like the cases (have 80+ hours on my PS3 before deciding to get it on my PC)Cons -- Gun fights are limited to only Tommyguns, Shotgun and Pistols and are very tedious to deal with- The face movement may be awesome as well as the voice acting but it's sometimes hard to tell if they're lying or telling the truth as they tend to do some very shall we say... akward faces. They sometimes makes it way too easy, hard or funny looking- Tedious sidequest as they don't serve any real purpose, sure you can get XP from it but max lvl is 20 and I reached that after just 5-6 main mission quests so they serve little purpose.- Graphical glitches and slow FPS, I didn't have this problem but some have. Some have had poorly made computers whilst others had top of the line gear and still had these errors so it's random I guessAll and all I give this game a 8/10It's no masterpiece, but not far from. It has great voice acting great story and just all around fun.30 euro is and ok price epecially since you get the complete edition

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												LA Noire is 3rd person action game that concentrates on investigating crimes by inspecting crime scenes and interrogating witnesses. Cases are more or less unrelated, but still provide great story as a whole. Wish they make a sequal with modern technologies and better optimization.Good+ Story (several stories unravel at once, each on it's own pace)+ Visuals are so-so but face animation was really good for 2011 (yes i know that it just pre-recorded stuff, like movie :( )+ Good balanced approach to investigation (this is no easy mode, like in most of games nowadays, but it helps you a little)Bad- GPU greedy (almost like Crysis back in 2007)- Faces have more details than city itself.- Rockstar Social Club (which does nothing, but slowdown start time)- Not much of replay value- No cloud saves- No SteamPlay (win only)Bottom line: worth full price if you can run it and interested in detective genre.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												What can you say about this game? I played this game back on console and didn't like it's change of pace from a GTA type shoot 'em up open world.Fast forward a few years and as I matured as a person and a gamer, this game has been a hallmark in my gaming adventure. The recreation of L.A is superb, and even though I have ever visited the city, it's the small things that ground the game for me and make it a real place. Like seeing a box of Kellogg's Corn Flakes in a store window or hearing a advert for it in the car radio.The cases within the game are well structured, and seem very real. The story is a masterpiece.The PC port itself is quite bad, it is locked at 30FPS. But this, for me, doesn't detract from the game itself and even with that in mind, it is still a highly recommended game from me.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												GREAT game!  Seriously, this game is amazingly well done!  The story is very interesting and really fun -- a nice blend of foot chases, shoot-outs, trailing suspects in your various vintage cars, searching crime scenes, and role-playing detective work.  Also, I have to say that this game has, without a doubt, some excellent character animation.  The skins of the characters are based on real actors (some of whom you'll be sure to recognize from TV and movies) and the facial espressions, mannerisms, and body language of the in-game characters is suberb!The interrogation/questioning of suspects aspect of the game is, admittedly, a bit hard to learn, but once you get the hang of it it actually is one of the most interesting parts of the game.Oh, and about those vintage cars: They've also recreated an amazing rendition of late 1940s Los Angeles that you can cruise around  via your vehicle.  If you search around, you'll be able to find lots of interesting rides (rare sports cars, an ambulance, etc.).  I've thoroughly enjoyed taking cars that aren't mine and driving them to death, literally, by jumping off embankments, taking out mailboxes at 60mph, and other things we've all wanted to do with a car at some point.  By the time I'm done, my ride-of-the-day is a smoldering wreck on the side of the road.  Totally fun!Anyway, I haven't completed the game yet; I've played about 10 hours into it.  But so far, it's awesome.P.S. The DLC is totally worth it too, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Ok, I'll try my best not to spoil anything (wrote review after I finished the ending credits):Waw, what a game. You're in for a rollercoaster that just gets faster and deeper the more you progress. In my opinion you should look at this game like you're participating actor in a very well done Noir series that could air on TV any day.For a 2011 game it also still looks pretty great on full detail, the score and soundtrack is well done, suited to the era and atmosphere of the game. Cinematography feels like a movie too.A few tips for people who are diehard about the story though:- Take some time to see the town, you'd be surprised what you find.- Learn from your mistakes, don't use wikia unless absolutely necessary or if you want that 5star rating on your 2nd try.- It's an 18+ game for a reason, respect that while you play it. Some scenes really can be shocking for some people, so take it as a warning.As conclusion (it's almost impossible to tell anything about this game without spoiling it), get it. If you fancy the era, the music, the detective genre, the noir genre, if you like puzzles, storytelling, if you like environmental accuracy or just like retro/vintage in general......get this game! You won't be dissapointed.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												An underrated gem.L.A Noire is an open world adventure game where you play the role of take no♥♥♥♥♥♥detective Cole Phelps in 1940's Los Angeles. The gameplay mostly revolves around investigating crime scenes for clues and scenes where you interrogate suspects and try to decided weather they're telling the truth or if they're full of crap.The awesome thing about this game is the highly detailed and lifelike facial motion capture on the characters. It's so detailed that you're not watching pre-rendered animations, you're actually watching performances by actors and it's pretty amazing to see. The game world is immaculately detailed and a joy to cruise around and experience.I loved this game and I hope you will too because it needs a sequel ASAP.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2012
												This game is amazing. In its entirety it’s intriguing and different.I like the detail put into it. In most games simple unimportant characters don’t really have a face of their own, they just use the same few models. (E.g. the citizens in Half-Life 2) but in this, every character has their own face and therefore their own identity, and I really liked that. They were all built around their voice actors and it was really amazing to see 3 or 4 actors that I knew of, appear in a video game. That was something that really did impress me.It’s mainly a detective type game, and there is a lot more action to it than your average detective game. You get to drive around an open world city responding to street crime, be involved in car chases, find clues for your investigation and interrogate your subjects making sure you judge them right.I only have one problem with this game and that’s the storyline. It isn’t exactly a “game breaker” for me, I just found it a little disappointing. At first I was extremely intrigued with the plot and it felt like it was going to go somewhere great and be really good, but it just wasn’t. I found it very up and down, it leads up to one thing then completely changes the subject.At the end of every mission you are given a score as to how well you did, and there are some points where you can’t avoid doing the wrong thing, which I thought was really stupid. There’s even one part you get told off for doing the right thing! I just thought that it was all over the place when it came to plotline.Apart from that I think this game is great, it’s a lot of fun and it’s not something you see all that often.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												To resume L.A. Noire quickly, it's the story of a LAPD cop named Cole Phelps and his rise & fall in the police system, all while questioning a bunch of people about various crimes. This game manages to immerse you into the past, in the late 40's as a LA police officer trying to climb the ladder.I like alot of things about this game: The ambience, the music, the facial system, the captivating storyline, the relevance of almost everything placed in the decor, the dialogue, etc, and the list goes on. Rockstar/Team Bondi (R.I.P.) have done an amazing job on this game, making sure to create a different feel than in their previous games (such as Bully or GTA). There is no other game like this one, and that's a quality I love when it comes to good games.The story will run you at the very minimum at least 26 hours (DLC included) and you can then retry past cases individually to try and get better. I like to play through L.A. Noire about once every 1/1,5 years (it's kinda like a movie, where it's as enjoyable as the first time once you let some time pass and come back to it).I would recommend getting the complete edition of this game to any fan of Noire TV series or movies, and fans of well scripted detective games. DO NOT come into L.A. Noire expecting exactly the same as GTA but as a cop in the 40's because you will be very dissapointed. That being said, the game is amazing, probably the most immersive game i've played.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Fantastic game.  Always enjoyed detective movies/shows, so getting this is a no-brainier.  Worth playing; Recommend getting the "complete" edition if if gets on sale (usually only a few bucks more than base) and it comes with a few more missions and such. Music: It has some good '40's music playing on radios, but when you drive it's just soundtrack (shame i know) But the OST is still good regardless. Would like to hear some music while I just drive around. - 8.5/10Graphics: Facial animation is stunning. The lengths they've gone to; amazing. 30fps cap. 9/10Story: The more you play, the better it gets. You get flashbacks of Detective Cole back in the war after every few cases, and reading newspapers will give you back-story on "current events" (or something)  9-ish/10  Plot twists on your plot twists.Driving: I don't like it. Too sensitive for me. Tap directional key and the car moves across the street. No mouse steering. No in-car radio. When driving it's always the background music. (shame). No drive-and-shoot (Your a detective with common sense. That's why.)  5/10 - Average, could be better.   -- Reckless driving will give you a lower end-case rating. so don't cause city/personal damage - This isn't GTA. You're a traffic cop gone detective. A man of the law.  -- You can always hold "E" to let your partner drive to the location selected (if there are case-related dialogue; that will be said, then loading screen then you'll be at the location; with you behind the wheel.  - If there are car chases, you'd have to drive no matter what.World and level designs: the city is giant. Streets seem well done with placement of names, ads, and such that is realistic.The main map has almost every street on it, so when dispatch says "on the corner of this and that" you check the map and see what streets to take (there's no on-road line to see where to go) 9/10- The buildings are well made, with loads of clutter of personal items like photos that make it seem like there's someone living in there.- Only enter buildings with a Golden doorknob. So don't know what floor the perp is on? look for the golden doorknob. - The cars, buildings, clothes, even some speech is something from the '40/'50s - Devs captured it perfectly.Overall: 9/10 - Play now.TL;DR: Buy this game. Sale or full, get it. Worth every cent.  Good luck detective.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13
												LA Noire is a detective game published by Rockstar and Bondi. It has some adaptations from the GTA series but they are not as large. One of them is a funny one, in GTA you were stealing cars, in LA Noire you can get inside any car by just stopping them and entering. It is developed by Rockstar so you'll have to deal with Rockstar Social club which can end in save file corrupting, losing accounts and things among those lines.The game is set in Los Angeles, as you might have guessed by the title, right after World War II. As our main character Cole Phelps, is an ex-marine, this opens up for some WW2 flashblacks and some returning co-marines that are connected to Cole. LA allows for a big setting for a game and you can also opt for a Black and white mode which is definitly as beautiful as with colours. Unfortunately the problem with a big city as big as LA is that it can lag quite a lot rendering parts of the map which makes driving not always as smootly. The music is a mixture of investigation music or music from shootouts which is the same the whole game and whenever you driving you can enjoy songs from that time mostly popular ones. If you are into that kind of music or heard such music before you'll recognise a lot of songs. The story is more the character trying to redeem himself from the actions he done in the war with a sad ending. I think the sad ending made the main character shine even more because he didn't get the respect he deserved for a big part of the game. I can't say I didn't enjoy it, although theres one part that I really found unnecessary. The demotion from Vice to Arson was pretty uncalled for, okay I agree, cheating on your wife is pretty bad. But that shouldn't get in the way of your career. I think it would've been better if they put Arson before Ad Vice and worked the ending out there. Ad vice had to do a lot with the army surplus morphine that had been stolen. It could've easily worked too.The gameplay is worked out very well, the work fits right into the setting and the cases are very good overall. The work you do in this game is detective work, which means you'll be solving cases. Or when you don't want to for a while you can solve street crimes. Before each case, at least in most of them, you get shown a cutscene showing us how the crime happened without showing faces and giving clear clues away. In the cases themselfs you find clues to help solve your case, requires you to sometimes brawl or shoot your suspects. Brawling in this game is amazing it feels like a boxing game. You sometimes also have to chase suspects or how they call it in this game subduing. It is a very bland objective since sometimes shooting in the foot doesn't fail the case for killing them and sometimes it does kill them. You are on thin ice trying to shoot a suspect you are chasing because it is not clear if it is allowed. In the cases you also get help from a partner depending on what desk you are in, I'll be mentioning the different partners and desks later. Whenever you are driving with the partner it starts a conversation with them about the case giving you side information or their insight. You could also use them as a sort of GPS. Do remind yourself that once you choose to reveal a new side mission that the partner will direct towards that. You also get to question your suspects which is for me the best part of the game. They have really spent an amount of detail to the facial expressions in an interview although the mouth may go out of synch with the voice sometimes. You have three options after you asked your question, whetether you believe him or doubt him or believe that he is straight up lying. You can recognise in the facial expressions in the small details what direction it is going in although making out a doubt from a lie depends how much you have progressed in the case and how much you can charge against him. When you are finished you get shown a case reports with the amount of clues you found and the amount of questions you have done correctly. Aside from that and the rating, in stars, you get some side information sometimes revealing what you missed.Desks:Patrol is the standard police work before we get a real taste of the detective work. This is mainly an overextended interactive tutorial more meant to show us the ropes of the game and to intrest us in the rest of the game. It also makes us more acquaintanced with the main character. Traffic surprised me more or less. If you do not know what Traffic means in cop terms, it mainly is about solving hit and runs. What surprised me that every case contained the hit and run with that little element extra what didn't make an ordinary hit and run. In Traffic you get partnered with Stephen Bekowski. He is a pretty rookie cop in the Traffic department but so are you so you learn a lot from each other making it both to Homicide eventually.Homicide is probably the longest rank you have in the game. It is twice as long as any other desk in terms of cases, unless you count the DLC cases, and the missions themself are also longer compared to Traffic. Homicide is researching and solving murders. I like how they managed the endings of the cases, giving the player an open ending, and also the question if you did the cases right. The open endings made the final case even better which was mainly designed around missing clues from other cases and most of the landmarks in LA. You get partnered up with Rusty Galloway in Homicide. He is a good cop who can't wait on his pension and he expresses that most of the time. The conversations about the cases were definitly the most interesting in the game since it was more a discussion which made me doubt too. Ad Vice is trying to stop the drug empire from happening. The Ad vice story itself is pretty short, again without DLC, but the cases are pretty lengthy on themselfs. The surprise to me whas the shoot first then ask questions later mentality in this desk. Which made it more exciting, I also think the drug empire in this game is pretty interesting how it works. They also connect with Cole his backstory , his time in the war as a marine, giving a chance to see most of the ex-marines back again. Roy Earle is impressed by your work in Homicide that's why he pulls you over to Ad Vice to be his partner. Roy Earle is a detective we already met an Homicide case and I didn't like him then and I still don't like him. He is by a landslide my least favourite parnet in any game with a buddy system. He thinks the only way to solve things is by being rude and aggressive. He does know the drug community inside out and teaches us a lot about that and also how the LAPD really operates. Arson desk is the solving of domestic fires and finding out how they happened. These cases are only meant to connect with the ending so that all the pieces fit togheter. I wouldn't mind that they had added some extra, non-DLC, but I like the appearance of the ex-marines again and the whole scandal around them. I also like that Cole isn't the only one investigating in this desk, what I mean with that will be clear once you play this desk fully. You get partnered with Herschel Biggs in Arson. Herschel has been in the war too but not the second one, which gives you an idea of how old he is at the time. Herschel is a very grumpy character but he is the only one who would never question a decision made by Cole without helping him in any way. That is how a partner needs to be. What I missed with Herschel is the conversations, they are there but very short.LA Noire is in my eyes a must pick up, if you love the setting of the 1940-1950's America with the classic detective with interactive cases which are sometimes pretty confusing to solve. I do not know if the DLC's are worth picking up, can't wait to find out for myself.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												For those that remember and loved the Police Quest games this one is up your ally.  La Noire lets you find clues, question suspects, do crazy car chases and lots of shoot'em ups with the bad guys.The game engine used for this game is massive!!  There are so many streets to drive place to see, that doing all the 21 mission (DLC included) will not let you experience the whole map of L.A.  What is also nice is the small little details in the game.  The radio music playing while your drive or the news broadcasts are specific to the time of the game.  The cars also all handle differently from each other.On the hunt for some of the collectibles in the game I left my partner behind, after stopping in another part of the city a black and white police car stopped sirens blaring.  My partner got out and had some choice words for me leaving him behind.  This brings me to the voice acting which is really good for a game on this scale.  The small talk between your character and you partner on the specific desk can be a times really amusing.The annoying parts of the game are 2 achievements that you need to get to complete the game 100%.  One is the hunt for the golden films reels and the other is driving all the 95 vehicles in the game.  The film reels are movies related to the time, but they are hidden in such places that you will never find them during normal game play.  A quick Google will net you clues and maps to where all the golden film reels are.  The other pain is driving all the vechiles in the game. :(  This took me a couple of days to complete.  In the end I found a site that made it easier to get some of the vehicles.  For this you need to go to the Extras in the Main Menu, then the vehicle show room.  Move to the blacked out vechile and press ENTER for about 20 seconds. Escape to the Main Menu again and go to Cases and Select the Homocide Desk (Free Roam).  As soon as the map is loaded get out of the car and you will see the car that you need drive by.  For this you will need to Google to find a picture of the car needed.  If the car does not drive by check the parking lot across from the police station to see if it is there.  Some of the cars are mission specific and will only be found in certain missions or street crimes.  This will also only work for the 2 door and 4 door types of cars.All in all this is an amazing game.  If you follow your clues and check your suspects facial expression you may become a top rated detective.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Imagine if you wanted to play Sherlock Holmes, but instead of solving crimes set centuries ago, you substitute it with a living real-world city from the modern era, put amazing attention to detail into everything, gameplay that somehow manages to overshadow firefight sequences by a longshot AND a character with a relatable dedication to his work paired with an interesting subplot, and you've gotten L.A. Noire.The gameplay keeps me invested to a degree which I find awe inducing for such a game. I'm usually not into detective/murder mistery type games because it tends to be boring point-and-click gameplay with uninteresting writing that doesn't really reach out to me in any way.On the other hand, this game caught my eye with its fresh take on the genre, as Rockstar and Team Bondi spent a good amount of time doing research on the reality of criminal investigation of this era and while not exactly simulating real gunplay, is a fun experience that really feels grounded in reality.This doesn't exactly make it the kind of game you could play in short bursts, but rather something you wanna stretch out as with what most Rockstar DEVELOPED games tend to do. Even though this was developed by Team Bondi, I dare say it beats the production values of Rockstar titles of the time.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												L.A Noire takes you back to 1940's Los Angeles where corruption and drugs are everyday business.In this game you follow young ex-militairy Cole Phelps, who after winning several awards for his actions during the war signed up for the LAPD (Los Angeles Police Department)The game allows you to solve crimes with, or sometimes without a partner. While investigating for example a murder you have the option to question a witness, by paying close attention to their facial expressions or eye movement you can find out if they're either lying or telling the truth. Its exciting storyline and character developement is what makes this game such a masterpiece.As you follow Cole's career from Traffic to Homicide to Vice to Arson you get the feeling of being in a 1940's crime movie. Authentic clothing and infrastructure support this feeling. The game also allows you to free-roam, which makes it possible to drive around the city with your partner (Partner depends on what desk you chose) and respond to calls you get from the police radio. This game could just as well be a book because of its tensive storyline and fascinating character development.Overall I would give this game a 9/10.

												This game is more than just a story-driven rpg. It's a fully atmospheric experience of unpredicable events which will keep you immersed while playing, surprise you with the protagonist's difficult and shocking past, and simply - make you addicted to the game. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												The game is not the newest anymore and probably got plenty of reviews so I will try to be brief:The game is set in 1947 Los Angeles and I do really enjoy the setting and the story of the main charakter as well as the story of the cases you have to solve are quite deep and interesting. ( I wont say much about it because I dont intent to spoiler).The Missions are very well developed. You have to question suspects and pay attention for example in which order you ask questions or which evidences you provide. You have to check if you can dig up more evidence by visiting different people or points of interest, find information on places murderes happend or find information in letters, written orders or other types of papers. You often question people and either decide if they lie, tell the trueth or seem suspicious which you can tell by their facial expressions. (If they hide something they will often try to avoid looking at your or into your face and search the room with their eyes). There are shootings happening frequently. The side missions are often based on catching someone escaping from a crime scene or even shooting down all oponents. You can use their guns. Aiming and taking cover is similiar to  GTAV. So action is present in the game as too and balances it very well.It is very fun even if you fail in most cases you still will move on with the story but get less points by setting up wrong evidence or accuse them of a lie while they spoke the trueth to you. There arent many games that combine those features with an open world and an interesting story.The open world is interesting too since all the cars and environments are set in the last century. Do not expect a GTA V of course, The game is made in 2011 and the traffic AI is horrible in fact you can try to drive perfectly and the AI will simply ram you off if they want to switch the lanes.The environment is set in LA only and you cannot really leave the city. You can visit some real life landmarks, especially the train station is very nice as you can see incomming and leaving trains but sadly its also a bit glitched.There are no different radio stations which is a bit of a downer too. The city is very alive and you in fact are able to look into the different shops and even enter many houses and buildings.The pedestrians however act funny too. You should avoid to run them over since you are a cop you get a message you shall protect civillians and not bring them into danger. In fact you even can lose points if you do continue bad behavior.Another thing I personally dislike is the social club login. You always have to keep signing in but in LA Noire it simply wont save my account data and I regularyly have to retype it to be able to start the game.I payed 5 Euroes and 99 cents but the game was completely worth it. I enjoy it a lot and since you can handle the missions very differently, there is quite some replay value as well if you wanna keep puzzling on a perfect score.

												If you're looking for an action based game, this isn't it.That said, if you're a fan of plot-driven, detective-work based adventure games of yore, THIS IS YOUR FIX.The game has a massive fanbase in Japan for essentially being a visual novel with a sandbox framework, and it shows in both writing and execution.The only real downside I can think of is the uncanny valley potential (very large here), the fact that the sandbox is underutilized unless you go on many of the sidequests for collectables, and as a whole the plot escalation being a basic snowball in pace.In any case, a must buy for the complete version, and a major "wait for a sale" if you are focused on action moreso than anything else.

Posted: February 14, 2015
												A unique adventure game that borrows many features from mystery and action games, incorporating them seamlessly in the narrative flow, thus creating a truly special game that not everyone will enjoy. And that's because it has its own character, defying contemporary 'fast food' games that are churned out today and because it's reminiscent of endeavors made in another era, where immersion of an ultimate single-player experience was the first and last goal of their creators.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												The game is good. The gameplay is nice and all, but it feels very limited. The driving and walking physics are good, but climbing ladders, pipes, and going up fire escape stairs is very annoying. Hand-to-hand combat could've been much better.  No opinion on firing weapons, that was executed well. Driving physics are good, but car damage is very ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. So are NPC's in vehicles. They will randomly crash into you, or stop in the middle of the road, causing you to crash into them. There's a variety of outfits, challenges (not cases) and vehicles. Now for the story part. Is it just me or does it feel that Phelps is a cop for like two weeks? I mean, he starts off as a patrolman in early 1947, and the game finishes in September '47. He goes trough the Patrol Desk in like a week, same goes for Traffic. And then there is this six month gap where he is in Burglary (cut content) and he is Homicide for another week before being in Vice.  Again, he's in Vice for a week, then he gets supsended for like a day and is already back in Arson the day after. Oh, and he has like two whole cases in there and you waste your time with the final mission just to get to see "that" ending. The cases that you get to play are good, so is the questioning of your P.O.I's. But yes, the only thing that annoys me is how short the game is. And, it always made me think why none of Cole's partners got promoted. Phelps solved "The Fallen Idol" with the help of Bekowsky, and Stefan stayed in Traffic. Phelps solved The Dahlia case with Galloway, and again, only Phelps got bumped to Vice (although trough a special request), but still Galloway deserved some sort of promotion. Other than all that, good game.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Go get them Cole!L.A. Noire is in my opinion the perfect game. The perfect dose of action, suspense, story driven plot.We are given a ride thru the history of Cole Phelps. As he rises thru the ranks of the Police department, we get a history lesson has well a well paced travel into the human criminal mind. " there is one case that makes a detective, the one that doesnt let you sleep at night." This is the truth about this game. You deal with the "normal" crimes, robbery, murder, arson,etc. But nothing will prepare you for what lies further in the game. The graphic novelesk type story behind the insidious criminal mind that will remain a dark shadow while you play. Until you find out the truth. The vintage setting is just the iccing on top of this well rounded Cake. Worth it without a Doubt!

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I'll keep it smooth and ordered:Pro:- REAL mimics. They used a technology where they basically filmed the actors face and put it into the game. No animations, no face capture, you see real people there. That is the main selling point - at least for me - of the game because no other game used this since then. It is very expensive, that is why. - REAL(istic) movements. The motion capture worked really well, I rarely see this detailed animations. - Interesting cases. They're small full stories in themselves, but most of them somehow connects to the bigger picture. You start the game as a patrol, then as you move forward you became a detective. You solve cases at each different desk, but you only start to get the picture after half of the game. - Good main story. It is beliveable, the characters are detailed, such as their motivations. The plot twist impressed me. - I'd say nice cars as well, but that isn't a big thing to do these days. Contra:- Repetitive investigating. You use the same techniques and scripted animations over and over. - Also repetitive street crimes. Car chases, thefts and shootings. These were the three main types. Some were interesting though.- Annoying sound bugs. Had to restart the last mission from the beginning because couldn't heard sh*t from the last cutscene. - 30 FPS lock. And it drops below 24 even on a strong config. This is a smart game. The developers outdone themselves with the whole facial expression and mocap feature, but they didn't put as much emphasis on important things as they should have. My 27 hours playtime felt like 40 because I got bored many times during it. Still can't dislike it, if it's on sale go and buy it. 7/10

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14
												The story was wonderful.  I really thought that Cole was going to be this cookie cutter, always a goody two shoes (and very boring) kind of guy.  And while he does start off like that, Cole goes through some massive character development, as he starts realizing that the police had some seriously corrupt individuals running the show.  This game does touch on some sensitive issues, so if you have issues dealing with things like♥♥♥♥♥♥and child molestation, AVOID THIS GAME.  Granted, it is not the main part of the storyline, but you do run across those acts a few times during the entirety of the game.  Oh and don't forget that this is a noir game.  Keep that in mind and maybe you won't be tempted to take your comp out back and give it a beatdown when you finally hit the end. When the game told me I need to watch the face of the person I am questioning to see if they are sincere or not, I shook my head.  Great, here is another game that is going to ask you to do something damn near impossible.  I will admit that there are some, where you will need to listen to the voice as well as watch their face, but you should do that no matter what.  I will say this.  I did mute the volume just to see if I could read lips, and they were pretty readable.  One word of caution... if you suck at driving cars like I do, have your partners drive.  I realize that achievement hunters will have to manually control the car (which I did too... but let's just say some roads looked a lot like a tornado had blown through and car parts were everywhere).If you like crime games, noir, open world, lots of guns, cars, an excellent storyline with a great cast of actors... just get this game.   20 bucks is a good price, but if you see it on sale do yourself a favor and pick it up.  You'll be glad that you did.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												L.A. Noire is a real gem of my game library! It has everything I've ever wished for in detective games: * Open world with 95 vehicles you can drive. There is an Auto Fanatic achievement for starting engine of all vehicles available in the game at least once. Searching for more cars in game made me look at cars parked along sidewalks irl and think if they are those which are missing ;) * Wide variety of cases to solve under different departments of the police institute. It successfully prevents the game from being too repetitive and you get new partners to work on cases with. * Action! You will chase criminals and suspects on foot or in a vehicle. Combat involves both fist and gun fighting depends on a situation. But you must fight appropriately back or your mission will fail and you will have to start over. Weapons can only be used during firefights. If you can't successfully finish an action mission, the game will offer you to simply skip it and move on after the 3rd try. I think that's a great deal for people who are more interested in the story than in the challenges. * Many dialogues, questioning, truth, doubt and lie choices, great face mimic. * Nice graphics, attention to the detail, great voice acting. * You get to play character who's personality you learn more about through his behaviour, conversations and flashbacks of his past. You will find out he is a person who makes mistakes and who sure has skeletons in his closet.. It's pretty amazing how complex his personality is. I really like the twists we are getting there. I must say, don't let the 30 fps cap scare you away from one of the greatest detective games. You can easily fix it and increase it to 60.L.A. Noire is definitely worth of being finished. Towards the ending the game includes the most action scenes. Before that I used to play it when I wanted to relax after a hard day at work. Then things escalated and the story got a fast speed untill it reached the typical noire fiction ending.I really recommend the game from the bottom of my heart. Go for it :)

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												A new approach to the adventure genre. I‘m a fan of adventure games and i loved it. Of course the game is not perfect. I was amazed by the graphics when it came out on PS3 and purchased it. Now i bought it with all the DLC. Rockstar know how to make DLC, this is real DLC which adds about 8-9 hours of gameplay and the quality of DLC cases is great. It‘s integrated into the story cases and you can‘t even tell whether you‘re playing DLC or not.The facial animations still surprises me, i so want more games with similar technology. Wouldn‘t it be nice to se a walking dead game with such animations?The overall graphics is pretty good too. But the performance is not the strongest part of this game. The game is pretty old and the framerate is not very good. Of course i used the fix which unlocks 60fps it made the game better.Solving cases is fun, you search for the clues and talk to the witnesses and suspects and must decide if they‘re lying or not. The cases are different so it never gets boring. Story is very interesting too.It‘s an open world game but i really don‘t understand what’s the point of it. You have nothing to do except for story and side missions. The purpose of all that open map is only to drive from point A to point B.Anyway just grab this when you see it on sale, it‘s cheap now and is really worth it.

number of helpful: 76 of 142 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Let me preface this by saying: I did not expect GTA: 1940. I was told this was a puzzle game with some movie-like noir elements.That was wrong. L.A. Noire is a boredom factory. You push some buttons, you look around, you click through some dialogue and out comes the snores. The game is simple, the action sequences are usually holding the shift button as you jump over fences and short walls and other manners of game props while chasing a bad guy, and the 'puzzle' elements involve looking for one of the many shiny clue objects in a scene (there isn't even any clutter to complicate things, the console effect means that even in supposedly hectic scenes like a recently trashed apartment there are only a few interact-able props, which the main character will almost immediately tell you “isn't relevant to the investigation”) or walking around a room until a piano note sounds, then pressing a button and rotating an object to get the moron detective to look at all 4 sides of a knife before deciding it could be a murder weapon. No matter what you choose from the dialogue branches, the main character shoots off in whatever direction he fancies, so any immersion into the supposed movie atmosphere of the game is broken every time it prompts you for input because the talking heads have no flow to their discussion.“Stick with it”, they cry, “the later cases get pretty good!”Hogwash. It felt like a chore slogging through every single mission, at no point was I having fun. The stories aren't compelling, the gameplay isn't exciting, the puzzles aren't puzzles, and above all the voice acted dialogue sequences are an agony to sit through (not because of the voice acting, which is average at its worst). Pass, pass ten thousand times. I would rather play a real puzzle game, a visual novel, or an action game. L.A. Noire tries to do some mashup of all three and comes out a pile of turds. I think somebody accidentally released a facial emotion tech demo.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												L.A. Noire is a violent crime thriller that blends breathtaking action with true detective work to deliver an unprecedented interactive experience and follows the story of Cole Phelps, an ex-military and LAPD detective trying to climb in the ranks while fighting corruption and all-time high murder rates back in the 40's Los Angeles.L.A. Noire is a such a unique adventure game that borrows many features from mystery and action games, incorporating them seamlessly in the narrative flow, creating a truly special game.There's a wide array of vehicles and cases to solve under different departments, suspects to chase, either on foot or while driving and suspects in custody to interrogate.The graphics are amazing, the gameplay is pretty good, the soundtrack and voice acting are marvelous but what really makes this game a masterpiece is the astonishing and engaging story and the character development.I highly recommend L.A. Noire.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Rockstar has a lot of issues with their Social Club... but don't let that put you off this gem of a game. The rendering of 1940's L.A. is fantastic, and if it were a game for just a driving tour of the city, it would be worth buying for that element alone. The story is engrossing, if not quite completely fleshed out, and the character development and interactions with NPCs give the narrative a great flavor of the period.I just loved exploring the city. The cases and the whole "playing the detective" gameplay is well developed, if somewhat tricky (I had a hard time "reading" people to judge if they were lying, being evasive or telling the truth). I played the game "noir style" in black and white, and generally had no problems identifying clues despite the lack of color contrast.I got 60 hours of gameplay in my first playthrough and there is still tons of exploration to do. Would I play through the story again? Yes, emphatically. So I think the game is worth a look in, if you are still making up your mind. If anything, I was disappointed that the game ended (but also a little surprised by how abruptly it ended: NO SPOILERS). Recommended.

												Only a couple hours in, and I am completely amazed by this game. The facial details in this game are unparalleled (even for a 2011 game), even though sometimes the character's facial movements/expressions do not help you in interrogation. The story is also not completely erratic like others, yet keeps you on track enough just to keep you coming back for more. However, the game is not without it's flaws. Tasks such as running and gunning while goons are unloading whole mags on you feels a bit unresponsive at times, and I've had some minor graphical glitches dealing with character's heads at times. Overall, it is a really good game, and I would recommend for anybody who likes a good mystery.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												When this first came out, the first thing that came across my mind was Mafia II. And let me tell you, I like Mafia II a lot. So I thought this would be just a Mafia rip-off with only difference being the protagonist. Not a gangster, but a cop. Graphics looked similar, fighting system looked pretty  much the same and the setting was very similar too. But that was just me judging by simply looking at trailers. The differences are actually major.Later I received this game as a gift from my friend and, to be honest, I was quite impressed. That was after I managed to run it properly though. The game was rather choppy at first (which didn't suprise me since it was a well-known fact). I must admit I didn't even need to change too many things to make it playable. I probably got lucky.But enough of that, let's see what the game has to offer.Graphics is nice and the city this game takes place in, Los Angeles, is huge. It's very detailed and despite the impressive scale there are hardly any bugs. You'll find many types of cars and many character models with different textures. Almost everybody knows about the famous face expressions in this game. And yes, they did a good job with it, even though some people look more scary than real. I wouldn't call it a huge help during interviews with suspects either, because LA seems to mostly consist of professional liars. But don't get me wrong, it's a nice feature.Another good thing about this game is the music. And not only the score that puts you into right mood, but also great hits of the 1940's you will hear in the radio. Voice acting is provided by the same persons whose faces you actually see in the game, so the whole thing feels authentic. Sounds of weapons, cars and the city are your normal average sounds.Gameplay takes some time to get used to, but it's not bad. Walking, driving, shooting... You'll learn all that quickly. Then we have the other stuff that makes this game special. That means searching for clues and interviews. It might seem little confusing at the beginning, but there's a whole chapter of tutorial that also serves as an introduction for out protagonist - disciplined police go-getter named Cole Phelps. Sooner or later searching for clues will become a routine for you and you'll eventually get better at interviews. Those are made well too. You can either believe the suspect, doubt them or even accuse them of lying. But be careful! You must use correct clues to prove they're lying to you.And then we have the story. Is it good? Hard to say. It's mostly just cases to solve with a flashback cutscene from the war every now and then. Later in the game, Cole's personal life will get more space, but I won't be spoiling.I can absolutely recommend this game, even though there might be problems running it properly and you might need to find some tips on how to make it run smoother. Some cases are brilliant, some are annoying, but that's what life itself is like, so why not? Overall it's a great experience with lots of interesting stuff. In many ways unique too.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												L.A. Noire, why are you so entertaining and so disappointing at the same time?L.A. Noire is mostly the story of Cole Phelps, a former-marine-now-policeman working in the Angels' city. As such, he will have to work his way up the food chain, starting in patrol, soon to be promoted to trafic, homicide and what not.The game is a mix and match of several genres: it's a bit of a point n' click, but with third-person shooting and driving around, in a beautifully recreated L.A. Mostly, you'll be collecting clues on crime scenes, and interviewing suspects, while a partner lets you do all the work and comments on your action.Those parts are great. Thanks to some fancy facial-capture technology and the help of professional actors, the characters of L.A. Noire feel alive, and real. You can see their expression on their faces, notice when they tell the truth or when they lie (in which case you gotta shove a clue you collected into their face). Coles Phelps yells, gets mad, doubts... In a very convincing way. The cast includes many well-know series actors, from Madmen, Breaking Bad or Twin Peaks.What's more, the shooting parts (relatively frequent) aren't that bad, for an investigation game.But L.A. Noire's greatest success is its wonderful film noire atmosphere. Secret loves, murders, illegal gamblings, corrupted politicians and cops, jazz, femmes fatales... Everything is right here, in a post-WW2 US. A country that feels invincible, but whose confidence hides nasty stories.Great, heh?Yeah, except that L.A. Noire also disappoints. If you don't stick to the cases you're supposed to be solving, you quickly find out its greatest weakness: Los Angeles has no soul. The city is beautiful, mind you. But nothing happens. Car drives around, people walk. There are a few scripted events. But that's about it. You can't drive around and tail someone just because he looks weird. The game has to tell you to do it. You can't get into a restaurant a get yourself a coffee and read the news. You can't discuss with people. The city feels like a beautiful, but empty playground.If you're expecting a game that looks and plays like Gran Theft Auto, let's say you might be turned off by L.A. Noire. The game has little in common with Rockstar' behemoth. But if you like the film noire genre, and are willing to put up with sometimes clunky or repetitive gameplay, then you ought to try L.A. Noire. I personnally see the game as an interactive story (a bit like The Walking Dead), taking place in an open world where you can drive fancy old cars. Too bad the game could have been so much more.
