content:
Posted: April 12
												Before I start my review let me tell you the L.A. Noire is NOT the easiest game to get running smoothly. Here's what I did and it ran great on my modest Win 7 64 Bit machine. When the launch screen comes up go to Options and in the command line copy and paste "-npd -str -nonv" (without the quotes) into the box. Turn "Ambient Occlusion" off and "Threading" to Single. Hopefully that helps. Now. With that said, I found L.A. Noire to be a gift from Heaven. I'm a huge fan of Raymond Chandler and his stories of Private Detective Philip Marlowe swimming through the seedy side of early Los Angeles with every case. L.A. Noire has you patrolling those very streets and solving cases involving sex, drugs, murder and corruption. The major crimes found in L.A. Noire are based on real life crimes and the streets of Los Angeles circa the late 40s have been painstakingly recreated to colorful perfection. You're rewarded for oberservational skills both in clue hunting and during the interview and interrogation portions. There is tons to do whether you want to look for landmarks, well hidden bonus items or one of the 40 "street crime" mini-missions that you can elect to take between calls. I really liked the facial motion capture which gave each character more personality. The acting is superb and loaded with recognizable character actors like John Noble, Michael Wiles & Kurt Fuller. Gunplay and driving is as easy as what you'll find in a GTA game. Now is it perfect? No. The port is not very good. From what I understand it's a pain to run even on a beefy PC. The street crime mini missions are very short and there are times you'll be driving a while to get to them.  Overall, L.A. Noire gets a 9.5/10 from me. If you're looking for a lengthy, well told story with excellent voice acting and game play then hit "install".

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Wow. Okay, wait, let's get the bad out of the way first.1) It's optimized poorly. The game seemingly started fine, or perhaps I was too enamored with the city to notice, but DX9 or DX11, highest settings or lowest, nothing mattered. The camera would stutter, the engine would slow, and otherwise damage the otherwise breathtaking aesthetics of L.A. Noire.2) The driver and pedestrian A.I. is atrocious. For a game that forces you to spend the majority of your time driving, expect to laugh at the ridiculous decisions made by the NPCs in this game. Then, when chasing down suspects or trying to avoid... well, I won't spoil anything, but let's just say at certain points, you will yell at the television for these dummies to get out of the way.3) The action sequences aren't as interesting as the investigation ones. Basic action, such as the street crimes, or even a moderate shootout, aren't too bad but the above complaints tend to ruin any tension Team Bondi attempted to create.I think that's about it. So what did I like?1) The city. Sorry, Sleeping Dogs, you've been knocked off the top spot (previously owned by Saints Row 2) for best video game city. It's no wonder Team Bondi went bankrupt after this game. The amount of time and resources it must have taken to recreate Los Angeles is staggering.2) The characters. Thanks to stellar voice acting and the well-publicized facial animation engine, it's easy to forget you're playing a game and not watching a movie. Tip: Play L.A. Noire in black and white and the effect is even more staggering.3) The story. I'm a sucker for noir in general, and this is a pretty good tribute to the genre. That pretty much every single element is tied to the main story, no matter how minor it seems, is a nice touch.4) The investigation. Whether you're screaming at a widower -- er, I mean 'doubting' a widower -- or trying to figure out how a torn letter fits with the case, I enjoyed poking around the city's seedy underbelly and solving the (many!) mysteries.Note that I keep writing "the city" instead of "the game." Yes, it's that realistic.I loved L.A. Noire, and if you like mysteries and history at all, please don't hesitate picking up this game. Just be warned that even at 30 FPS, a computer that laughs at the recommended specs of the latest games will (probably) not run this smoothly. Fortunately, you'll probably be too engrossed to care. I know I was.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												So , I completed this game on 100% and I can finally write a review. What can this game offer?Well , in this game you are going to play as a detective Cole Phelps and watch not only how he is going up in his career but also how he is becoming a real hero.There are 5 desks to complete in this game : Patrol , Traffic , Homicide , Vice and Arson.Each of them contains ~5 cases (only Patrol has 4) and also 1 or 2 DLC cases.Both of default and DLC cases are very interesting. Each desk offers unique cases , for example in Traffic desk you will investigate crimes related with cars stealing and in Homicide you will investigate brutal murders.To feel like a real detective you'll need to collect evidence at crime scenes and also ask questions to suspects. You'll need to see if they are telling truth or lying and show one evidence to confirm that they are lying. Sometimes it's really hard to tell if person is lying and that's why there are "Intuition"in this game. You are getting "Intuition points" while you are leveling up and use these points to see what have other players chosen.This can help a lot.There are a lot of things to collect in this game from hidden badges to cars.To fully understand plot you can pick up newspapers which you can easily find during main story. There are also flashbacks in the end of some cases. These flashbacks help you to see the past of Cole Phelps.This game has huge open world(almost a half of GTA V(or even more)). To move around quickly you can ask your partner to drive the car to the selected location. This can save a lot of time.In conclusion , I can't understand why almost everyone is upset with ending of this game. I think that the ending that we have would be the best option to end the game.One disadvantage of this game is that it's locked on 30FPS.So , this game is great , shall i say. It has a great story and spectacular gameplay which will make you play this game even after you have beate it.Although , without DLC cases this game may seem to be short so if you can afford DLC bundle - buy it.I can proudly give this game 9.5/10 (because I had some problems with it and saw some bugs)

Posted: April 16, 2015
												If you're a fan of the 40ies era, crime scene investigations and narrative games then this is the perfect game for you!  BUY IT! Unfortunately the world in this game is limited to your detective duties and a few street crimes, as it would be suitable for a lot of open world playability, but it has even less sandboxing than Mafia II. So if you'd want an open sandbox world, you're out of luck and you'd be having more fun playing Mafia II with its DLC.However, all-in-all it's a great immersive game (awesome radio with real pieces of history!) that follows the career of Cole Phelps, an honest cop, freshly returned from WWII with the necessary traumas that he's trying to forget, while he's trying to solve murder cases. But there's more behind them than meets the eye....

												A flawed masterpiece. The major issue is you have to read facial cues from people- and while it's easy enough to tell when someone is being honest, for some reason lies are split up into "doubt" and "lie" - which is ridiculous, and you usually act more hostile when you "doubt" than when you're sure it's a "lie". As a result you get all those questions wrong, which forces you to re-do some cases. So you go online for the solutions, which really just ruins the game.The city is fantastic, the characters are well-written, and the missions a fantastic progression. I just couldn't get myself to finish. It stopped being fun. Just driving around was awesome though. So close to being amazing.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I've not got too far into this game just yet, but for someone who struggles with a short attention span and very rarely sticks to and finishes a game, this has already got me hooked! I love the fact that you have so much control over the game, and having to choose the correct answer (Truth, Doubt or Lie) from reading their body language and facial expressions is really interesting to me and can completely change the game play. content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Investigating thefts, robberies, disappearances and murders, all the while driving around in a huge city to get from site to site to gather clues and testimonies and, if you feel like it, respond to the occasional emergency dispatch calls (ranging from domestic disturbance to bank heist), that's what L.A. Noire is all about. Don't get fooled by the resemblance to GTA games. Yes there is a lot of driving around and some scenarios/street crimes involve shooting or fighting bad guys the same way but you'll spend more time confronting people with questioning than with your gun. Graphics are really nice and the animation...My jaw dropped the first time I saw a cutscene. The facial animation, especially, is so well done it makes you almost forget you're watching a game. This, combined with the top notch voice acting, brings the characters to life in a manner so believable you'll see actors, not computer generated dummies.  Music is also great and really suits the 40's era very well and helps to create the overall atmosphere. This one's worth buying. Still not sure? Wait until it's on sale then and get the complete edition with added scenarios.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
Product received for free
												This game gets a straight 10/10 for me, even though it took a lot of research and finally a patch to run it. There aren't many games in which you get to test your brains as well as as your hand-eye coordination in real world scenarios. Playing a detective could never be as much intriguing or fun as it was in L.A. Noire. The game mechanics are super cool, allowing the player to gauge the characters expressions and body language and based on that, assess whether they're lying, hiding something, or telling the truth. Although the game is fairly linear, it's very interesting to see how the decisions made affect each case. It would have been even more interesting if the entire story changed on the basis of those decisions, of course! Every gamer should definitely play this once.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												If you've played a game by Rockstar before, then you probably have a good idea of what to expect from L.A. Noire. It's a lot like GTA or Red Dead Redemption — third-person gunfights, car chases and hot pursuits on foot, well-developed characters, and a compelling storyline. It's a formula that may seem almost like a crutch with how often Rockstar employs it in their titles, but it's hard to complain when it's done well.If you're the type of person to play GTA for the plot, then L.A. Noire will keep your attention with relative ease. It does away with a lot of the nuisances that drag GTA down (there weren't even mobile phones for your cousin to call you on back in the 40's), but it also makes for — perhaps — a less substantial game, as there's not a whole lot to do besides follow the main storyline.You play as Cole Phelps, climbing the ranks of the L.A. Police Department, slowly uncovering a massive conspiracy that reaches all the way up to the highest officials in Los Angeles. By the end of the game, you'll have managed to collect evidence from nearly every other previous case, all pointing towards systematic corruption and foul-play.Knowing that he can bring the system crashing down is the ultimate goal that keeps Cole searching for the truth, but L.A. Noire manages to undo all player expectations with the game's finale. With an ending that nobody could possibly expect, L.A. Noire proves to be both the most shocking and most frustrating game I've played in a long time.As confused and angry as the ending will leave you feeling, I still recommend playing the game from beginning to almost-end and then maybe just making up the last mission in your head. L.A. Noire definitely wins the prize for having the biggest f•••-you ending that a game could possibly conceive, but it's still worth the time to try it out.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												L.A. Noire Review L.A. Noire is an intresting game, and very unlike other games and also like them all at the same time. You have your detective skills, questioning, unlike any other game, but you also have your car chases, shootouts, on foot chases, much like other games. One of the best things about L.A. Noire is that it skillfully uses these elements to create a consistent, cohesive, whole. L.A. Noire for me, helped me appreciate high production values used the right way. I believe the way L.A. Noire plays really makes it head and shoulder above many other games. L.A. Noire however doesn't come without faults. The procedural cases while engaging like, Law & Order, also get a little repetitive gameplay wise. After a couple of cases, you do the usual, find clues, investigate a place, interview witness' or suspects, and then chase the one your after. The case together though tell a great tale and it really is great especially if you are in to procedural dramas. The mo-cap system it uses is pretty darn amazing and the best I've seen yet. The performances really come through, although I would have loved for the directors, to come up with some more emotional cases or scenes, so we could really see how great this system is. About 20 or so hours in the game, you'll hit the Arson Desk, which provides some much needed reprieve from the usual procedings. I won't spoil it for you, but your entire time at the Arson Desk is unlike the other departments. At this point of the story L.A. Noire's plot really picks up and you start seeing the story threads all connect together, even threads that were started at the very beginning of the game. FOR: People who love noire, procedural dramas, and want to be a detective.NOT FOR: People who like fast paced gameplay, L.A. Noire has a slower pace than most games and it really starts to show about mid way. What probably doesn't help is the fact that it's about a 30 hour long game. While great for people who love this, it may not bode well for other with less patience. Nevertheless I suggest you buy the game, especially if it's on a Steam sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												After 40 hours of gameplay time I have to say LA Noire is one of the most ambitious, most interesting and most exciting games I have played in recent years. Attention to detail is top-notch as we have already gotten used to it when it comes to a Rockstar game. But here this is more commendable as this is now a "serious" game - you follow the story of detective Phelps, an LAPD cop, who rises from being a simple patrolman to working with the best and most influential cops in the force. You quickly realise that there are people harder to catch out there - you start with the small fish only to find clues as to how to grab the biggest sharks in town.Gameplay-wise LA Noire is a bit different from GTA IV. The missions - or as they're referred to, cases - usually start out with a crime scene investigation. You get in a car and drive to your destination where you need to look for clues. Clues are objects you can interact with - once you approach one you'll hear a chime; this is how the game tells you that you can now press a button to grab the object in your vicinity. The more clues you find the more are added to your notebook. There is usually a witness around you can interview. And this is the 2nd most important thing in gameplay: interviewing means that while you can pick your questions from a list provided you also need to "evaluate" the suspects' responses. You have 3 options: you either believe what they are saying, you can remain in doubt or you can shout at them calling them liars. Picking the correct answer will make it easier for you to find and apprehend the real suspect. Make no mistake: if you are wrong it does not mean game over but it will affect the scoring at the end of your case. You should also note two more things: firstly, you can have help in the form of intuition points. The more crimes you solve the more experience points you get. Once you level up you gain an intuition point. These can be used to remove one of the 3 possible answers thereby increasing your chances to 50%.  Secondly, once you accuse someone of lying you need to prove that. Phelps immediately turns the page in his notebook to the list of evidences. You need to pick the right evidence to succeed (that is, if you have found enough clues for that to appear in your list).Interestingly, some of these conversations can be the most exciting and rewarding parts of the game. Rockstar employed a special motion capture technique which makes all faces and expressions as realistic as possible. In fact, you can see the faces of real life actors and actresses - those of you watching a lot of TV series will easily be able to recognise some of these. This also means that voice acting is provided by the same people and it is of equally high quality. Suspects not telling the truth usually look away, move their mouths, grimace, scratch their head, loose their tie, etc. The mechanics for the action scenes are similar to that of GTA IV. You have the same cover system, you can brawl occasionally and you have car chases where your partner does the shooting. You just need to make sure you are as close to the suspect's vehicle as possible so that your detective partner can shoot the tires. Sometimes, your job is to apprehend a suspect in a non-lethal way - if not by brawling then by running after and tackling him. These scenes can get very repetitive which I did not mind in particular - except some of them felt a little too scripted: I thought I could get a guy if I was quick only to realise he was meant to be stopped by an accident. Another minor annoyance is the interview part: sometimes you are convinced the suspect is lying. You know you do not have any evidence so you pick the option "Doubt" but it turns out the guy was right so he was probably making a grimace due to being confused. As the game has an auto-save function you can easily quit and reload to try again but after a while this can be annoying. It just feels that Rockstar had a certain idea in mind for these choices and if you are lucky you can get the answer right.But what is there beside the cases you work on? Does LA Noire offer you the option of free roaming? I am happy to say it does: dispatch informs you of ongoing crimes and you can leave your current case to pursue these. Also, there are TONS of items to look for: badges, famous landmarks, film reels and 95 (!) vehicles to get into. Once you get into a car it is "unlocked". Under "Extras" in the main menu you'll find a showroom to have a look at an already unlocked vehicle. Many look pretty similar but they can be different models - sometimes it feels a bit ridiculous to get in and out of every vehicle you find in a parking lot but there's no other way for you to find all of them. I have to admit I could only collect 90% of them.As for the cases: you have everything you need. Narcotics, arsons, thefts, grand theft auto, cases with corrupt cops, serials killer, etc. The places you visit are varied and look realistic. Accompanying music and sound effects also represent an excellent quality.LA Noire has 21 cases. It feels as if you were watching a season of your favourite crime series. 21 episodes of it. And when it is over you are happy but at the same time you are eager to see what's coming in the next season. I wish LA Noire had one more season.

												L.A. Noire is not just a detective game, it's truly so much more in my opinion. This game is based around the late fourties when LA is at its Golden Age of the movie industry and the evy of the world. Your protaginist, Cole Phelps, is a WWII veteran now serving for the LAPD. Every case is based mainly how much of the clues you've found during the case, as well the damage of you've caused to the city, but mainly the interrogation questions you had to ask and confirming their 3 types. If you like these type of games, I highly recommend L.A. Noire to you.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												One of the best games I've played so far. Very original and fun, with some challenge to it. To start off, the graphics are dated, but not bad at all. The motion scanner they used on the characters really bring them to life and play a big role in interrogations.You play as a detective in the 1940's, and as such you examine crime scenes, find clues, and interogate suspects. It's all original and very interesting to do. Interrogation can oftentimes be tough, so I recommend taking your time finding all possible clues and examining the expressions of suspects very carefully. Trying to prove that a person is lying is particurlarly tricky, but very satisfying. The game has chase scenes, both on foot and in cars. There are gun fights, which are fun but not particularly noteworthy. The city of LA is open-world, and you can find hidden cars and do some sightseeing. It must be said, however, that the game is very mature, and you will often find brutal killings, blood, and naked victims. There are a lot of mature topics as well as some disturbing things, so I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone under 16. Overall, the game is very fun and definitely worth your time and money.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2012
												This is a dark and controversial detective story taking place in L.A. of 1947. Everyone's a sinner in this game. It's very good at visually, musically and sometimes psychologically resembling the real Los Angeles of that time. The city consists of a couple of connected districts, from Hollywood to the central one. That is enough to make the game world huge. There are 95 types of cars from the most famous manufacturers, like Ford, GMC, Buick and Chevrolet. As for the gameplay, it feels like Mafia II combined with a groundbreaking police detective simulator inspired by well known crimes, such as The Black Dahlia murder. Among the innovations are the amazing facial animations never seen in videogames before. Unlike Mafia II, the game is mainly focused on looking for evidence, interviewing and interrogating people rather than gunfights. At the same time, nobody stops you from entering the Free Roam mode just to drive the cars, look around and prevent street crimes filled with action.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												For a game of this type it was relatively short.  But it didn't feel short, it felt like it dragged on and on for some reason. Can't say it was really boring, but it was repetative.  Why they couldn't have mixed the cases up a little more instead of doing the same same 5 or 6 murder investigations in a row.  Did a good job capturing the Time and Location it's set in.  Good Soundtrack. Likable characters, both good and bad for the most part.  Even the secondary characters you interview were good. Open world, but instead of playing like an open world it cut to a new "level" for each investigation. Entire game would have been better if the protagonist had either been a Private Eye, or if the game had fewer gun fights and car chases and more actual puzzles and investigations.  Interviews are sometimes unneccisarily difficult. Story jumps around alot.  Dramatic scenes that made no sense because there was no set up.  A single scene or few lines of dialog giving better context to the next part of the story arc would have made alot of the game more enjoyable.  in 30 hours of gameplay you wont necessarily remember someones signifigance  from a random unconnected scene from 25 hours ago.  Ending was garbage.  Overall like 6.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												I wish i could unlock the 30 fps lock and have a better saving system...Otherwise LA Noire targets niche-players. If you'd rather play a slow paced game that requires (a bit) brains and concentration instead of running with a gun and shooting everything that crosses your path, then you may enjoy LAN . Otherwise, well the game's very slow, and quite clumsy at that.One of the main selling point was the "incredible facial features"... well, i won't lie it's sometimes pretty bad, most of the time okeyish, seldomly accurate. Thus sometimes leading you to failing questionning a suspect because you misinterpreted something that obviously means he is stressed (eyes going all around, mouth grinning) but actually doesnt :^)While at it, i really enjoyed the gameplay phases on the crime scenes. Searching for evidences, trying to find connections during the multiple elements you've found, all that is really well done.The story's interesting, not great, but interesting and not too predictable. It's a bit disjointed though.The background musics are perfectly on point and the voice acting, both in french and english, is great. These are some of the game main strengths.Now one of the most important part to my mind, the graphics: in 2017, it looks bad. The 30 fps lock and low resolution textures are really awful (i looked for a solution but couldnt find one, it's certainly on me tho, there must be some program that allows you to play at 60 fps). That's a shame to  be honest, since the atmosphere is so well rendered. It really feels like beeing in an good ol' 60's city. Kinda like Mafia 2, which actually looked better.The atmosphere is pin-point what you could expect from a game taking place in the 50-60's.In the end, if you really dont mind the 30 fps lock, if you dont mind a few frustrations "God how the hell is that guy not lying with a face like that?", if you enjoy slow paced games then it's made for you.Otherwise, well i still think it's a nice experience to live. I've not finished it yet but will in a close future.I dont recommend it if you cant suffer playing at 30 fps. It really is a downside, and Rockstar's well known for their poor pc port anyway...

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												Some FACTS about LA Noire:- The game is 4 years old and the facial animations are STILL un-freaking-believable.- The music is phenomenal.  How many video games have a jazz soundtrack?- You can play the game in "black and white" (and it looks gorgeous this way).- The writing is better neo-noire than most films have ever managed.- The city of 1947 LA was directly modeled from aerial photographs.- THE CARS OMG THE CARS!!!!!- When you interview people, their facial movements reveal if they're lying.- This is based on real science, so playing this game will improve your lie detector skills irl.LA Noire is a masterpiece.  It isn't as wildly popular as it deserves to be because it focuses more on style and detail than on NONSTOPACTIONPEWPEWPEW.  But if you're all grown up, wearing your big girl panties, this game will impress the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												Despite the age of the game, the graphics are very well done. The facials (insert joke here) are movie like thanks to some special technology they implemented in this game. Being a ROCKSTAR game, many people purchased it thinking it would be a shortened GTA-like game. This is not what it is, although it does feel like it at times.Despite being classified as open world, there was a linear feel to the game. I truly don't understand the obsession many gamers have with "open world" (perhaps instead of a story, they want an escape from their miserable exsistences), but this linear story suited me just fine.  The game was more like a visual novel or interactive movie, which i enjoyed, but was also the #1 complaint many had about this game during discussions with friends. They craved more action. They wanted a GTA like experience.I found the game relaxing, THEN INTENSE, then slow, and i can see how many with attention deficit disorder (if you grew up in the 90's) or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (the new excuse for the kids today) can't muster enough attention to read more than 148 characters at a time.The guides available thru steam are well written, fully detailed, and make difficult parts smoother when you had enough of scratching your head. They would let you get some drawn out achievements with ease provided you invest the time and attention span. Right now it's 70% off ($5.09 CND), and for that price it's a steal of a deal. Over all, i'd give this game a 8/10 and at its currently price, I'd stamp it with BigRig's cheap♥♥♥♥♥game buyer Stamp.

												A WW2 game that doesn't involve WW2, you play the role of Cole Phelps. A cop who, by sheer luck, stumbles upon a gruesome murder, the first two of which have racism as the motive. Eventually becoming a detective, it becomes increasingly clear that the system is completely corrupt and it's up to your scientologist friend and fake german wife to save the world from psychology while you sort vice squad cases off on the side with a shotgun and cigar. Every cop you encounter is intentionally incompitent, and you eventually get to shoot them all when your space marine firebat friend takes to the caves to fight Charlie. Origami plays a major role in the game, making it the only game to involve folding paper into little swans important.Because it's California, drugs,♥♥♥♥♥♥on the railroad and arson by proxy cases usually lead to pedophillia and rifle stockpiles.Overall, a solid and unforgettable game, mostly because the villian doesn't do anything evil and never kills anyone.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												7/10The game is an adventure game with Rockstar trappings.You investigate crimes, follow leads, question witnesses, interrogate suspects, and occasionally subdue criminals with force.  The game has a wondeful ambiance, a great score, and very strong characters.Why not a better score than 7/10?  Three things cost it those three points for me:1) The "GTA"-like elements feel out of place/unnecessary.  The game is 80% criminal investigation, 20% action (car-chases/shoot-outs/fist-fights).  The action bits feel "tacked-on" and are not fleshed out very well in comparison to the rest of the game.  Driving between locations feels largely pointless with very little to do between points-of-interest.2) The interrogation/questioning aspect can come off as a little strange at times. You might know that a suspect is lying, but it isn't always clear if you've got the correct piece of evidence to directly accuse them of lying. When you make a bad choice, you look like an idiot, but it doesn't change the outcome of the case for the most part. The story moves forward even if you bungle all the questioning/interrogating/evidence gathering parts.3) The ending sucks. It's abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends. It feels like they ran out of time. I know that's my opinion, but I'm sure many other people feel the same.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												My 48 hours of play time was all on Windows 7 from earlier this year. I have since built myself a new computer with Windows 8.1 x64 and, as many reviews here state, the game doesn't launch. I tried running it in Windows 7 compatiblity mode - nothing. From the looks of it this problem has been around for years now and still no formal fix. That's pretty disgusting. This is such a great classic game. I feel terrible for people who never got a chance to play it and now never will if they're on a "newer" operating system. If you're on Windows 7 or earlier, I highly recommend the game. If you're in the majority of Windows users who have moved on to Windows 8/8.1 or Windows 10, don't bother. Rockstar has this same problem with GTA IV and they do nothing about it. Blows my mind. Don't they want people to continue buying their games even years later? Clearly it's too much trouble for a billion dollar company to support newer operating systems for older games. Good one you f*ck faces.Update: There is a patch that was installed where the game finally opens without crashing but, guess what, the performance is so bad it's truly unplayable unless you enjoy 12fps. I've tried every fix possible from the "-npd" command line, running it in DirectX9, choosing single thread, changing the resolution in game, creating a custom resolution, etc The menu seems to be capped at 24fps and in game it hovers around 28fps about twenty percent of the time - eighty percent of the time it's fluctuating between 12 - 25fps. I'm so sick of it. The best I can do is get the menu to go back to it's default 30fps cap but, once I'm in game, ithe performance is the same 18fps average. So unfair. Steam needs to put a disclaimer on the store page of this game that cleary states - If you have Windows 8/8.1 there are common issues still unresolved and to buy at your own risk.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												There is some really solid foundation here with the setting, stories, a city that actually feels alive and fleshed out.  Unfortunately it's plagued with sound issues, UI issues, mechanic issues, control issues, and gameplay issues that all add up to a really frustrating game that just feels like a letdown.  I was too irritated with all the problems and faults along the way to feel satisfied at the end of any given case.  Important text during important dialogue so you only get half of what you need is just poor design.  But the number one irritation is driving.  Driving across the whole blasted city over and over again with poor control of the car and a city full of fools that can't drive and a lack of streetlights in half the intersections.  And the driving has NO impact on the game other than there can be some flavor audio while you're struggling across town and you get fined for the inevitable damage to the car.  If you can actually get past all these issue and annoyances, then yes, it's an inovative game that differs from anything else I've ever seen.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												... This game REPEATEDLY forces you to jump to illogical conclusions. As much as I want to like this game, FORCING the player to make poor judgement calls takes away from the experience. This flaw was a constant reminder that I was trapped within the rules of the game. As ambitious as it tried to be, LA Noire can't deliver on it's promises of "true detective work". Maybe if they spent as much time and money on gameplay as they did on facial animation (which, I admit, is pretty epic...), I could understand the hype.

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												So I'm kind of missing a middle option in terms of ratings here.While it's not a espacially good game. It isn't a bad game either.In terms of technical aspects. The graphics are nothing mind blowing by any stretch of the imagination, but they aren't bad either. There's a strict 30fps lock going on, which I couldn't find a quick fix to by googling (such as changing a line in some config file) So I just decided to suck it up and enjoy the "console experience".The gameplay:The investigating comes down to looking long enough for "clues" and interrogating people afterwards and deciding wether they area) lying (and you have proof in form of one of the clues you previously collected)b) lying (and you don't have proof, but are in fact just suspecting they are lying) - this option is confusingly labeled "doubt"c) telling the truthThe rest of the gameplay comes down to some shooter-segments, some car chases. Neither of which are particualarly good.The Main positive about the game in my opinion is the Story, which I actually found pretty interesting. However the actual plot only develops very slowly during the beginning and middle of the playtime. The story gets more interesting towards the end when the plot thickens.Another Selling Point is the setting of post WW2 America in the late 40s, which isn't beeing explored in very many games. So If you think this sounds like a interesting setting just because it isn't such common theme in video games, then this might be something for you.So overall I said I don't recommend this game because there is no middle option, cause that is what this game has written all over it in my opinion. And I reserve the "I recommend this game" option for games that I think are actually worth recommending, such as the Witcher 3, Tomb Raider(The Reboot), or Bioshock Infinite,...This doesn't mean I think LA:Noire is bad, it's just not as good as those games which I just mentioned in my opinion.And it honestly feels kind of like a♥♥♥♥♥♥move to click the thumb down-button, because I know that people that don't read the review will just think I thought it was a bad game, when really I don't.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												A truly unique game, executed well. Instead of playing as a dangerous criminal, you play as the good guy who is trying to solve crimes.This game takes place in 1940s LA. Rockstar managed to recreate the world well and it provides a unique atmosphere to the game. There's not going to be too many instances where you go around killing people with your gun, because this is supposed to be an investigation game, rather than a open world city sandbox game. The plot can be unpredictable, and keeps the player interested to continue the game. Graphics are quite nice, and the DLCs are also worth trying.However, the PC version is by flawed, too. The game seems to be poorly optimized for PC, as it has a 30fps lock and many people have a hard time running this game.Get it, if you can find a way around the 30fps lock and can fix the game with some mods.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Flawed gem that never really got the success it needed (and maybe even deserved).The gameplay itself swings between overly simplistic (finding clues) to somewhat obtuse and illogical (the way the interrogations are handled sounds great on paper, but simply don't hold together very well), and the driving and combat is perfunctory and servicable. Where the game really shines though is in the setting and story. You can really feel the love and attention that has gone into getting the feel of the time period right, and the details that really tie the story together.Is it cliche and perhaps a little predictable at times? Of course. But it's a love letter to a genre we don't see much of these days. It will make you want to dust of your LA Confidential DVD, and wear a sharp suit.

Very rarely you can fail a investigation, when suspect interrogations fail, your superior scolds you and suddenly you repeat the dialog sequence all over again.I had extremely high expectations for this game, it didn't deliver completely, but it is an immersive game nonetheless.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is a good game which will be overlooked as forgettable by once mountain-dew-addled-teens who are now adults as choose your own adventure GTA. This game has more in common with world exploration games and the old arcade classic Dragonslair than it ever did with the zany violent world of Grand Theft Auto. The developers have presented an entire world full of beautiful set pieces, interesting and engaging characters and violence that is presented as a story device rather than reward for getting through the narrative elements. Sure, the game plays pretty much the same on replay but with hundreds of variations depending on who you kill, where you go first and what questions you ask. The game has been cheap often for a long time now and if you haven't had the pleasure of digging into a game that will make you feel something different, you should get this.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												L.A. Noire does what Americans do best: to complain about themselves.L.A. Noire features the city of Los Angeles as a prototype for the present cities: a city made for cars, not for people. The city of "opportunities" (opportunists), the film industry and corrupt politicians. All of this amid the flowering of psychiatry, drug trafficking, property speculation and the American dream.The protagonist is a decorated war hero who now works as a police officer. During the game, the protagonist is promoted to detective. Along the game you investigate several cases, and uncover a true conspiracy. The noir atmosphere is always present. The soundtrack and the voice-acting is very good.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												For all it's flaws, I loved L.A. Noire.The port, first off, is woeful. After you've contended with Rockstar Social Club updating and generally being a nuisance, the fight is getting the game looking pretty while keeping the framerate consistent. I played the whole thing through at the locked-in 30fps, and had a fine time.For it's time, this is a beautiful, innovative game. The facial models make characters readable and relatable, and the generally minimalist nature of the game - few HUD features popping in or out, heavy reliance on sound rather than visual signposting - allows the game to unfold like a dense TV series rather than a videogame. The atmosphere is exceptional, and period music and vehicles only add to that.The story is good, although it wanes towards the end. The same goes for the gameplay - it is fun, unique, and rewarding, but also blows its wad off the bat: by the endgame, you're doing the same things you were at the very start.Even still, a fantastic single-player experience.

content:

Review of L.A Noire - Complete EditionPositive:+Great storyline, easy to follow and understand!+Graphics aren't too bad for game released 2011+Several missions, even more with the ''DLC''+The DLC whitch gives you several new outfits and unlocks many cases for you to solve out, is practically free for you because the main game costs witouth sales 29,99€ meanwhile the DLC whitch includes original game, is 29,99€ = Profit for you!+Achievements, and several puzzles for you to solve if you want to take break of the main-story+Huge map of Los Angeles, dating back to the mid and late 40's, they did well with getting the atmosphere there!Negative:-Team Bondi does not accurenly show any kinda of interest to this game, there have not been a single update to this game after I bought it, whitch was in Summer Sale 2014, a fairly long time ago!-Yes there is many cars, but I'd like if you could ride the trams and busses in the game too tho' this is not a big deal at all-The worst thing with this game is it's support for PC version is just... Bad, this was made for the consoler first, and then the team got lazy on importing it to PC version so they just took the exact copy of the X360 and PS3 versions and put it in the PC version = 30FPS lock, and it looks f*cking bad! It can be removed with a program but that does not completely fix it, instead makes it worse in some cases i.ex when driving a vehicle, the physics becomes very bad and you can not steer the vehicle almost at all, but I recommend you to turn it off while driving and just trying to survive that 30FPS maddnes, it's just a game afterall I guess...Altho' some of it's negative feedback I gave this game, I can easilly give this game a 8.5/10 rating!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												L.A. Noire is an engrossing tale derived the famous City of Angels that has you playing the role of an L.A.P.D. detective.  It features a vast open-world environment set in 1947 just after the Second World War. The characters, level of detail and the mature setting draws you into the era and presents the player with a unique blend of third-person action and point-and-click adventure. You will be thrown into car chases, foot pursuits, shootouts, interviews and setup to investigate crime scenes where you must establish motive and means. L.A.  Noire is simply a must for gamers!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
COMPLETED 100%Game has a great flair of originality in it with gameplay elements you don't see in any other game out there. The open world is rendered beautifully in 1940s L.A. with incredibly detailed landmarks and plenty of interiors you can just walk straight into and explore even with no incentive given to do so.  What it does good though, it fails a largely in repetitiveness and a rather disconnected story that mostly just consists of a bunch of cases that always ends up with you arresting the culprit, guilty or not, it doesnt even matter. The same game elements like investigations and interrogations that looked interesting at first eventually starts getting stale and might become quite a chore to do, with so little in the way of variation.Trying to ace interviews and interrogation scenes are not the least easy and sometimes the correct answers (Lie, Doubt, Truth) doesn't make sense. I started this game mostly looking forward to a good detective noir story but what turned out instead is quite a disappointment. The central plot only gets underway in the final desk of the game making everything you did before nothing more than random crime cases. Story overall is nothing impressive and even seemed quite rushed. Mediocre at best.Look past the flaws however, and the game still holds up with brilliant dialogue and voice acting and exceling in innovation in its own rights.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Wow, what a game... first, let me say that I've always been interested in WWII and the post-war world in the United States.  This game combines all my interests into one package.  It is fascinating to just drive around and look at things (clothes, cars, shops, etc...) and see how they were in 1947.  The gameplay is also well done too, you basically wander around in L.A. and try to solve crimes by looking for clues and talking to people.  The lip-synching is fantastic, L.A. Noire could almost pass for an animated movie.  When questioning witnesses, you have to really look at their faces to see if they are lying or telling partial truths, it takes some practice but you'll get good at it with just a little time.  Think of this game as a time machine back to the late 1940's, it lets you experience the time period in a way that you could never do by just reading books or watching movies.  I was a little worried about the performance issues I'd read about but the game runs absolutely fine on my old dual core PC (with a few small additions in the launch options).  I highly recommend this game to anyone who is on the fence about it... get it now and start playing, you won't regret it.

												Great story about post-WW2 Los Angeles, I love the setting. It is very interesting to play as a detective, looking for clues and reading people's facial expressions. Also, driving is boring too, even though there's an open world, it just feels empty, and most of the time you will probably want to skip it.All in all, L.A. Noire is a very good game, definitely worth trying, especially if you like detective genre games.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												A great game with a pleasant atmospheric experience based in 1940s Los Angeles as Detective Cole Phelps. The graphcs are good in terms of setting a balance of immersion by creating a very realistic vibe. The street crime cases add a bit of flavor to the overall gameplay to a game that may seem too linear to some by providing a bit of uncertainty for when the next case will come. The main cases are very interesting and carry a lot of suspense and intrigue. The downside of many of these cases is that they may become too easy for some and may not prove to be a good challenge. However, it is important to note that only the chase scenes can be a bit too easy, but actually finding the clues and persons of interests in the right order can prove to be a challenge. The controls are the typical WASD and a realistic point and shoot dynamic without any visible crosshairs. Overall, I found it a very pleasing game to play and there is a certain uniqueness that creates an enticing desire to continue to the next case.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I'm currently in the middle of the game, as a homicide detective. As I don't want to provide spoilers, I'll try to be brief. At first I thought that the crime or chapters of the homicide cases were poorly written because although some of the clues pointed out to the "person of interest" being the criminal, even though not everything fit into place. After playing through the chapters a few more times, I thought maybe it was just the developer's way of portraying the LAPD in the 1940's and their focus on convicting a suspect instead of actually finding out who did it and delivering justice; justice however is relative to the person dishing it out and the person receiving it. It could also be that all the cases lead up to a true mastermind framing everybody else, so that is something to look forward to. Overall, the gameplay is pretty enjoyable in the sense that it is quite similar to GTA. So if you're a GTA or mystery fan, and you are also interested in playing the role of the cop instead of the role of a robber, I would highly recommend this.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												L.A. Noire does what Americans do best: to complain about themselves.L.A. Noire features the city of Los Angeles as a prototype for the present cities: a city made for cars, not for people. The city of "opportunities" (opportunists), the film industry and corrupt politicians. All of this amid the flowering of psychiatry, drug trafficking, property speculation and the American dream.The protagonist is a decorated war hero who now works as a police officer. During the game, the protagonist is promoted to detective. Along the game you investigate several cases, and uncover a true conspiracy. The noir atmosphere is always present. The soundtrack and the voice-acting is very good.

												Well, I`d like to compare it with older or old games where you need solve crimes. First, here you are in 3rd person, map is open to you, go where you want - that is a big plus for me. Hell this game has amount of actors like and average movie :) Many cars. Well, not that many, as actors, but many. Duplicates seen, but mostly in parking lots. No big deal. And story. Story is great. Sound is great. Driving/ steering with keyboard, I think a bit too sensitive, but you can adapt after some time. Hm, what else... Annoying dispatcher voice... looks there is only one dispatcher in whole LA (sometimes other voice is heard, but too briefly) I haven`t played newest Sherlock Holmes game, so can`t compare with it and at this moment I can tell it is the best crime solving game I have ever played.

												All in all a very atmospheric game, which allows one to submerge himself into post-war LA.Minuses are: - very weak in certain plot areas, which leave one wandering about the imbecility of the police portrayed, as well as the impossible prowess of the culprit in planting evidence at just the right moment (Homicide squad cases);- there is no way to disarm an armed opponent, even if you shoot his weapon hand (which is perfectly possible due to the good aiming system), you can only shoot to kill. not a very police-like attitude.- most cases follow a similar structure, which is theoretically hidden by their actual storyline, but can still feel like repeating routine procedures. Could count as a bonus on portraying police-work correctly though.Despite this, in my opinion, a very worthwhile game, solid 8/10 from me.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Story - I should start off this review by saying I am totally biased in favor of this game and it is my favorite game in my library at the time of writing.  I love the setting of the 1940's and especially the noir and detective aspects.  This game is the closest you will get to playing L.A. Confidential: The Video Game.  I found the story and even the individual cases to be very engrossing and they feel like actual crimes that could have been committed.  I love a video game with a great story above all else and this one totally delivers on that.  All of the characters feel very real and have more depth than in other Rockstar games.  Cole Phelps, the protagonist, at first seems like a squeaky clean detective, but as the story goes on, that changes and you become very engrossed in him as a character.  When you add a deep and perplexing murder myster to that, I was hooked.  There are even real historical characters (gangsters like Bugsy Siegel) in the game and scientology makes an appearance (in an interesting way) too.Gameplay - You assume the role of Detective Cole Phelps and investigate crimes, interrogate suspects, tail suspects, and sometimes get in shoot outs and fist fights.  I really like the way L.A. Noire handles investigations.  You have to find clues at the crime scenes by picking up and examining objects.  When you find suspects, you can interview them and respond in three ways (truth, doubt, or lying) depending on what they say.  This is probably the most challenging part of the game because unless you're very good, it can be hard to know whether to doubt or call the suspect a liar.  You can and will arrest the wrong person if you get too many questions wrong or don't find all the evidence.  Fortunately, there are plenty of guides out there to help you if you are worried about getting it wrong.  In total, the game has somewhere between 20-30 cases and it took me around 30 hours to get through them all.  I never got tired of playing L.A. Noire and would have played many more cases if I could.A lot of the other game play is really similar to Grand Theft Auto.  Driving is arcadey in a good way and shooting is cover based and pretty fun too.  While you spend more time investigating in missions than doing shooting and car chases, the game also offers street crimes which are often foot or car chases with a shoot out or a fist fight thrown in.  These aren't necessary to beat the game but they are fun and were a nice addition.  Presentation (Graphics and Sound) - The graphics in L.A. Noire are both dated and incredibly impressive at the same time.  I'm pretty sure this game uses a version of the Grand Theft Auto 4 engine and while the graphics are solid, they do look like a PS3 game and if you have a good gaming pc, you can certainly find games that look better.  What makes this game great though is the acting and animation of the characters.  L.A. Noire uses a newer animation system that captured the way the voice actors looked and acted when delivering the lines.  This makes it possible to see when someone is lying and it also makes the characters look really distinct and believable.  I hope we'll see more games use this technology in the future.  In addition, the makers of this game put an incredible amount of detail into replicating the Los Angeles of the 1940's.  The city looks and feels real.  There is so much detail and nothing feels recycled when you drive around. The sound is excellent from the voice acting to the authentic music on your car radio when you drive around.  I love the theme song for this game and think it sets the mood for the game better than almost any other I've seen.  Overall - As I said at the beginning, I truly love this game.  From the story to the realism to the satisfying game play, I think L.A. Noire has it all.  If you don't care about these things, especially a great story then it is very possible you will like this game a lot less than I do or lose interest in it before beating it.  I've certainly heard people say that they felt this way and I think this is just one of those games that some people will really love and others will just find to be pretty good.  However, if my review sounds appealing to you, this game is one of Rockstar's best and that is really saying something.As far as achievements go, this game is very easy to get a high percentage on by playing through the game once and trying to grab achievements as you go.  You will want to find a good guide for getting five stars on every case and for making sure to use all the weapons in the game or you will have to repeat parts of the game.  The one that kept me from trying to get them all is an achievement that makes you drive every car in the game.  There isn't an easy to find all of these cars and you almost need some luck to get them all.  That one is a bit of a bummer but I would still say that compared to other games, L.A. Noire has more reasonable achievements, especially if you can live with getting 90% or so of them.9.5 (out of 10)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Top Tip: to fast travel to any location select it on your map and then hold e until your character gets into a car and then it fades to black.  This is very important as LA Noire is approx 8 square miles and it does take some time to drive from one side to the other.  The game is fun, but it has a few issues.  As a console port the game is fixed at 30fps.  This is due in part to the special technology used to graphically capture actors’ face expressions.  The biggest problem that I have with the system is it sometimes sticks me at 25 FPS despite having a GTX 980 and plenty of headroom.  Overall, the graphics look pretty good and are satisfactory as long as it keeps running at 30fps. The gameplay is good too.  The cars drive well; the gunplay is fun, I wish there was more of it.  The detective questioning can be aggravating.  If you challenge a witness’ statement as a lie you must present some evidence to prove it, sometimes there are multiple pieces of evidence that indicate they are lying but choosing the wrong one results in a failed question. When interrogating two suspects you may be forced to charge someone who you don’t think is guilty just because you failed one interrogation.  The last issue is that if you suspect someone of being the criminal you cannot actually go after them unless it is scripted in the story.  I have mixed feelings about the plot, they make Phelps do some very uncharacteristic things to progress the story and bring everything together.  However, the scams that the local government and business owners put together is interesting and clever.  Overall, I am not much of a fan of detective stories, shows, etc; but this game is fun and if they come out with a second one I will pick it up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Spent 45 hours playing this and in the end, can't really recommend it. I think the concept is pretty cool and I really wanted to like it, but it has several major flaws:1) Boring - this game is just boring. It's like a very long movie in slow motion. You can't fast forward the cut scenes so everything is very slow paced. The game does not evolve from the first mission, you don't get more skills so it is all the same over and over. Talk to some people, chase down a suspect (which you are scripted to never catch), shoot some bad dudes, repeat.2) Bad conversation system - in conversations you can choose Truth/Doubt/Lie, the problem is that it is a crap shoot which one to pick. You are supposed to hear the voice and look at the animated face to determine if they are lying. That is all fine, but even if they are lying, you need to choose between Doubt/Lie, and if they are telling the truth it is still Doubt/Truth, it's whatever random choice the programmers decided is the correct answer. To elaborate, someone can be telling the truth, but if you don't think they are telling enough of a truth (not enough details) you are supposed to pick Doubt. That leads to save scumming/using a walkthrough since the system is so ridiculous. 3) Laughable story - most of the non-DLC missions are connected by a main story. It is too bad you can see the big story from a mile away. Even worse is that even though you can tell what is going on, you repeatedly arrest innocent people because you have to. In about half of the cases - I repeat, in HALF OF THE CASES - you have no option to actually arrest the true criminal. Best case is that you choose between two innocent people. You are hailed as the best detective in the LAPD - yeah ok.It isn't all bad, the game is beautiful and the voice acting is great. Issue is that the key systems don't work and the game is boring. If they had ditched the main story, actually let you catch true criminals and made it into a 10  hour game, then maybe it would have been better. One of the very few times where less would have been better.4/10

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												By the time I am writing this review, I have not yet finished the game, but I am 10 hours in and would like to share my opinion and impressions, which hopefully will help you to decide whether you should get this game. First of all, I'll start with the positive things: - The vibe and atmosphere/Setting: They did an AWESOME job at setting up the right setting and getting into the spirit of LA in 1947, at least IMO. I do like this period a lot, and the look of the game (if you like, you can play this in b/w as well), the music/radio broadcasts (unfortunately, no way to switch radio stations manually, apparently. No custom music either, but then again, listening to modern music in the car would kinda ruin the immersion), the cars, fashion, lingo etc... just GREAT. Also, since this is based on old thrillers and stories by guys like Raymond Chandler, they went for that vibe, and did it VERY well... this does feel a lot like a that noire crime fiction Chandler was famous for. - The general idea is very cool and, IMO, refreshing - interrogating people and, based on the clues you found and their facial expressions (done with actors and motion capture) figuring out whether they're lying or not... great job there! The IGN review says that sometimes, it is too easy to tell when someone is telling a lie or getting nervous - but doesn't that add even more realism? After all, not everyone is a good liar irl!- The gameplay. The cars DO feel a bit... odd, chases can get a tiny bit frustrating, the shooting mechanics are far from perfect, but between examining crime scenes, searching for clues, interrogating witnesses and suspects, using your notebook to find clues, car chases, shootouts and some interludes to deepen the story, there is some variety.- The characters. I really like the main protagonist, and some of his fellow policemen. Sure, there is quite a bit of clichè to be found here, but that again fits well, as this is a tribute to the noire-genre, which never was deep literature anyway. Now for the less than positive or even negative parts:- On rails. To a certain degree, the game takes away your freedom. An example: In one case, I apparently missed a clue at one of the places I visited. I was doing interrogations at the police station, and was not able to go back to those places and pick up the thing I missed, which would have made solving the case easier and unlocked some additional questions/accusations. - Evidence. Basically, if you think a person is not telling the truth, you wanna choose "doubt". If you pick "lie", you have to prove the person is a liar with a piece of evidence/clue from your notebook. And sometimes that doesn't work right. Not a bug, it's the writing. The abbreviated details of the clue or piece of evidence might make you think that it is clear evidence the guy is a liar, but when you choose it, the game says it's wrong or not enough. - Some frame rate issues. This game is by no means recent. I don't have a killer gaming pc (i7, 16 gigs of ram, Nvidia GTX 960 with 4 GB of ram), but I would think that it should be able to run this game well... and still, there are frame rate issues, the game sometimes slows down. Odd, when games like Unity, Mad Max, GTA V, Witcher III or even Arkham Knight perform much better on my system. YMMV. - Repetition. Sometimes, the cases are TOO alike, or at least the procedure you do is. There is a bigger storyline with a certain series of murders, and at one point, it was like "OK, another murder like those other ones. Check for clues. Interrogate. Visit a bar. Visit another place. Interrogate. Done". Of course, those steps should be part of it in a crime/police-game, but I think there should have been more variety in the cases or the activities that are involved in them. I did enjoy the homicide cases (after the first or second promotion), but didn't enjoy the drug-related cases I was given after my next promotion- Mechanics. As I said, driving feels...wonky. Mind you, you are not driving a very recent sports car or something like that, but the controls feel a bit clunky sometimes, and so do the physics. I did play the game with an Xbox controller. Verdict: The idea was refreshing, and they really nailed it with the setting and vibe. Unfortunately, there are flaws to the whole Lie/truth/doubt/clues/notebook-system. Sometimes it's misleading, not elaborate enough, and sometimes it's too much "on rails". However, the story, vibe and the idea itself are great, and even though it's not perfect, I'd give this a 7.5/10. I got this while it was on sale and do not regret it at all, I do enjoy the game. Check out some gameplay videos maybe, and if you can get it on sale and dig crime/police-games and the era this is set in, check it out!

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												Игра, которая на первый взгляд казалась очередным клоном GTA, Mafia и прочих, оказалась очень и очень приятным сюрпризом. Плюсы:1) Геймплей. Сцены расследования и вдумчивого поиска улик вовремя сменяются погонями и перестрелками, и наоборот. Ни от того, ни от другого заскучать не успеваешь.2) Графика. Дело даже не самой графике, которую я на 100% не оценил из-за не слишком сильного железа, а в лицевой анимации. Персонажи проговаривают каждое слово, эмоции переданы очень и очень достоверно. Впервые вижу такой высокий уровень исполнения.3) Миссии. Они всегда увлекательные и интересные, со своей предысторией. За кровавым убийством обязательно скрывается драма, бармен не хочет выкладывать на-гора всю информацию, похищение оказывается следствием кризиса между супругами, а плохой парень в итоге оказывается хорошим. Даже побочные квесты, которые можно принимать при движении по городу, не повторяются, и их действительно интересно проходить. В этом отношении Rockstar, как всегда, не подкачали.4) Музыка. И та, что играет на радио, и та, что звучит во время расследований - уместно, атмосферно, выполнено на высоком уровне.Минусы:1) Первый и главный минус - Rockstar Games Social Club. Отвратительное дeрьмо, которое постоянно забывает мой пароль, лагает, просит зайти снова, в общем, всячески мешает играть. Если бы можно было приступить к игре, не заморачиваясь с регистрацией, стало бы только лучше.2) Еще один минус, менее существенный, но все же заметный - открытый мир. Песочница тут довольно-таки безжизненная, но основная проблема не в этом, а в том, что открытый мир тут не играет никакой роли, мы бы запросто могли обойтись и без него, автоматически перемещаясь по локациям, связанным с текущим расследованием. Местный сендбокс не делает ничего, помимо растягивания геймплея ненужными поездками из точки А в точку Б. Вспоминается старая добрая Mafia, в которой перед каждой миссией нужно катить через весь чертов город на убитом драндулете.3) Излишняя казуальность. Потратив так называемые очки интуиции, вы можете узнать правильную реплику при допросе или увидеть расположение всех (!) улик на месте преступления. Это ломает геймплей, связанный с расследованием.Итог: очень интересный эксперимент от Rockstar, не лишенный недостатков, но определенно стоящий того, чтобы ознакомиться с ним. 7/10 только лишь за отвратный RGSC.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												x_xSo in this game you pay as a legal criminal who works to take out the competition who don't have the same backing of the government. Okay... in all seriousness the player character is (mostly) a decent guy, but your fellow policemen tend to be either bitter, corrupt, or narrow-minded. And while the last of those makes sense for the 1940's, it still ensured that my opinion of police in this game is more or less what it is IRL: a handful of good people in a sea of jerks who are no better than the people they throw in jail.Anyway... gamey. You search crime scenes for things, interrogate people about the things you find, and sometimes shoot people since these are American police and they like to do that sort of thing. Though at least in this case all the people you are forced to shoot tend to be firing back at you, so I guess that's justifiable. While the gameplay isn't broken, it just... didn't work for me. I was bored alot of the time and the game choosing to rate my performance promoted save scumming and looking for guides rather than working things out for myself. And while I suppose it is my fault for deciding to skip the "fun" of figuring out things for myself, I just felt uninterested and wanted to be done with it all......well, until the late parts of the game, when things heat up and interesting plot stuff actually starts happening. And while the final level is a bit absurd by being a massive gunfight and a rushed ending with alot of unresolved messes, at least the stuff before it was interesting and kept me wanting to see where things would end up.I'm not sure about this game. It felt really long and the first half was profoundly lacking in excitement. I suppose that would be realistic: most police stuff is samey and boring I expect. But the "realism" here came at the cost of fun, and I could barely play more than a case at a time before I had to go do something else to entertain myself.But it's not a bad game. It's just not for me. I'll give this a "yes" because it works, does get better later on, and that there is no "maybe" option on Steam and I don't dislike this game enough to give it a "no".Yey... now I can do something else. x_x

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												Really fun detective game, but don't expect it to be anything like a 50s GTA game.  There's a freeroam option which is mainly used for completing all of the fourty street crimes.  This is a game aimed at a more mature audience due to realistic nature of the investigations.  As others have stated, the investigations can be somewhat repetitive if you complete a lot of them in a row (I'd suggest not to do this obviously).  The graphics look nice for a game released 5 years ago,  and every main case (there's 21 of these cases in total including 5 DLC cases) has unique locations which add a lot to the detective atmosphere.The Rockstar Social Club thing is mandatory and stupidly annoying to some, but there's an easy trick to avoid the "necessary account creation":  either disconnect your internet manually with the cable or disable the internet connection on your internet options.  The game will detect your computer has no internet connection, and it will prompt you to create an offline account.  This account only requires you to enter a username, and the game will automatically sign you into the username when you reload the game with or without an internet connection active.I recommend anyone with an interest in detective media to purchase this game, but you should wait for a sale.  It's usually at least 50% off when it is on sale due to its age.  The game still holds up today because of the unique motion capture technology used to simulate the in-game characters.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												By and large, one of the most interesting games I've played for a long while. Instead of the classic reliance on violence, explosions, car chases, bullet time and skimpily clad anime girls, this game 'ACTUALLY' does what it set out to do, and did it rather well considering just how difficult it must've been to release this in the way it was intended; as a detective simulator.The game has 3 styles in one: Interrogation/Interviewing , Open World Transportation , Crime Scene Investigation.Open World Transportation is rather simple...You drive around in your 1950s or something automobile copcar, with your partner whose usually a complete♥♥♥♥♥♥ And you go from place to place depending on where the case takes you, be it a gunshop, a grieving widows home, an axe murderers back yard, or the filthy hard drive of a delusional waifu hunter weeaboo's hard drive(Not really).Crime Scene Investigation is part 2 to Open World Transportation. You arrive at the crime scene, and you wobble around the place looking for clues, such as bloody hand guns, Newspaper clippings, bullet casings, or used condoms with banana flavor (Not really).Interrogation/Interviewing is the selling part of the whole game, and obviously where the most time and effort was dumped in. The faces of the characters in the game were enchanced with live-action motion mapping of an actual actor's face, to help one determine what they're thinking. It makes tell-tale characteristics, like fidget eyes, a nervous lip twitch, or even something subtle like a quivering eyebrow, more evident and easy to determine. In this way, the game went above and beyond, and really makes the process of deciding whether someone is telling the truth or lying, a treat.The graphics are hard to determine in a singular way due to the fact that the developpers have been so picky-choosey with what they focus their attention and effort on. For example, buildings are pretty damned bare-bones. You don't really look at the wall texture and go "THIS IS AMAZING", as they never really stand out enough for you to even notice them. They're just there. Cars and bodies are a little bit better, although movement and shooting a hand gun still looks rather robotic and unnatural. Meanwhile, the faces are a whole different level of quality and attention to detail, which honestly looks a bit weird and kind of crappy when you think about it. Crappy everything else, except for the faces which are smooth and perfect in every way?....Talk about playing favorites guys, jeez, at least TRY to make it less painfully obvious next time.All in all, the game's fun, and you'll get tons of hours of fun out of it if you're into detective work and such, but don't be super impressed by the game's execution as a whole. Take it for what it is, a detective simulator. It's not Grand Theft Auto, and don't expect it to be.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Since there is no neutral rating I guess I'll give this a thumbs up.  But just barely.  The gameplay in Noire gets extremely repetitive.  This is a game best played in short bursts as binge playing will quickly wear on your mind with the same ol' gameplay in every case.  Here is a break down of a typical case:1. Meet the suspect.2. Walk around and press A to interact with stuff.3. Interrogate suspect.4. Leave and drive around to the next clue location.5. Chase suspect on foot until forced to do a driving sequence.NPC's act strange someetimes during interrogations too.  Like when you think they're lying, it turns out it was the truth.  Or, they will do something that will completely incriminate themselves and send them to jail.  Controls are pretty awful.  I can't imagine playing this on a keyboard so I use a controller but it still has tanky controls.  Moving Cole around is very slow and the input is delayed.  Still, the game is fun in short bursts.  If you like the 40's pulp era novel's you'll appreciate the seting in Noir.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												For all it's flaws, I loved L.A. Noire.The port, first off, is woeful. After you've contended with Rockstar Social Club updating and generally being a nuisance, the fight is getting the game looking pretty while keeping the framerate consistent. I played the whole thing through at the locked-in 30fps, and had a fine time.For it's time, this is a beautiful, innovative game. The facial models make characters readable and relatable, and the generally minimalist nature of the game - few HUD features popping in or out, heavy reliance on sound rather than visual signposting - allows the game to unfold like a dense TV series rather than a videogame. The atmosphere is exceptional, and period music and vehicles only add to that.The story is good, although it wanes towards the end. The same goes for the gameplay - it is fun, unique, and rewarding, but also blows its wad off the bat: by the endgame, you're doing the same things you were at the very start.Even still, a fantastic single-player experience.

I can't imagine playing this on a keyboard so I use a controller but it still has tanky controls.  Moving Cole around is very slow and the input is delayed.  Still, the game is fun in short bursts.  If you like the 40's pulp era novel's you'll appreciate the seting in Noir.
