number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												WARNING: Possible spoilers ahead, read at your own risk.Pros:A very well put together narrative, which catalogues the rise and fall of it's characters, in typical Film-noir fashion.Strong, believable characters with excellent delivery both from their respective actors and the awe-inspiring motion-capture technology utilized.Your partners. Their random banter and distinguished personalities are a joy to behold, they act both as the lancer and the foil to Cole's personality, and do an excellent job of playing off of Cole's own musings.Meh's:Lack of penalty for not upholding laws (especially when dealing with traffic), Cole can drive as recklessly as he wants, even right next to other cops without them giving a damn.The structure of the cases, especially between Homicide and Vice. In Homicide, you just finished solving a case that had made a mockery of the LAPD, and in turn, acted as a very rewarding end to that desk. BD would have served as a greater case to end the game with, although given the circumstances, I'm inclined to believe that the narrative was constructed before the individual cases, and that the cases merely served to facilitate Cole's fall from grace.Cons:The save system is check-point based, which is fine, until you realize you have to restart a case and lose an hour's worth of gameplay because the game decides to auto-save after a failed interrogation.Combat, atleast on the PC version, is rather finnicky and temperamental. The gunplay itself works, but the cover system is unresponsive and has baffling key-binds.All in all:If you're willing to deal with slow gameplay coupled with investigatory work and puzzle-solving, this game is right up your alley. It's not a masterpiece, but it will serve as the industry-wide standard for detective games in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												L.A Noire plays out in the mid-20th century, just after the Second World War. You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a good hearted cop who was a soldier in the pacific during the second world war. The game confronts you with a time period where racism was rampant, drug abuse was growing, and violence was all too common. The city of L.A is one of the major stars in the game. Every street is full of life, with people going in and out of bars and shops, people reading the daily newspaper before going to work. The game feels as though its actually come to life. MotionScan, a neat piece of technology which Team Bondi created to capture the emotions of the characters on screen. It works splendidly, giving each conversation an engrossing hook that typically associated with great film and television dramas. When a character lies, you can see it in their face. Interviewing a suspect is the hardest and most important thing you will do in the game. You ask a question, listen to their response and then attempt to decipher whether it's a lie, the truth or something you should "doubt" and inquire further about. You don't only listen to what they saying, but you have to look very carefully at their faces as well. The slightest twitch in there cheek, or there eyes darting quickly to the left can help you uncover the truth. There is more to L.A Noire than just interrogation. There is a fair amount of crime-scene investigation, patrolling and beat work. At crime scenes, you are able to examine the victim up close to try find clues. You will walk around crime scene picking up all sorts of objects to see if they hold any clues. Outside of the regular story. L.A. Noire offers a few other tasks. You can explore the city and look for historic L.A. landmarks, tackle random side mission crimes as they come to you over your C.B. radio, as well as play additional DLC cases. Once you have finished a story, you are ranked to how well you answered questions, how many you got right, and how much damage you did to your car and the the city of L.A. The sounds in the game are amazing, with cars and busses going by, to the sound of the sparks coming from the electric wires as the tram drives past you. The acting is completely believable and really helps set this game apart from other detective games. The Verdict:For all of its attention to detail, L.A. Noire hits the occasional false note. But if you put that aside, L.A Noire can be a very entertaining game, with an open world to explore and lots of interesting cases, The awesome performances and great facial capture make every interrogation and investigation a riveting affair. L.A Noire is a perfect game that I would definitely recommend to everyone. Pros:+ Open world of an authentic and outstanding 1940s style of atmosphere+ Memorable story+ Great use of motion capture+ Compelling investigation and interrogation mechanics + Amazing graphics+ Brilliant acting + Amazing soundCons:- Some restrictions during pursuits and shoot-outs feel artificial- Can become a bit repetitive at timesScore: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												As a cinematic experience, LA Noire is very good. It has a stack of content, compelling stories, great voice acting and revolutionary facial animation. It tackles challenging themes in a mature manner. It offers a large area to explore, built with great attention to detail.As a game...it's a mixed bag. The distractions - driving, shooting, tailing and collecting items - are nothing special. The core is the investigation - searching for clues and interrogating witnesses/suspects. The former is decent, with helpful difficulty options. The latter has its moments, both good and keyboard-smashingly bad.Two examples. A witness is asked about a document found in the possession of somebody else. There is no reason to be sure, or even reasonably suspect, that she is aware of it. When she denies knowledge of it, an appropriate choice response would seem to be "Doubt". According to the game, it's "Lie" - even though her response seems to confirm that she was unaware of it, making the "Lie" a strange choice. Even worse, there is another situation where you are expected to select "Lie", when the actual lie arises from the response to your challenge upon choosing "Lie"!The single checkpoint save is also frustrating. Realise you made a mistake (seeing witness in a certain order cuts out a possible question in an early mission, for instance) or encounter a mission-breaking bug after a checkpoint save, and you have to go back to the very beginning - 30+ mins of unskippable dialogue and driving.There's also port issues - a woeful 30fps, graphical pop-in and the like.For all that...it's still a compelling experience. As much as it annoys me, I keep coming back. It may require a new keyboard by the end, but it'll be worth it.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2013
												Respect to Rockstar for originality. Really refreshing gameplay, never played anything like it. Overall pretty much all of the elements are high quality too, nice visuals, great soundtrack, interesting and mature story. The action and driving although far from perfect are decent enough. The investigating, interrogation and story is were the game excels though. Plus I enjoyed the use of the motionscan technology (facial expressions).I did feel it dragged on a bit but remedied by taking a break now and again, one of the main flaws was the most fun part of the game - interrogating suspects and witnesses sometimes failed due to the way the system works and how it is named. Finally it seemed a shame that in such a lovingly crafted and detailed  world there was very little, if any reason to explore away from the main story. A favourite film of mine is Chinatown and LA Noire at points made me feel like I was taking part in my own similar movie. I hope they make a sequel one day and it remains in that era. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Well, the game is broken. Most people can't seem to launch it since a recent patch, hence the many negative reviews. However, one community member, namely Nightbreed, found a solution to make the game work fairly easily. And it is reported by many members to work.You can find his solution here:http://steamcommunity.com/app/110800/discussions/0/366298942102103678/So, once we're through with launching the game (even though Rockstar tried hard to make it impossible), we have a nice game after all. There is noire, there are realistic facial expressions (which we have to learn how to read if we want to crack all the cases), and the story itself creates a nice atmosphere. Maybe one of the greatest trait of this game is that it's one of a kind. Trust me, there might be other detective games, but none other recreates the unique game experience that L.A. Noire provides. It's not action pumped, although it does have shootings once in a while, but instead it entrails us with well written dialogues, interesting, and often mind-boggling cases, a knack of humour, all presented to us in a 50's style, with a hint of noire in it.One of the greatest cons I could highlight from this game is a technical one: As it seems, the game is limited at 30fps, so those who have a keen eye for 60fps and beyond, might need some time to get used to it.Other than that, if we get past that tiny little thing, that the game doesn't start in it's original form, I could hardly come up with cons. And why would I?Fix the game, then play the hell out of it. Case closed.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												UPDATE: Thanks to Nightbreed, the game is playable right now. Full review incoming when I finish it.To fix launching issues, try Nightbreed's guide. Don't forget to rate it if it helped you! And, if you meet him, buy the man a beer, willya.


Problems launching L.A. Noire? Try this fix! 
A Guide for L.A. Noire
By: ƝƖƓӇƬƁƦЄЄƊ

			I made this guide because the thread I posted to the community forum seems to have helped a lot of people. With this information in the form of a guide I'm hoping that it serves as a better source of knowledge on what...		


OLDER VERSION OF THE REVIEW HERE***************************************************THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF THE GAME ITSELF, BUT ITS CURRENT PLAYABILITYAs you might notice from a lot of recent reviews, L.A. Noire is currently unplayable on Windows 10 64bit, and perhaps other operating systems too.I tried all the fixes out there, checked the integrity of .NET framework (both 3.5 and 4), have latest upgrades and drivers installed. Compatibility modes, run game as administrator, run Steam as administrator, reinstall, check game cache, everything. Nothing worked.It just shows the loading screen after the loader and stops working. Windows Event Viewer shows an error saying 0x40000015 unknown application exception. The faulty module is MSVCR90.dll (part of VS2008 runtime, THIS IS NOT THE MISSING MSVCR90.DLL PROBLEM).Seems like the problem has persisted for quite a while, and Rockstar isn't too keen on fixing it (and has one of the worst customer support websites out there).This is the reason of a negative review - I am yet to play the game. If they fix it at all, that is.The reason why there aren't more negative reviews out here is that I was forced to farm "playtime" by repeatedly trying to launch the game to be able to write this time.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												You're one of the LA's finest, a former military veteran who is looking to build a successful career out of law enforcement in 1940's post World War II L.A. with fancy suits and muscle cars. It's men's world.Playing L.A. Noire is like taking part in an interactive movie. It's more than just watching the action as you get to take part in it. And the outcome of the cases is determined on your gut, your attention to detail, and interrogation skills rather than just wating the actor to state their line. If there is at least a tiny bit of detective in you and you want to get to the bottom of things then you'll find the storyline captivating and it will drag you in like honey.As of gameplay, mouse & keyboard combo is tolerable. Walking and running around with keys and using mouse to look/aim works fine most of the time. Driving is slightly awkward when you want to drive straight or especially when trying to take sharp corners in high speed due to the fact that the camera turns slowly behind the vehicle unless your mouse hand is in sync with your keyboard hand. Many times I've ended up smashing bumpers with oncoming traffic or rear fender taking contact with nearby mailbox or lamp post. However, as this is not the most important mechanic I bare with it. Car chases are still fun.Interrogation of people is the one that gives you the most "what ifs". Do I believe what this person is saying with their eyes rolling out of their heads or do I push my luck to squeeze the last bit of information they have? Or do I dare to state they're lying and then provide them with evidence that I know what the real case is? And you'd better have the evidence with such allegation or the conversation may be short lived.The gameplay involves occasional chases both on foot and on wheels, some gunfights and brawls. They play out decently not getting too much attention from the story itself. In overall, there's a nice balance of action, seeking and dialogue to my taste and it keeps me tempted to replay a case after a case until I get the gist of how it should have been.If you have no patience and you couldn't care less about the story then this might not be the game for you. But if you're into the era and the mysteries of police detectives then I highly recommend L.A. Noire.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												this game was excellent, it's largely something unlike the majority of game experiences i've had. I really enjoyed the interrogation mechanics and the use of the motion capture technology for the actors faces to be realistically portrayed in the game was just awesome.the game loses some steam right after the early sections, it becomes sort of repetitive and the action sequences (driving and shooting sections) are spaced out a little too far for a few hours of gameplay, but make it through this slower section and the game's story and action pick up and hook you into the experience hard enough to push through to the more exciting final chapters of the game.I experienced a few minor technical issues - mostly with the controls at certain sections of the game, navigating tighter spaces when looking for clues can be a bit clunky and the cover shooting mechanics felt very unpolished and I tended to avoid using the cover system because of that.9.5/10 experience overall. Had the pacing been a little better in the second act of the game, and the control issues not been there it could've been a 10/10. These two small issues didn't keep me from loving the game regardless though. Probably a top 10 game of all time for me.get it now

One woman might find it hard to look you in the eye whether she's telling the truth or not, a man might be exceptional at wearing a fake smile, and another might change his story purely because he's scared. content:
Posted: March 14, 2012
												L.A. Noire is a lot like an adventure game, but it's very original and doesn't spare any novelty for that. I found it very enjoyable, a game full of mystery, with a well written story and interesting characters. Action is well done likewise, but it isn't the main focus of the game, instead it's the process of solving a case, finding the truth even though the harder you go, the harder it is. The whole facial animations are great, in fact there are no animations - the facial expressions are taken from real people. Unfortunately it can fall in the Uncanny Valley at times, but you can't blame it for that since, it's trying to succeed. If there would be no initiative - there would be no success. This is a favourite of mine.

Problems launching L.A. Noire? Try this fix! 
A Guide for L.A. Noire
By: ƝƖƓӇƬƁƦЄЄƊ

			I made this guide because the thread I posted to the community forum seems to have helped a lot of people. With this information in the form of a guide I'm hoping that it serves as a better source of knowledge on what...		


OLDER VERSION OF THE REVIEW HERE***************************************************THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF THE GAME ITSELF, BUT ITS CURRENT PLAYABILITYAs you might notice from a lot of recent reviews, L.A. Noire is currently unplayable on Windows 10 64bit, and perhaps other operating systems too.I tried all the fixes out there, checked the integrity of .NET framework (both 3.5 and 4), have latest upgrades and drivers installed. Compatibility modes, run game as administrator, run Steam as administrator, reinstall, check game cache, everything. Nothing worked.It just shows the loading screen after the loader and stops working. Windows Event Viewer shows an error saying 0x40000015 unknown application exception. The faulty module is MSVCR90.dll (part of VS2008 runtime, THIS IS NOT THE MISSING MSVCR90.DLL PROBLEM).Seems like the problem has persisted for quite a while, and Rockstar isn't too keen on fixing it (and has one of the worst customer support websites out there).This is the reason of a negative review - I am yet to play the game. If they fix it at all, that is.The reason why there aren't more negative reviews out here is that I was forced to farm "playtime" by repeatedly trying to launch the game to be able to write this time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												LA Noire is a unique and fun game in the aspect of how it plays. The main goals are to collect clues, interview witnesses and solve crimes with a cast of very real characters. I don't mean this lightly, having worked in security and talking with LEO, the different characters are people you will or have met before. The game is nearly six years old now, but still feels and looks pretty modern. Casual and veteran players alike will enjoy most of the game. People living in LA will appreciate the games setting and take on a fictional 1940s. Don't come in expecting action like GTA, it's quite the opposite, but in a nice way. Think of it like listening to music from this time compared to modern tracks. Where I feel the game lacks is namely it's pace after a certain point of the game and it's main character, Cole Phelps. Much like Zero Punctuations comments, Cole comes off as a robot and for me I don't see much change at all. It makes controlling him quite boring after a certain point. Yes, he is a straight as arrow cop wanting to redeem himself, but he's so detached for most of the game it feels a bit akward and the few times he does seem to show emotion or connect, it's almost like filler. Lastly is the ending, I won't spoil it, but to me it felt lackluster and as if the team inteded to make a sequel, but got canned before they could. I still would recommend the game for it's unique approach to gameplay, but don't go in believing all the hype, because honestly, if they had made Cole develop as a character more, and the ending a bit more concluded, I felt the game would have overall been a fair bit better.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I really wish there was a 'mixed' option because I appreciate what this game was trying to do (and in many regards it succeeded), but ultimately it was ahead of its time and felt lacking in some departments.The game itself, while having an amazing story, complemented by top notch character development felt awefully linear. I often felt like I had to choose what the game wanted me to choose and wasn't allowed any freedom throughout the cases, such as when there are two pieces of evidence that could equally disprove someone, but the game only allows one to be correct, you cannot present both, or one or the other, only the one will be correct; that combined the 30FPS lock is what makes me have mixed opinions about this game.I would still recommend to anybody looking for a crime-thriller, or just a great story driven game in general.It was a great idea by Team Bondi, but unfortunately ahead of its time, I hope someone at Rockstar picks this title up again and we eventually get a sequel.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												You play as a LAPD officer in 1947, trying to make the city a better place. Under the rising silver screen stars of Hollywood and the American dream, lies the dark side of the big city: contraband morphine hits the streets, people die from overdoses, a serial killer is on the run, families are burning in house fires, and a few of your fellow cops workmates are not very clean.This game is awesome, you don't see the time flying by when playing it. The 3D animations and motion captures are very well done. The voice actors are really believeable and the main plot is simply amazing. It is definitely worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												The suspect was taken into the station. I searched the place for more clues. Didn't get much out of it. I went back to interrogate the suspect. He was with me on okinawa, he was never really my friend, but he wasn't really my enemy. I started with small talk about the war back in the day. But he's fed up and said cut the crap. So i started questioning him about the murder. He got no alibi at the time of death. It was a simple question, but a complex answer.Now the hard part, I have to decide. Is it the truth? Or a doubt? Or maybe a lie. I decided to trust him. And he gave me another lead. I went on with that lead with my partner. It was pretty convincing, so i decided to take him as another suspect and brought him to the station. While searching the place, i found the murder weapon and proceed to interrogate him. He gave an alibi. I chose the lie, and show him the evidence. I charged him, and the DA will do the work next.I went home, not to the usual place. It was a blue room, i saw an angel singing i always kill.  I was tempted. The next morning i went to the office, there's another murder. So i went to the crime scene, expecting a new body. But i was wrong. It's the same mark as before, the murder didn't stop. At that moment i knew that it was him. I went to his place and dragged him back to the station. He insisted that it wasn't him. And i said that's a lie. But it was pretty convincing, so i persuaded him to gave up names. He's a tough guy, he won't gave up his friends. So it must be on our unit back in the army. Just before i went to continue the investigation, the boss called me. There's a picture of me with the germans. My wife left me, and i got demoted. It was my partner, he rat me out. Then i wondered, who's really the enemy, and who's really the friend? I got caught in the truth and the lie. So i forgot the doubt. Then i doubt the LAPD, i doubt my partner, i doubt my wife, i doubt him. And the most important one, i doubt myself. I said goodbye to the angel. Forever.Then i went home to play L.A Noire.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2012
												L.A. Noire, set in the 1947 Los Angeles, puts you in the shoes of the LAPD detective Cole Phelps. In addition to creating a perfect atmosphere and unbelievably well made set of facial expressions for the characters, the game allows you to dive more deeply into the work of an old school detective. Be on the good side for a change and wear that cool hat with honor!

												L.A. Noire is a fantastic game. I personally give it a 10/10. Because it has a fantastic story that is unparalleled even in today's movies and books. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												It's like playing a movie, in the best way imaginable.I've seen previews of it, and I was intrigued. I heard more about it and I really got interested. I saw someone demo it and I was immediately sold. This game is not for everyone, however. It has gritty visuals and intense subject matter. If you like the Black Dahlia film or Noir detective stories, you may like this. The sound direction is superb, and the music is very well done. Some tracks can wear on the nerves, but the action tracks put you in the moment.This game plays very well on Windows 7, but crashes do happen on occasion.Overall, this is a very excellent title, and the actors are superb, for the most part. If you watch Mad Men, you may see more familiar faces than just Phelps. This is a huge leap for in-game visuals, as the talking heads do look very good most of the time. Some glitches can be jarring, but they're few.It's a large game, and requres a lot of RAM and a very capable video card. Nevertheless, it's well worth the visit to 1940's Los Angeles if you want a good detective procedural.

												Worth reviewing for a lump of coal or a badge. However...Highly engrossing. Some say it's repetitious, probably due to each case essentially having you starting from scratch. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I bought this game a few years ago, but I never got around to playing it because my computer was a potato. However, here I am now having completed the game on my new computer, and here is what I have to say about the game. The game takes place in 1947 Los Angeles, and you are put in the position of a police officer who is working their way up the ladder of law enforcement. The gameplay is in third person, and if you are looking for something like GTA, then look elsewhere. L.A. Noire is a game that requires a lot of decision making and reflection on evidence that you find at multiple crime scenes in each case that you are assigned. Which brings in another mechanic, you have to track down the evidence with is indicated by a sound, or a vibration if you have a controller. I'm going to be honest, in the first few cases it was fun to do the investigations without any guides, but it got old really fast. I ended up going over guides while doing investigations, and this actually helped me with a lot of the achievements, but it takes away from one of the core mechanics of the game, which is to carry out the investigations yourself. Does this make it a terrible game? No. It is a really great game for what it is. It has a good balance of action and investigation, and the story is really good. The graphics aren't really amazing, compared to other things released around the time of this games publication, but this really doesn't detract from the game. Overall, I was disappointed that this wasn't GTA set in 1947, but the game makes up for this with tons of fun little side missions, challenging achievements, and some really funny and interesting dialogue. I would rate this an 8/10 because it has a lot to do, but at some points you will just get really frustrated and want to play something else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												I powered through L.A. Noire because I enjoyed the story and I found each case to be compelling.  The way it weaved the past into current events and tied things together by the end was legendary.  The way the devs captured the actor's facial expressions, while treading into the uncanny valley big-time, gave this game an amazing quality.  Driving through old time Los Angeles was a lot of fun.  I think this is a game most people will enjoy.All that being said sometimes when characters talk their mouths look really wrong.  It looks like the mesh is the wrong shape for the expression ( usually noticable with yelling and other large mouth shapes).  While historically accurate all the cars look way too much alike to necessate the diversity in this game (especially with the frustrating achievement attached to driving them all).  Getting in and out of cars takes flippin' forever.  Special cars that boast a max speed of 140 MPH even at full throtle the game says your max speed even was around 86 MPH.The main gameplay element of interrigation is frustrating as they purposefully designed it to not allow you to restart a bad interrigation over without quitting and reloading your last save.  Sure, it opens other opportunities to play through the mission based on failure to catch the person in a lie but that wasn't what I was playing this for. Story gripes ahead, Spoilers: The love interest in this game looks like a dirty bag of melted action figures so when Cole started persuing her romatically I didn't buy it for a second.  You are a war hero get a woman that is worth the trouble. The ending was purposefully unsatisfying but come on give a guy some hope that Cole's work wasn't for nothing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Solid, interesting crime thriller, but with rough edges. Good things:-Paints an incredible atmosphere of 1940s L.A., with stunning historical detail. -Unique and innovative way of moving through cases based on being able to read lies through social cues. -Interesting companions with a lot of fun, banter-y dialogue. -Fun car chase mechanics - you can't run over citizens when you're a cop, so you have to restrain your GTA urges. -Really strong voice acting and motion capture.Bad things:-Driving AI is atrocious - other cars will swerve straight into you, and you suffer the blame for it. Also, civilians are horrible at avoiding your police car, even with full sirens blazing. -The Truth/Doubt/Lie mechanic can be a little harsh and often slightly unfair with how it determines a 'correct' response. -Slightly repetitive and formulaic for the first 3/4 of the game. -Roy Earle's existence. I'd definitely recommend picking this game up in a sale, especially for the thrilling crime atmosphere of a noir cop. At full price, though, I'd have to think hard about recommending it, because it often frustrated me, or felt a little too repetitive by the middle sections.

												One of the best games Rockstar ever made? La Noire is about a cop named Cole Phelps that keeps getting promoted (from Patol desk then all the way until arson desk.) you can do it in color or in Black and White (I think Black and White is better for this type of game.) this game is like is like a lie dectector, but you have to pay attention to details instead of a machine telling it or no. when asking questions to witnesses you can choose 3 things when they answer, Truth, Doubt or lie. this is when paying attention to details comes in you have to see how they have say their answers and their face expressions they have also pay attention to how many times they blink or move their head all over the place. but without anymore detail about the game it's a true classic game and a masterpiece of a game. 9.5/10

												If you are looking for a detective game and find the CSI series too boring you should definitely buy L.A. Noire. The game's set in 1947, after the second world war. The gameplay is set in an open world similar to GTA. You work cases, ranging from homicide, vice, arson and traffic as the main story line unfolds itself. You can play the game multiple times and discover new clues which lead to a deeper understanding of a case. You may miss vital parts or accuse an innocent person, or let a guilty one go if you don't find all evidence and process each crime scene. Definitely buy this game it's worth it.

Let's Play L. A. Noire: Craziest Glitch Ever! Headless Game in Medias Res! Nosy Old Hag, No Head Bug 
A Video of L.A. Noire
By: Knave of Hearts

			Watch the rest of my playthrough of L.A. Noire, starting from Homicide department and cases related to the BD Tex / Black Dahlia murders:...		


Worst PC port ever, to even launch the game you need to find somewhere and download an old version of Rockstar Social Club, install in, back it up, let the game autoupdate it (it won't launch without updating and the last update doesn't load the game) THEN delete the new version and restore your backup. After all of that you need to set compatibility in the new back♥♥♥♥♥♥way for Windows 7/8 and repeat every time before launching... A hidden gamble is if it'll launch from Steam directly or from the game folder. It's like roulette, really! "Rockstar" can't do PC games and swindled actual developer (Team Bondi) out of money... even Japanese developers with no experience on PC make better ports. Never buying a game from a publisher with such a pretentious name, even on a big sale. Oh and it's so full of bugs it's barely playable.That said, the game itself is amazing. "Rockstar" games just needs to crawl under a rock and slowly die, since they manage to be a publisher worse than EA, Ubisoft and Capcom all together.

I'm going to be honest, in the first few cases it was fun to do the investigations without any guides, but it got old really fast. I ended up going over guides while doing investigations, and this actually helped me with a lot of the achievements, but it takes away from one of the core mechanics of the game, which is to carry out the investigations yourself. Does this make it a terrible game? No. It is a really great game for what it is. It has a good balance of action and investigation, and the story is really good. The graphics aren't really amazing, compared to other things released around the time of this games publication, but this really doesn't detract from the game. Overall, I was disappointed that this wasn't GTA set in 1947, but the game makes up for this with tons of fun little side missions, challenging achievements, and some really funny and interesting dialogue. I would rate this an 8/10 because it has a lot to do, but at some points you will just get really frustrated and want to play something else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												L.A. Noire is an incredible interactive experience where you play the role of a detective in a wide variety of different police cases. The first noticeable thing is the amazing detail of the faces. And this is important because it is the player's job to determine whether people are telling the truth or lying based on their facial expressions during interviews.The gameplay is essentially broken down into driving to different scenes, searching for clues, interviewing people, and occasionally chasing down suspects. It is really unlike any other game on the market and it does a great job at drawing you in. Musical chimes are used to let you know when you are next to something relevant so it is important to keep an open ear.The story feels realistic and is broken into shorter chapters meaning it's easy to pick up again after not playing it for a while. The acting is superb. All the characters feel genuine and it is obvious they put their heart and soul into their roles adding to that sense of realism. The game also showcases some great music as well. With 30+ hours of enjoyment, this is a must play game in my book.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Solid, interesting crime thriller, but with rough edges. Good things:-Paints an incredible atmosphere of 1940s L.A., with stunning historical detail. -Unique and innovative way of moving through cases based on being able to read lies through social cues. -Interesting companions with a lot of fun, banter-y dialogue. -Fun car chase mechanics - you can't run over citizens when you're a cop, so you have to restrain your GTA urges. -Really strong voice acting and motion capture.Bad things:-Driving AI is atrocious - other cars will swerve straight into you, and you suffer the blame for it. Also, civilians are horrible at avoiding your police car, even with full sirens blazing. -The Truth/Doubt/Lie mechanic can be a little harsh and often slightly unfair with how it determines a 'correct' response. -Slightly repetitive and formulaic for the first 3/4 of the game. -Roy Earle's existence. I'd definitely recommend picking this game up in a sale, especially for the thrilling crime atmosphere of a noir cop. At full price, though, I'd have to think hard about recommending it, because it often frustrated me, or felt a little too repetitive by the middle sections.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												More like a movie rather than a game, L.A. Noire is a splendid interactive translation of a noir novel, in particular Black Dhalia and L.A. Confidential by J. Ellroy (which I also recommend). The 1950 Los Angeles is immersive and realistically reproduced, framing a brilliant plot and a character developement worthy of a book. Interactive dialogues are the soul of the game, being also the key to conduct interrogatories and solve cases: for this purpose a very detailed facial motion capture permits to evaluate emotional reactions and to expose lies. Detective work is realistic and capturing, allowing personal investigation lines and always letting the player to deduce and judge in first person.Although cinematographic narration overwhelms the gameplay, L.A. Noire is another confirmation of what level of care Rockstar puts in his videogames.93/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												CSI: Los Angeles 1947 style...Developed by Team Bondi, L.A. Noire sets you up as detective Cole Phelps. Unlike in previous Rockstar entries (ie GTA), you play asThe story is unique and has a few twists to keep you interested. You start of as a rookie cop, after returning home from army service from Japan. After a series of cases you move onto different cases including homicide, vice and arson. Gameplay involves a mix between evidence gathering, chases and combat. In each case, you need to look to look for clues at the crime scene. This will involve interacting with items at the scene (picking up and observing stuff) as well as questioning witnesses. When you intereact with items (e.g. bodies, cups etc) you can move the item around to observe them from different angle and therefore hopefully finding the sclues you need. Some of the items that you pick up at the crime scene may add no value to solving the case what so ever, so they would have best been left uninteractable to the player to save time.A unique mechanic to the game are the detailed facial expressions from characters. You need to look at character's facial expressions closely when asking questions to tell whether they are telling the truth, lying or you have doubts. If you choose truth, then you proceed in asking other questions. The lie option involves you showing proof (from the evidence you collected) that they are indeed lieing. The doubt option is used when you have a feeling that they are lieing, but you don't have the evidence to back it up. Furthermore, you may recognise some of the faces from actors you know.Combat is decent but not spectacular. You are limited to the weapons that are in you police trunk. Most of time you will have a shotgun in the trunk,but if you have DLC you can get the tommy gun as well. There is a cover system, so you can hide behind cover such as cars, buidlings and furntiture to avoid bullets and heal. Your health is indicated by the screen turning red and regenerates over time when you're not being shot. You can also pick up enemy weapons if you ran out of ammo. Combat is quite rare and generally occurs near the ending levels of the game during police raids or chases.During chases the aim is  to catch and interrogate the suspect. this involves sprinting at them and trying not to get too far behind. When you are close enough,  you need to aim your gun at the suspect for a period of time before you can apprehend him. Sometimes chases may be in vehicles,. In this circumstance, you need to chase and ram the other vehicle until they get stuck and therefore arrested.There is a free roaming element to the game, however your activities are far more limited than GTA. You can't pull out your gun and shoot civilians. You can ram down civilians during cases, but that will lower your score. You can't buy stuff either and there are only a limited number of buildings  you may enter. There are some random crimes which you can solve while free roaming the city as well as collectable items and cars. Otherwise your free roaming options are more limited compared to GTA games.The audio is fantastic. Music does a great job at settiing the 1940's atmosphere. Character voice acting sounds perfect as well.The graphics are decent for the time. Character modles may not look that great, but the city of Los Angeles definitely looks like it was from the 1940's. There are some noticeable landmarks as well, which you can find.If you're looking for a detective game that oozes with 'Noire' feeling and American 1940's atmosphere, then L.A. Noire is the game for you. However, those looking for a GTA game will be dissapointed.

												Solid, interesting crime thriller, but with rough edges. Good things:-Paints an incredible atmosphere of 1940s L.A., with stunning historical detail. -Unique and innovative way of moving through cases based on being able to read lies through social cues. -Interesting companions with a lot of fun, banter-y dialogue. -Fun car chase mechanics - you can't run over citizens when you're a cop, so you have to restrain your GTA urges. -Really strong voice acting and motion capture.Bad things:-Driving AI is atrocious - other cars will swerve straight into you, and you suffer the blame for it. Also, civilians are horrible at avoiding your police car, even with full sirens blazing. -The Truth/Doubt/Lie mechanic can be a little harsh and often slightly unfair with how it determines a 'correct' response. -Slightly repetitive and formulaic for the first 3/4 of the game. -Roy Earle's existence. I'd definitely recommend picking this game up in a sale, especially for the thrilling crime atmosphere of a noir cop. At full price, though, I'd have to think hard about recommending it, because it often frustrated me, or felt a little too repetitive by the middle sections.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2013
												L.A. Noire is an incredible interactive experience where you play the role of a detective in a wide variety of different police cases. The first noticeable thing is the amazing detail of the faces. And this is important because it is the player's job to determine whether people are telling the truth or lying based on their facial expressions during interviews.The gameplay is essentially broken down into driving to different scenes, searching for clues, interviewing people, and occasionally chasing down suspects. It is really unlike any other game on the market and it does a great job at drawing you in. Musical chimes are used to let you know when you are next to something relevant so it is important to keep an open ear.The story feels realistic and is broken into shorter chapters meaning it's easy to pick up again after not playing it for a while. The acting is superb. All the characters feel genuine and it is obvious they put their heart and soul into their roles adding to that sense of realism. The game also showcases some great music as well. With 30+ hours of enjoyment, this is a must play game in my book.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2013
												Америка 50-х годов, одна из моих самых любимых тем для игр. Обычно нам давали побегать за мафиози, и мы в его роли проварачивали всякие грязные делишки, постепенно становясь более искусной машиной для убийств.. В данной же игре нам предлагают примерить костюм защитника закона, честного и неподкупного полицейского в лице Коула Фелпса. Честно говоря, сначала игра мне не очень понравилась, все казалось через чур простым, но затем дела пошли более трудные, улики оказались спрятаны по всей окрестности, а во время допроса уже стало трудно определить, лжет ли ваш собеседник, или говорит правду. Сюжет в игре выше всяких похвал: он показывает нам коррупционную сторону правительства, да и не только его. Обязательно поиграйте в L.A. Noire и станьте свидетелем жизни обычного человека, который боролся против преступного, лживого, коррупционного мира Города Ангелов.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												8.5/10 Masterpiece. The game took 5 years to finish the development and you can see why as you play.The game invites you to a world of crime and do not hold your hand while you do your best not to miss any single clues or ask the wrong questions. It is surprisingly realistic when it comes to investigations, and if you enjoy crime themed shows, or enjoy books like Sherlock etc, this IS the game for you. Especially the intensive interview part of the game is unique and you really have to look into your notes (that you took while investigating) and read their expressions, tones etc to really hack the cases. As the game progresses the case gets harder and harder and it pushes you little bit at a time.Overall, the game is beautiful and well designed and the gameplay is solid and unique. Although the freedom part of the game is relatively inclusive but it is intentional in order to focus you to the police work.The only thing I dont like about the game is the fact that it requires quite a good computer considering the fact that the game came out quite a long time ago... but still, a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I remember an argument when this game came out that Cole Phelps was a weak character because his actions seemed unlikeable and his character was definately flawed. We see him throughout the game being torn down by his own past , we no longer see him cling to the ivory tower of hypocrisy we saw him in, in the beginning of the game. Playing as Jack Kelso at the end is supposed to make us feel like we made a mistake judging Phelps too early because Kelso is a character who is way too nice and lets others trample over him just so he can call himself an honorary man who lives for a higher purpose. But after the ending, you realize that Phelps was right to abandon his fortune for his passion, that there is no higher purpose but to live with what you want out of life and to chase what you want with reckless abandon. His mistake was joining the marines with this mentality and getting most of his men killed in battle and many more civilians killed. In the end, Elsa healed Cole but when let his guard down, he got the retribution he deserved not for commiting adultery but commiting an act of hubris that led to a long and winding path of death and misery. If you think about it this way, Cole was the suspect the whole time, becasue his warcrimes led to most of the game's murder cases.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Usually I try to finish the games I start as quickly as possible. I do the side quests, I try some achievements, but before playing any other game I try to finish what I started. That’s not the case with LA Noire: I avoid playing it. Why? Because it is in another league completely. The game is so good I’m taking my time to finish it. Literally MONTHS. I simply don’t want to end the story too quickly, I’m sipping it.The graphics are amazing, playing in 1080p with ‘quality’ settings and DX11 is an incredible experience. On the downside, there’s a 30fps lock, but that doesn’t compromise the gameplay because the action isn’t frantic. I find the game to be historically accurate as well. It definitely portrays the beginning of the American “Golden Age” (check the “Old Economy Steven” MEME for further references) in a clear-cut manner. There’s a “Bukowskian” atmosphere surrounding the setting and the characters (Bukowski was living in Los Angeles during the 40’s and both “Ham on Rye” and “Factotum” are accurate descriptions of that period). Coincidence or not, there’s a character in the game named “Bekowsky”...The characters are cynical, disillusioned, smoking drunkards, racist sexist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the “noir femme fatales” shares many of the features of the male characters. LA is portrayed as a XX century Babylonian city packed with all sorts of lowlifes, degenerates, powerful and perverted directors and producers (L.A. didn't changed all that much, huh?). Due to its dedication to the Noir genre the game ends up rated Mature. This definitely isn’t a game for young gents. There’s plenty of nudity in some crime scenes, and the developers don’t hide anything, which is great, otherwise the game couldn’t qualify as a proper Noir-detective title.Since I have already established that this game is a marvelous piece of art, let’s see the cons:•	30 fps lock.•	Rockstar Social Club is required to play the game.•	The aforementioned Rockstar Social Club will eventually request your password, and you won’t remember it because the password needs to be 300 characters long, with 20 special characters, numbers and 125 capital letters. Why? Why??•	Every time you update the Rockstar Social Club, which is mandatory, otherwise the game won’t start… it’ll request your password again. And guess what: that 300 characters password you created 4 months ago won’t work because YOU WON’T REMEMBER IT. And when you request to reset it, all sorts of issues are going to popup. Seriously, you can count on it.•	Rockstar Social Club again. It’s useless. It’s dead weight and it’s sadistic towards the gamers. Steam offers everything a gamer needs, we don’t need extra-layers of crappy proprietary-software between us and the fun. It’s some sort of annoyance toll.•	Rockstar Social Club is worse than Uplay . There, I said it.Other than that the game is a 10/10.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												We're talking about classic Rockstar Games Hi-Quality merchandise here :)L.A. Noire is an amazingly new and fresh concept, in a market that only tries to repeat itself.L.A. Noire is an investigative game in which you are brought to solve many interesting cases as a L.A.P.D. detective.The cases are varied and amazingly well written, ranging from Traffic cases, to Arson cases, ending with Homicide and Vice.From time to time, while you solve these cases, you have to perform other tasks like shootouts or car chases ecc...so the game keeps things interesting for the player.The best feature of the game is the connection you enstablish with the main character.It's not just a linear progression of cases to solve, but you actually follow the intriguing story of the main character Cole Phelps, and all the cases are all connected into a hidden understory which is very engaging.The topics that are dealt with are different, but the atmosphere reminds of L.A. Confidential.The overall graphics are pretty good and the game features a groundbraking facial animation technology which feels strange at first, but then delivers some of the most realistic facial expressions seen in a game, and the best thing is that they are not just for show, they are very important for the gameplay, since you have to check suspects facial expressions (even the smallest details) during interrogations, to spot if they are lying or not.The Los Angeles reconstruction is incredible; the city is ENORMOUS! It almost feels life-size.The player is immersed in a very realistic and detailed representation of the most glamorous city in the world (L.A.), in its prime time (the 1940s, after the war).A great experience, and if you are a patient player you'll be rewarded with one of the best games available on the market.Pros:- The Main Character, which is more multi-layered and constructed than it might look at the beginning- Amazing cases; the developers had great ideas for every case, and you feel engaged to discover the truth- Varied experience (The case-solving is alternated with other activities)- Brilliant interrogations system (you need to take care of the clues and the interrogated person's facial expressions)- L.A. is detailed and beautiful- Engaging story, linking all the cases togheter- Long gameCons:- There's a bit of aliasing, even if you activate antialiasing- Needs a patient player to be appreciated and completed (Not a negative point, but it's just to let you know)- The city is BIG...maybe too big, and some driving phases are a bit boringRecommended!

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Usually I try to finish the games I start as quickly as possible. I do the side quests, I try some achievements, but before playing any other game I try to finish what I started. That’s not the case with LA Noire: I avoid playing it. Why? Because it is in another league completely. The game is so good I’m taking my time to finish it. Literally MONTHS. I simply don’t want to end the story too quickly, I’m sipping it.The graphics are amazing, playing in 1080p with ‘quality’ settings and DX11 is an incredible experience. On the downside, there’s a 30fps lock, but that doesn’t compromise the gameplay because the action isn’t frantic. I find the game to be historically accurate as well. It definitely portrays the beginning of the American “Golden Age” (check the “Old Economy Steven” MEME for further references) in a clear-cut manner. There’s a “Bukowskian” atmosphere surrounding the setting and the characters (Bukowski was living in Los Angeles during the 40’s and both “Ham on Rye” and “Factotum” are accurate descriptions of that period). Coincidence or not, there’s a character in the game named “Bekowsky”...The characters are cynical, disillusioned, smoking drunkards, racist sexist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the “noir femme fatales” shares many of the features of the male characters. LA is portrayed as a XX century Babylonian city packed with all sorts of lowlifes, degenerates, powerful and perverted directors and producers (L.A. didn't changed all that much, huh?). Due to its dedication to the Noir genre the game ends up rated Mature. This definitely isn’t a game for young gents. There’s plenty of nudity in some crime scenes, and the developers don’t hide anything, which is great, otherwise the game couldn’t qualify as a proper Noir-detective title.Since I have already established that this game is a marvelous piece of art, let’s see the cons:•	30 fps lock.•	Rockstar Social Club is required to play the game.•	The aforementioned Rockstar Social Club will eventually request your password, and you won’t remember it because the password needs to be 300 characters long, with 20 special characters, numbers and 125 capital letters. Why? Why??•	Every time you update the Rockstar Social Club, which is mandatory, otherwise the game won’t start… it’ll request your password again. And guess what: that 300 characters password you created 4 months ago won’t work because YOU WON’T REMEMBER IT. And when you request to reset it, all sorts of issues are going to popup. Seriously, you can count on it.•	Rockstar Social Club again. It’s useless. It’s dead weight and it’s sadistic towards the gamers. Steam offers everything a gamer needs, we don’t need extra-layers of crappy proprietary-software between us and the fun. It’s some sort of annoyance toll.•	Rockstar Social Club is worse than Uplay . There, I said it.Other than that the game is a 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 17
												You have to sign up for Rockstar's Social Club in order to play the game. While playing the game, everything hinges on finding clues and interviewing suspects. However, clear evidence to catch suspects in a lie sometimes isn't, you have to guess what the developers were thinking instead of working the evidence in the case as if you were a detective. Addresses and items that you find sometimes don't appear in your evidence book. So it's a linear storyline that you have no real control over. The lead character that you play is also really annoying, and you have to hear his voice for the entire game. You build relationships with characters and they are angry with you one minute, then coming to your defense the next, or vice versa. There's no believability in the flow of the gameplay. They could have done a lot better. This game is a time suck.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												L.A Noire delivers an exceptional story focusing on the exploits of a WWII officer turned detective in post-WWII L.A. The game efficiently blends story within story (past and present), via chapters that seamlessly blend together, efficiently creating a believable narration of one mans journey though a troubled time, and a troubled country. The game boasts amazing facial animation techniques, thus creating a greater range of viable facial contortions for the actors to express. The authenticity of the time is expressed in great detail as shown with the vehicle designs, the setting of the city, the music, and the people. The game boasts an extremely interactive environment in the form of interrogations, crime solving, clue searching (all being core aspects of gameplay), and in a most realistic way. Vehicular chases of any sort are exhilarating and finely executed (as well as the pedestrian chases), although general movement is a tad clunky, and unfortunately the combat mechanics are relatively mediocre, if fluent and stable. In conclusion: L.A Noire is well worth your time and your money, and is a must have for any fan of the mystery/thriller genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Many people think that L.A. Noire is something like Mafia but they are wrong. Those games have common only the age of story maybe. The biggest difference is in the adventure part of L.A. Noire, you'll have to find evidences and to speak with suspect people mostly in the gameplay. Though shootouts aren't frequent (just in optional missions and at the end of the game) and if you get to some they are boring, the investigations of cases are seriously funny and the system of dialogs is great. You have to decide, if suspect person says truth or lies at the moment. If you choose a lie, you must prove your contention by the appropriate evidence that you have found. You can make a pressure per person as well, if you are not sure. The storyline is higher than average and the surroudings of the City of Angels is very nice. I recommend to buy DLC's as well, there are the best cases in my opinion.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												This is one of those game that you must have played at least once. The technology used on the faces is almost in an uncanny valley kinda of thing, but it's still very enjoyable.As a detective in a 1947 L.A., that is pretty detailing and very accurate picture of the city in the past, you're suppose to discover the truth, see behind the lies of the all the suspects and find the one truth. And you gotta do that not just by using evidence, à la Ace Attorney, but also by reading the physiology of the person in front of you (well, it's more the face, and their expression but you get the point).Anyway, is a good game and with an awesome scenario and very interesting features. Definitely worth a try!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I've played some of this game. Not enough that I can give spoilers, but enough that I think I can make a decision. The decision is this: Wasted. Potential. In a summary, I'd say this was an elaborate point and click adventure. That's not a bad thing. If you enjoy your clicky adventures little on the easy side, then no-probs. It's awesome.Story is broken up into separate little "cases", investigating whatever crime of the day. This means even short sessions can be satisfying enough.The only problem is, it's a shoddy console port. Can't ever trust Rockstar in this respect. Look up. It was released Nov 2011. It even looks like Nov 2011. It's not eye-poppingly beautiful either. Maybe some complex (read "stupidly archaic and inefficient") shading, that's it. It runs horribly. Unless you've got a beast of a machine, you shouldn't be playing this game. Just don't. If you do, then go ahead. You won't get the top-notch graphics your machine might be usually chugging out, but you will get a completely unique experience.

Posted: November 27, 2014
												One of the best games I have ever played! LOVED IT9/10---------------------------------Simply brilliant piece of game art. There is not much talk around this gem but LA NOIRE sits up there with those Half lifes, GTAs, Mass Effects or whatever best game you know.It has such a great story, and great ... is GREAT. You are going to feel like you are part of a noire film from the 30's. I freakin loved that. It is so greatly written and it is quite deep so I experieced that feeling "I need to do something else but ♥♥♥♥in hell I need to know who killed that woman" and then spent like another 4 hours playing LA NOIRE.The reason why LA NOIRE is underappreciated is that it is quite a different game. It stands between Tomb Raider, GTA and Sherlock Holmes adventures. You are not gonna shoot everybody you meet and you are not gonna have an opportunity to do that. This game is not about shooting or car chasing... it so complex that you forget you are playing a GAME.Simply loved it. If you love detective style films.. you're gonna love LA NOIRE too. It just feel so real.AMAZING GAME!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The story of "Why I love this awful game..."This game is bad... really bad... You are given this big city in which you are not allowed to do anything. Literally, you can run or drive around, hoping to find crime scene in which you start totally generic and boring missions where you do few thing over and over again... You are trying to catch someone, or fight, or shoot... It's always more or less, the same...Not including gun fights, which are somewhat ok, melee fighting and running is awful... Hand to hand combat looks like two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, trying to hit each-other, and running controls are usually too sensitive, and there are some obstacles that you cannot jump or pass, although they are easily accessible... The worst part of running is that, you usually cannot outrun anyone... You just run until they are cornered in which case you either start a hand-to-hand fight (OMG!!!) or just catch them... And, hand to hand fighting almost always starts when they "hide" behind the corner and wait for you to pass and "surprise" you... Ofcourse, you see them, they are standing there, their hand is there, dangling around the corner, map shows the big dot of your assailant, but you can't do anything, you just need to pass and be hit like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moron...Car driving is also pretty dull... All cars feel pretty much the same, and, given the time period, are pretty slow, but that is understandable...And, the most awful thing is actually trying to follow someone... Be it either on foot or in the car... You just need to be extremely slow, and if they catch you, do it all over again... Ok, that is the point of following, but THAT IS NOT FUN! And this is the game, and if you really need to do it, don't do it 100 times... It's boring...So, when you think that questioning system is nice... It is, really, not... Whenever someone answers your question, you must either say that they are telling the truth, you can doubt their answer or tell that they are lying (in which case you must have the evidence)... In the first half, you can easily tell when someone is not telling the truth, so just doubt it, if you have no evidence... But near the end of the game, there are some questions, when you just can't tell if someone is telling the truth, and you don't have evidence for lying... So... good luck, 50/50 doubt or truth... Well, ok, it's not supposed to be easy, far from that, but I want it to be as near to perfect as possible, and you cannot load conversation again... :/ This is not so important and bad as those problems mentioned above, but could've been better...But... As the title said... Why I LOVE this awful game...Although whole game is really bad in terms of almost any game mechanics... It is one fantastic interactive movie... Voice acting is great, facial expressions are fantastic and story just feels real almost all the time... Especially when you reach the Arson department, when things start to unroll...Characters also feel real, and I really started to understand their motivations, fears and emotions... From that point of view, this game is amazing...So, TLDR; This game should have been a movie... It is an awful game experience, with absolutely amazing actors and story writers... I will recommend it just for that, because when I finished it, I really wanted to "play" it again and see all the characters, their stories and ends...

It is so greatly written and it is quite deep so I experieced that feeling "I need to do something else but ♥♥♥♥in hell I need to know who killed that woman" and then spent like another 4 hours playing LA NOIRE.The reason why LA NOIRE is underappreciated is that it is quite a different game. It stands between Tomb Raider, GTA and Sherlock Holmes adventures. You are not gonna shoot everybody you meet and you are not gonna have an opportunity to do that. This game is not about shooting or car chasing... it so complex that you forget you are playing a GAME.Simply loved it. If you love detective style films.. you're gonna love LA NOIRE too. It just feel so real.AMAZING GAME!

Posted: September 7, 2014
												This game is the odd ball of Rockstar's games. Being a school bully, an ex-outlaw, a psychopath, or a gangster is pretty cool, but have you ever wanted to be a cop? Probably not. A detective? HELL YEAH! The game is pretty much based around crucial information you gather to reach a conclusion that normally ends in gun fire and a trip to the morgue. It has superb voice acting and story. I liked this game so much I spent months kicking down doors and shouting, "L.A.P.D.!" at the top of my lungs and scaring the crap out of everyone. So, point fingers (sometimes) and take names (literally) in this noir-ey detective game.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												L.A. Noire is a fantastic game, and you owe it to yourself to play it... on a console. The PC port is inconsistent and just not worth the hassle if you have this alternative. Hurts my soul to see so many unable to play it. I haven't exactly had any catastrophic issues (unlike others), but I have had to put up with brief launching issues, getting stuck on the title screen, no Cloud support, configuration only on startup, and some slight stuttering even though I exceed the recommended requirements (it wasn't always like that so I'm sure it's fixable, but I haven't tried yet).It's also probably better to play with a controller, partly due to the vibration function making searching for clues (which you do often) easier.Apart from all that... game's damn near a masterpiece. But it's probably best to find it for cheap on a console for a smooth experience. About two hours of my recorded playtime are probably made up of trying to get it to work.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The story of "Why I love this awful game..."This game is bad... really bad... You are given this big city in which you are not allowed to do anything. Literally, you can run or drive around, hoping to find crime scene in which you start totally generic and boring missions where you do few thing over and over again... You are trying to catch someone, or fight, or shoot... It's always more or less, the same...Not including gun fights, which are somewhat ok, melee fighting and running is awful... Hand to hand combat looks like two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, trying to hit each-other, and running controls are usually too sensitive, and there are some obstacles that you cannot jump or pass, although they are easily accessible... The worst part of running is that, you usually cannot outrun anyone... You just run until they are cornered in which case you either start a hand-to-hand fight (OMG!!!) or just catch them... And, hand to hand fighting almost always starts when they "hide" behind the corner and wait for you to pass and "surprise" you... Ofcourse, you see them, they are standing there, their hand is there, dangling around the corner, map shows the big dot of your assailant, but you can't do anything, you just need to pass and be hit like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moron...Car driving is also pretty dull... All cars feel pretty much the same, and, given the time period, are pretty slow, but that is understandable...And, the most awful thing is actually trying to follow someone... Be it either on foot or in the car... You just need to be extremely slow, and if they catch you, do it all over again... Ok, that is the point of following, but THAT IS NOT FUN! And this is the game, and if you really need to do it, don't do it 100 times... It's boring...So, when you think that questioning system is nice... It is, really, not... Whenever someone answers your question, you must either say that they are telling the truth, you can doubt their answer or tell that they are lying (in which case you must have the evidence)... In the first half, you can easily tell when someone is not telling the truth, so just doubt it, if you have no evidence... But near the end of the game, there are some questions, when you just can't tell if someone is telling the truth, and you don't have evidence for lying... So... good luck, 50/50 doubt or truth... Well, ok, it's not supposed to be easy, far from that, but I want it to be as near to perfect as possible, and you cannot load conversation again... :/ This is not so important and bad as those problems mentioned above, but could've been better...But... As the title said... Why I LOVE this awful game...Although whole game is really bad in terms of almost any game mechanics... It is one fantastic interactive movie... Voice acting is great, facial expressions are fantastic and story just feels real almost all the time... Especially when you reach the Arson department, when things start to unroll...Characters also feel real, and I really started to understand their motivations, fears and emotions... From that point of view, this game is amazing...So, TLDR; This game should have been a movie... It is an awful game experience, with absolutely amazing actors and story writers... I will recommend it just for that, because when I finished it, I really wanted to "play" it again and see all the characters, their stories and ends...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Never do you play a game that has no clones, or at least not as good as it. That game is L.A. Noire.Lets look at the Pros, Mixed, and Cons.+ Very fun gameplay. I want to let you know that this game IS a puzzle game, but not as you might expect. You have to find certain clues, not doing any stupid pushing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's very fun and addictive, and wants me to have more of it. Also, there is some shooting and driving involved. However, if you wanted this to be a GTA in 1940, then you will be disappointed. However, you should love it, even if puzzles are not your thing.+ The Sound if FANTASTIC. If I had to rate this game on Sound, it would be a 10.5/10. It's that DAMN GOOD. The soundtrack is great and so 1940s! In fact, I noticed a lot of music from Fallout 3 in here, which also has awesome music. The voice acting is also perfect. It sounded like it could have been real detectives.+ The graphics are pretty dang sweet. The character models, especially their faces, are great. I never noticed bad lip-syncing, unlike most other games. I know there is one issue invloving graphics, but I will later address that in the review.+ A long story. It took me around 24 hours to beat L.A. Noire, and I was not rushing. It's fantastic well it lasts. However, well it lasts.+ Side Missions. They are not that good, but not bad either. It is nice that they added this, so this will not go against the review.Mixed:- 30 FPS capped. This would be a huge con IF it were not for a damn good explanation. So, this game was originally a console game, just like Red Dead Redemption (By the way rockstar, add it onto Steam. I don't care that it's almost 5 years old, I really want to play it) As we know, a lot of console games are locked at 30 FPS (Destiny, Fallout 4, etc.) However, Rockstar noticed there was a huge problem. The lip-syncing on PC was not good at all. They had a total of 4 choices: 1. Let there be bad lip-syncing, removing points from the PC review. 2. Redo THE ENTIRE GAME FOR PC, which could have taken a long time. 3. Make the gameplay 60 FPS, but the faces 30 FPS, possibly making bad lag, as well as confusing most people. 4. Keep it the same, but face there will be only be regular players who will outrage. I think 4 was the safest bet, plus it does not run that bad. At 30 FPS, it is fantastic. However, I still wish there was at least an option.Cons:- The gameplay gets boring a bit fast. After the 30th time of having a shoot out, it gets tiring. However, only the shooting. The interviews and car driving never get old.- This game has glitches, which might not seem bad, until I tell you. Screen-tearing, graphical glitches, and more are only uncommon, not rare.- Very little replay value. There is no second route, like GTA, Fallout, or Elder Scrolls. The next time you play it, it will be the same, which makes it boring. However, there is DLC if you can not get enough, which you would have to be crazy to not be.FINAL VERDICT9/10 L.A. Noire is a fantastic game.At full price it is worth it. On sale, you would have to be crazy not to buy it. I love this game and am praying that Rockstar will make a sequel, improving the games flaws.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Lie Detector: The Video GameStory: 23/25 Gameplay: 20/25 Graphics: 24/25 Sound: 21/25OVERALL: 88/100Well, you're a cop. That's new for this type of game. The story was pretty awesome with a lot of twists I didn't expect. It also shows pretty well how corrupt the police were at that time and how even the best men can do bad things. The gameplay was rather enjoyable. Running, gunning, following traffic laws until you get bored and decide to just drive on the sidewalk even though there's people there. Good stuff. The main thing that sets this title apart is the interrogations where you have to decide whether or nor people are lying. This is really, really, really awful at times. The graphics are amazing and everything appears to be from the proper time period. The sound is equally as good except I notice some reverberation or muffling with some of the voice acting. Awesome game, get it and its DLC.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Don't even think to compare this game to GTA-series. It's very different from some stpd thug-simulator like Watch_Dogs or GTA.Playing this game requires you to roleplay a detective of LAPD. Game is very immersive. City outside the buildings is vivid and alive. Graphics and sounds are very good.Act like a restless and proud detective. Drive retro cars carefully, stop at traffic lights if not in a hurry, embrace the atmosphere of 40's, listen to some flavor music while driving to settle your mind boiling with clues and suspects from current case. Interogate victims and suspects, look carefully and gather clues at crime scenes, don't get shot in firefights and get upperhand at HtH brawls.Take your part in ongoing plot.Interogation logic could'be weird at times, but doesn't break immersion or plot. Cases could be solved faster if you ask right questions and find important evidence upfront. This promotes replayability of the game.Verdict: This game is incredible if played right! Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												It's a quite interesting game with some unique gameplay mechanics and excellent facial animations, but...It is somewhat let down by horrible driving controls that are extremely over sensitive and the cars handle like tanks. All the movements in general have a really weighty, clunky feel to them, and there are many times when performing simple actions, such as climbing over a wall during a chase fail because you initiate it at slightly the wrong angle. Quite frustrating and difficult to get used to.The investigation mechanics are the only thing the game really has going for it, and they are great, but I can't help have the feeling that the game would have been a LOT stronger overall if it focused more on that side of things than on crappy gunplay and drawn out driving sequences.Probably the most irritating thing is that cut scenes are unskippable...So if you restart a case, you have to sit through all of the dialogue, then drive back to the crime scene etc....This is bad in any game, but in a game that relies heavily on story exposition it is pretty unforgivable.It does have an interesting story as well. Probably worth picking up in a sale if you are interested in the premise, but don't expect an action game, or rewarding gunplay, or enjoyable driving experiences.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												L.A Noire is a game about Detective Cole Phelps. It's a game based around solving crimes and arresting (or in most cases, murdering in cold blood) suspects. The game is supposed to be like a real old movie, and it has the framerate to match. Seriously, this game is one of the worst ports I've ever seen. At least Max Payne and GTA 4 worked and kept above half a frame.  I've spent more time trying to fix the bloody FPS then actually playing the thing. I really, REALLY want to recommend this game, but I just can't. Rockstar just doesn't care about PC users. They just care about maximizing profits by giving us the scraps. Games like GTA 4 or L.A Noire are shadows of their console versions. We can't keep letting Rockstar push us around like this. They throw us a bugged, poorly optimized game and then never fix it, despite having all the time in the world to. How come companies like Valve and *shudders* EA can make good PC ports, but Rockstar can't? Because Rockstar is lazy. They're lazy, and they don't care about PC gamers. They make us wait months, sometimes a year or more, for a fantastic game, and they make it unplayable. Rockstar can't keep getting away with this, they just can't. When i was a console gamer, I thought that Rockstar was the best company ever, and that they actually cared about their gamers, but after playing their games on PC, i know that i was mistaken. All in all, L.A Noire would be good, if Rockstar cared enough to put any effort into optimizing it for PC.
