												Fantastic detective game with a very enjoyable story, characters that are interesting, some of the best facial animations yet, a wonderful creation of old school LA and the detective gameplay is a TON of fun. The game is not as open world as say GTA or Watch Dogs, but it goes for story alot more and also has the great detective work, looking for clues, interviewing people about crimes and trying to figure out if they are lying or telling the truth. If you want more story/character driven game pick this up, more linear than most open world games but the fantastic detecitve work, story, characters and animations are top notch. The game is capped at 30fps because of the facial animations they use, which might annoy some people, but once you play you will see it is not a big deal. Didn't have any crashes in the game and no big game breaking bugs. Not perfect but overall I had a blast on this game the two times I beat it. Not the best graphics ever but as I said the animations are fantastic and most everything else is well done.Looking for a fun detective game? Pick this up asap!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I never actually made a proper review for this:The storyline:Brilliant, just brilliant, one of the best storyline based games I've ever played, it's the first that I've been able to replay more than once without being bored at all. It keeps you enthralled in it at every turn, even letting you learn a bit more about Phelps' past in the war. And, if you wanted to take a break from the story, you can drive around town responding to "normal" police calls such as bank robberies, things that aren't detective work, you can also search for rare cars and learn more about the landmarks of Los Angeles in the 1940/50's.The mechanics (Questioning, clue finding): I must say the questioning part of this game is very fun, and the achievement for 100% correct answers is very difficult without a guide, I almost had it and near to the end I screwed up a question and it's safe to say I wasn't very happy at all with myself. The clue finding is fun as well, in some cases it's a bit boring, but with most cases I've found that there's difficulty finding some clues but once you've played the game through at least once, you can remember some of the spots where clues are left.The length: A perfect size in my opinion, it's lengthy but not so lengthy it's ridiculous.Overall rating: 10/10By far one of THE best games I have ever played, I would recommend this to anybody.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												This has got to be one of my favorite games of all time.  The story about Cole and his experiences really drew me into his life and made me care about his character.  The crime scenes are very fun to search around and look for clues, although when you're stumped it can be frustrating at times you can save up intuition to help you out.  The action sequences are very intense and can be challenging at times.  They do offer to allow you to skip them if you're having difficulty but where's the fun in that!  The interrogations are the hardest part of the game for me.  It takes a while to see how the different characters will react and lie to you.  The game is really long but I enjoyed every moment of it.  If you love crime/detective shows this game is a must buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
L.A. Noire is a nice and pure detective game. A must play for any fan of the genre.The place and setting is charming and beautiful, but also dark where you wouldn't look - which is just perfect. The story is great, and every mission feels different and unique.What's most fascinating is the mechanic where you read peoples facial expressions to tell whether they're telling the truth or not. That; together with the clues you find, and the small details you take notice of, and through a careful method of interrogation - makes you able to find the persons that are responsible for the crimes that has taken place.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a must for anyone that likes crime drama or detective noir. This is not GTA. GTA is more like Saints Row which are both great games but not much like this game. LA Noire is more like Mafia or Hard Rain set in the post WW2 era but it plays more like a movie. So the equation: ((HR x 2) + M) may be a start.What the game lacks in action it makes up for in story. It will draw you in -I played it straight through which is unusual for me. While solving the main story mystery there are mini-games/crimes that will show up. Some of the mini crimes tie into the main storyline but are not essential. They are great if you feel the need for some action. There are also cars, badges and film reels scattered about that you can collect in a Free Roam Mode.The only issue I had was the 30FPS cap on the game which can make the game seem choppy at times but it doesn't ruin the game. This is a great game and I am looking foward to the next installment. I recommend buying all the DLC with this game before you play since it adds so much to the story.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game was utterly fantastic at immersing you into the atmosphere of the late 1940's.  Hats off to the developers.  The detective work was fun, but It sort of had its own subtle way of holding your hand, ex. sound cues, a limited amount of hints, giving you the option to skip a sequence if it becomes troubling to you, etc.  However, these things can be turned off in the options menu, giving the hardcore detective wanna-bes no conflict.My single playthrough gave me nearly 30 hours of content, including the dlcs.  I did every side mission (street crimes), but didn't obtain the entire exploration extras; real life landmarks, hidden badges and film reels, and collecting the cars from the time.  I gotta tell you, after finding the hidden vintage cars...That was some serious eye-candy.  If you are into restoration or you are a vintage collector you will probably turn ecstatic.The gameplay was okay but nothing really specialThe graphics were nice, but had the occasional texture pop-ins. Last, but not least, the realistic character face imagery was awesome.  The purpose was using it to decide whether a person was lying or telling the truth.  Some of the reactions were hilariously overblown and gave an obvious sign of deceit, giving the game more of a "helping hand".If you like this period or like detective games, I say make the purchase.  I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2011
												Rockstar has once again made another excellent game.   1940's Los Angeles is the setting in this Detective game that resembles the GTA Series.  Great Graphics and Gameplay.  Ignore the DRM since it is non intrusive, ignore the complaints about fps and graphics, I have no problems running this game at all with a new system.  Game requires more thinking skills than shooting/action.  Facial animations are top notch.  Graphics are true to giving us a realistic 1940 LA Time Period.  This is a highly recommended game!

Noire is mostly an investigative game and for this reason does not have as much action as some players would like it to have. If you are looking for lots of action and shooting in the 40s, L.A. Noire is not the game that you seek. However, if you are in the mood to spend hours looking for objects, analyzing, interrogating suspects and victims and occasionally take part in shootings or car chases, congratulations, you have won the jackpot. Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is freaking great. You take control of a paranoid schizophrenic patient who believes he's a detective in the 1950's. The entire game is a lie, and the people that you "kill" in-game are just hallucinations, as you actually are running around downtown L.A. like an absolute madman in "real life". I feel bad because there's this one part where you need to kill a little girl to obtain the secret information from the FBI overlords, and if you think that she's "lying" about her story, you kill her and take her papers. The reality in that is that you kill her in real life, and then take her kindergarten schoolwork. It's a twisted game that will leave your computer full of kum when you're done with it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game was utterly fantastic at immersing you into the atmosphere of the late 1940's.  Hats off to the developers.  The detective work was fun, but It sort of had its own subtle way of holding your hand, ex. sound cues, a limited amount of hints, giving you the option to skip a sequence if it becomes troubling to you, etc.  However, these things can be turned off in the options menu, giving the hardcore detective wanna-bes no conflict.My single playthrough gave me nearly 30 hours of content, including the dlcs.  I did every side mission (street crimes), but didn't obtain the entire exploration extras; real life landmarks, hidden badges and film reels, and collecting the cars from the time.  I gotta tell you, after finding the hidden vintage cars...That was some serious eye-candy.  If you are into restoration or you are a vintage collector you will probably turn ecstatic.The gameplay was okay but nothing really specialThe graphics were nice, but had the occasional texture pop-ins. Last, but not least, the realistic character face imagery was awesome.  The purpose was using it to decide whether a person was lying or telling the truth.  Some of the reactions were hilariously overblown and gave an obvious sign of deceit, giving the game more of a "helping hand".If you like this period or like detective games, I say make the purchase.  I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												What an Incredible game! One of the deepest and richest storylines for any game I have every played. Not only do you feel good after solving a crime, but you actually feel like you are in the game with Cole Phelps and his partner. The searching of evidence is extremely easy with music and sound effects making almost impossible to miss a clue, but remember, not every clue is necesasary to the case! The driving is absolute perfection but I felt that at times, the car felt terrible for how far in the story you were (not a spoiler). I feel once you progress further, the car you drive should get better. The action mechanics are awesome, chasing down a baddy and tackling him to the ground is a satisfying thing. Though the shooting mechanics of the game take time to adjust to and some enemies take at least a full magazine of ammo to kill if it is not a headshot, it is easy to adjust to. The interview process of the game is extremely detailed, where a simple swallowing of saliva, could show the persons doubt. Make sure you look at your notebook and check every piece of evidence to make sure the accused isnt lying. This game has some small flaws, but are easily overlooked and one of the best police/detective games ever! 9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												L.A. Noire took me really long to complete with all the DLC, around 40 hours and it was hell of a run. This game was filled with amazing detective based mystery cases and a very distinct story line.The action was fun and amusing, chasing down people on foot and inside the vehicles. The gun action was also basic and easy to understand , from taking cover to blind firing your ememies or even just straight ramboing it.Taking the vehicles back to 1940's was a very neat idea, driving old cars was fun for a change wrather than the ones in the GTA series. They are over 90 vehicles and I only found half of them.The map is huge and there's just so much to explore.The main factor of the game is the motion capture of the face, the facial expressions were probably the most detailed and realistic I've ever seen in a game. When it comes to asking questions, i'm sure many people will get stumped or unsure on either choosing the "truth", "doubt" or a "lie"I will give this game 9/10 just because the ending wasn't how I wanted it to end.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
What it is aboutL.A. Noire is an action-adventure crime game played from a third-person perspective. There are cases to be completed, such as investigations for murder, to progress through the story. Inbetween all the cases, the player can roam in the 1940's Los Angeles to complete in optional activities, which appear through the police radio. Combined together, one can spend many hours to complete the game.The game is known for MotionScan, whereby the actors portraying the game's characters were recorded by 32 surrounding cameras to capture facial expressions from every angle. This technology is one of the important things in the game, as you have to guess if the witnesses you are interrogating are lying or telling the truth.L.A. Noire is capped to 30 frames per second (MotionScan is the reason for this), and the graphics, for a game being released in 2011, look kinda plastic and lifeless (applied to objects that are not alive). MotionScan does make the game feel a little alive, although nowaday's techniques let MotionScan stand in the corner for being the Ugly Betty.The available DLC expands the base game for a few more missions, giving it a little more time to survive the time you are playing it :-)In a nutshellL.A. Noire definitely set a new level for reality in 2011. Being beautiful, brutal, difficult and action-packed in one, this game is a must-play for every player that likes AAA-titles from previous years and for players searching for a temporary addiction!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a must for anyone that likes crime drama or detective noir. This is not GTA. GTA is more like Saints Row which are both great games but not much like this game. LA Noire is more like Mafia or Hard Rain set in the post WW2 era but it plays more like a movie. So the equation: ((HR x 2) + M) may be a start.What the game lacks in action it makes up for in story. It will draw you in -I played it straight through which is unusual for me. While solving the main story mystery there are mini-games/crimes that will show up. Some of the mini crimes tie into the main storyline but are not essential. They are great if you feel the need for some action. There are also cars, badges and film reels scattered about that you can collect in a Free Roam Mode.The only issue I had was the 30FPS cap on the game which can make the game seem choppy at times but it doesn't ruin the game. This is a great game and I am looking foward to the next installment. I recommend buying all the DLC with this game before you play since it adds so much to the story.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I've only played through the first campaign and that's a story in itself.  It is a cinematic game akin to Mafia 2 which was an incredible experience.  The fault of this game is the confusing interrogation of the suspects and witnesses.  The whole lie/truth/neutral stance really makes no sense to me whatsoever because whatever I click, Cole's response is never what I expect him to say.  If I knew what he was going to say before I click it would feel so much better and probably give me more correct run throughs.  I also failed to pay attention to some of the characters from the larger story arc but that's my fault so the story campaign was a little confusing.On the bright side, the shooting and fight mechanics are awesome.  Driving around LA is great fun.  The world looks and sounds brilliant though it does run a little slow on my computer.  The dialogue and character interactions are top notch with excellent voice acting.  The facial expressions are a shining highlight and it makes those interrogations special even if I don't choose the correct option.  Don't get too wrapped up in the interrogations, maybe it's all my fault, but the rest of the game is good enough, especially for 5 bucks on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												I fully recommend this game, for those who like crime-solving games, games with mystery or suspense, or for those who enjoy the '50s noire detective/gangster theme. I myself enjoy all three of these elements, and so find this game incredibly addictive and enjoyable. The game is designed so that mistakes can be made during clue collecting (ie, you miss a clue) and interrogation (ie, you fail to call out a witness on a lie, or accept a lie as the truth) without a failure-state; it simply makes it more difficult to come to the correct conclusion at the end of the case, or it leads to a decreased score on the case. Each case has a very powerful film noire feel, and the cases are often based on historical cases from the 50s. You play Detective Phelps, an WW2 veteran who has turned to detective work for the LA police, and you interact with diverse, interesting characters, all with great voice acting and motion capture. To sum it up, there's not really any other game like this one, so if it appeals to you, get it! If you get it today, it's on sale for 4.99, but if you get the complete edition for an extra 10 cents, it comes with a couple extra cases and other DLC. What a steal!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I'm surprised at the relatively low scores here. I think this game is fantastic. It is what Mafia II was supposed to be on the storytelling/narration front. I'm normally very sensitive to shoddy ports, but this port doesn't seem to have consolitis at all in my opinion. I never played the console version so I can't compare. It certainly seems to control better than, say, Dead Space 1 or 2 did on the PC. The acting, story, and facial animations are world-class, and the facial animations really do raise the emotion of the scenes...you can see people's Adam's apples move when they gulp, for crying out loud! Doesn't sound very important except when you consider that much of what you're doing in the game is trying to find out if people are lying or not. I would say this is a GOTY contender if it weren't for the fact that Arkham City is about to come out, which I assume will dominate. My only gripe is that the cars handle way too well for cars of that era. They're very 'sticky'. It has worked perfectly 'out of the box' for me (purchased on Steam), no stability issues at all, except the game crashes whenever I quit. Obviously that is a non-issue, doesn't affect the experience at all because it only happens when I quit. I also don't have any of the frame-rate issues that some are reporting.

L.A. Noire is a nice and pure detective game. A must play for any fan of the genre.The place and setting is charming and beautiful, but also dark where you wouldn't look - which is just perfect. The story is great, and every mission feels different and unique.What's most fascinating is the mechanic where you read peoples facial expressions to tell whether they're telling the truth or not. That; together with the clues you find, and the small details you take notice of, and through a careful method of interrogation - makes you able to find the persons that are responsible for the crimes that has taken place.

												This game is freaking great. You take control of a paranoid schizophrenic patient who believes he's a detective in the 1950's. The entire game is a lie, and the people that you "kill" in-game are just hallucinations, as you actually are running around downtown L.A. like an absolute madman in "real life". I feel bad because there's this one part where you need to kill a little girl to obtain the secret information from the FBI overlords, and if you think that she's "lying" about her story, you kill her and take her papers. The reality in that is that you kill her in real life, and then take her kindergarten schoolwork. It's a twisted game that will leave your computer full of kum when you're done with it.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												L.A. Noire took me really long to complete with all the DLC, around 40 hours and it was hell of a run. This game was filled with amazing detective based mystery cases and a very distinct story line.The action was fun and amusing, chasing down people on foot and inside the vehicles. The gun action was also basic and easy to understand , from taking cover to blind firing your ememies or even just straight ramboing it.Taking the vehicles back to 1940's was a very neat idea, driving old cars was fun for a change wrather than the ones in the GTA series. They are over 90 vehicles and I only found half of them.The map is huge and there's just so much to explore.The main factor of the game is the motion capture of the face, the facial expressions were probably the most detailed and realistic I've ever seen in a game. When it comes to asking questions, i'm sure many people will get stumped or unsure on either choosing the "truth", "doubt" or a "lie"I will give this game 9/10 just because the ending wasn't how I wanted it to end.

A very recommended game for those who enjoy the action, adventure, and mystery genre. [9.5/10]

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												While visually impeccable, the game plays like your favourite 50s detective flick (I'm looking at L.A Condfidential.) There may be a few performance issues (it is a port) but nothing game breaking.The story is superb (mostly) and there are a few plot twists that one would never have seen coming. The shooting is as basic as you can get but feels very refreshing from GTA or Call of Duty. People go down in 1-3 hits, like they should. Driving is a little 'iffy' and the cars a sometimes hard to handle; you'll find yourself crashing quite a bit. L.A Noire is flawless in most ways (gameplay and storywise), and I'm about to enter my 4th playthrough. While there is not really 'free roam' (there is, but it's only to replay the emergency calls you get in the story) the 15+ hours of story and interrogations should keep you perfectly entertained. I still don't get how they did the faces, they look amazing. For £4.99 on sale, you are duty bound to get this and play it.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
L.A. Noire is a nice and pure detective game. A must play for any fan of the genre.The place and setting is charming and beautiful, but also dark where you wouldn't look - which is just perfect. The story is great, and every mission feels different and unique.What's most fascinating is the mechanic where you read peoples facial expressions to tell whether they're telling the truth or not. That; together with the clues you find, and the small details you take notice of, and through a careful method of interrogation - makes you able to find the persons that are responsible for the crimes that has taken place.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												This game is a must for anyone that likes crime drama or detective noir. This is not GTA. GTA is more like Saints Row which are both great games but not much like this game. LA Noire is more like Mafia or Hard Rain set in the post WW2 era but it plays more like a movie. So the equation: ((HR x 2) + M) may be a start.What the game lacks in action it makes up for in story. It will draw you in -I played it straight through which is unusual for me. While solving the main story mystery there are mini-games/crimes that will show up. Some of the mini crimes tie into the main storyline but are not essential. They are great if you feel the need for some action. There are also cars, badges and film reels scattered about that you can collect in a Free Roam Mode.The only issue I had was the 30FPS cap on the game which can make the game seem choppy at times but it doesn't ruin the game. This is a great game and I am looking foward to the next installment. I recommend buying all the DLC with this game before you play since it adds so much to the story.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												L.A. Noire is reminiscent of a lot of us. We’re decent people sure, but we’ve become bloated with wasted potential. Maybe I should go ahead and compare Noire to a high-end escort. Sure, her parents are disappointed but she’s certainly bringing something different and enjoyable to your evening. You should definitely play L.A. Noire but like me you may walk away feeling that it could have been much more. There are also a slew of problems both technical and performance but the experience is fresh, invigorating, and will keep you playing through the night.L.A. Noire is heavily influenced by film noire. If you despise that genre maybe this game isn’t for you. The story is smothered in a thick layer of atmosphere with character personalities practically picked from the classics. Sure, some of the characters are definitely cliché but this plays to the games benefit. It’s supposed to be reminiscent of film noire and it does a damn good job at it. I won’t go too much into the characters or story because that’s something players should experience firsthand for themselves. It’s good and you should play it. The story can be described as paced and methodical. Unlike other Rockstar titles you won’t be blowing through waves of armed baddies every moment of the day. You’ll play as Cole Phelps, a veteran of World War II turned by-the-book detective in late 1940s Los Angeles. Because you’re a detective you’ll spend less time in shootouts and more time investigating crimes, interviewing suspects, and driving around in style. The investigations continue to introduce diversity in their story and characters but the central process generally stays the same. You’ll interrogate witnesses, chase down suspects, and sort through crime scenes for clues. The most prominent game mechanic is of course the interrogation mechanic in whom you judge whether your witness/suspect you believe the person you are interrogating is telling the truth, you doubt them, or they are lying. This is where MotionScan shines the brightest. The depth of the character’s expressing is fantastic and you’ll have to use those expressions to figure out whether they are telling the truth or not. At times dissecting the truth from the lies is rather difficult but most of the time it wasn’t too hard. A lot of the character’s tells are regurgitated over and over and the facial expressions are generally overdramatized. Regardless it is a ton of fun to interrogate someone to get one step closer to solving the case. Be careful though, there are consequences to doing a bad job. Outside of the main storyline there is little to take part in. There are side missions called “street crimes.” Unlike the campaign they are more or less regurgitated and not at all worthwhile in my opinion. You can also drive around and find all of the landmarks or try to find hidden cars. For such a large world there really isn’t a whole lot to do with it. You're free to explore the world but there is simply not a whole lot to see or do. It's like a fantastic themepark tucked away in some beautiful place but with only one ride.I first played L.A. Noire all the way back in 2011 on the Xbox 360. I fancied another play and decided to snag a copy for the PC. The unfortunate reality is that the PC version doesn’t offer much more than the Xbox 360. The game is locked to 30fps and suffers from some of the performance issues that the Xbox 360 suffered. I feel as if the game must have been rushed for its PC release. I suffered the occasional stuttering and even tearing despite have vsync engaged and more than enough hardware to handle the stress. The draw distances appear to be as short as they were on the consoles. I feel as if the game could have been made to better utilize the PCs superior power. Unfortunately it appears that this wasn’t the case. While the game is certainly playable these performance issues can be distracting and I feel as if they shouldn’t have ever been there in the first place. The most glaring annoyance is the FPS limit which may be more than a mild annoyance to PC gamers. Now, I have heard that the FPS limit was for the benefit of the facial animations. Apparently there is a FPS unlocker created by someone but I have yet to see how the facial animations work at higher frame rates.I decided to play the entirety of the campaign using my gamepad. Like Grand Theft Auto the game, in my opinion, is much better enjoyed with it. The driving was on-par or slightly above that of GTA IV. The combat mechanics feel unrefined and clunky, a problem that was equally persistent in bothering me on the 360. Fortunately combat is not the focus of L.A. Noire. I would consider the controls functional but not superb. The audio including the voice acting and background audio are no less than top notch. While you’re driving you are treated to period music and commercials. The voice acting and music score are engaging and enjoyable. Everything works seamlessly together to make you feel as if you’re really a detective in 1940s L.A. The recreation late 1940s L.A. is impressive. It is evident that a staggering amount of attention to detail was applied in its accurate depiction of the time. This applies to everything from the clothes, cars, hairstyles, architecture, and interiors. The game used a technology called MotionScan to record and transplants real actor’s facial expressions into the game. Overall this brings a truly unique cinematic experience and supports the games interrogation mechanic. It is a thrill to see so much detail in a game character and brings the world and experience alive. MotionScan could certainly use some polish and refinement but the implementation of the technology is definitely a good one. A handful of character animations are strange wonky. I wish some more attention could have also been applied to the more action-packed cinematic cut scenes. I know the game was made all the way back in 2011 but there’s a few that look downright silly. The game does a fantastic job of getting you absorbed in the world but there’s moments when an unpolished visual moments pulls you straight out. There exists the occasional discrepancy between textures. Some texture is lovely such as those for cars and interiors. On the other hand the gun textures (and reloading animations) are poor at best. Despite flaws L.A. Noire is an enjoyable and enthralling adventure. The game introduces new game mechanics, a story, and an environment that truly sets the game apart from the rest of the pack. It doesn’t matter that it came out three years ago, give this game a play. 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												L.A NoirePositives:+ A very cool and well thought-out detective thriller set in 1940's California, U.S.A. Playing as Coles Phelps you investigate homicides, thefts, drug trafficking and fraud, identifying crime scene clues and speaking to witnesses to gather evidence.+ A really nice feature of this game is the facial expressions used by characters. A lot of effort was put into this by the developers. After carefully observing how a person of interest behaves or talks, you can doubt what they are saying, judge whether they are lying, or believe them. If you're successful, you'll squeeze more information out of them leading to additional avenues in the case. This is good because it rewards the player for engaging in the game and playing it properly.+ Nice shootouts with several different types of weapons, although confrontations aren't that frequent. Use tommy guns, pistols or shotguns to take down foes. There's 40 street crimes to complete separate from cases.+ An intriguing storyline of crime, love and flashbacks of Cole Phelps life in the Marines during World War II. The ending is one you won't really expect. Really enjoyed it.+ Around 40-50 hours of gameplay with all DLC, trying to do your best on every case.+ Graphics are decent.Negatives:- The graphical quality of the game world could be improved. As it stands it still looks fine, but stunning visuals really do add to immersion.Overall Score: 9/10It's hard to fault L.A Noire. This game kept me entertained and had lots of playtime available, the DLC adds some epic firefights and the story was great. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: January 15
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!!! At least, not on PC.I had seen footage of this game before and was excited to give it a shot when it went on sale.  So, I picked it up and tried it out.  The first thing i noticed was that the game ran at low performance.  I was surprised, of course, given that I was running it on a GTX 1070 and getting 30 fps or less.  So, I googled the issue, and I learned that the game was locked at 30 fps-which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  I set about finding a fix.  I came across widescreenfix, and started using it.  After about an hour of gameplay I came to the conclusion that the game was simply unplayable.  While, yes, my framerate went up, it only went up to 44 or so at most and even then the input was laggy and the game was extremely difficult to control.  At that point I gave up, and returned the game.All that aside my one hour stint in L.A. Noire was very entertaining.  Even through the pain of playing it it was clear that the game has a lot going for it.  The game doesn't place you in a truely open world, instead setting up the gameplay as a series of episodes, like from a detective show from the '60s or something.  It's difficult for me to elaborate further as I didn't get to play much of the game, but I really wish I could have.  While light, the combat worked well enough and its clear that the main focus of the game is on the detective side of things.Yes, you should buy this game, just maybe not on PC.And Rockstar, fix your ♥♥♥♥ing game.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												LA Noire is exactly as advertised, a dark gritty noire story. And thats great, this is why i love Rockstar, they never fail to impress. LA Noire puts you in the shoes of Cole Phelps, a beat cop who is working way up to detective. Now beat is pretty much the tutorial section, after this you earn Traffic detective. Now the story in this game is phenomenal, or at least each story (for the most part). Each desk you get a different partner, my favorite being Stefan. There is one flaw i have though with the partners though, they all have the same progression and personality. Like at first they dont really care for you too much but after your first case in each desk they think your the bees knees. The atmosphere in this game is great too, i love the 1940s feel and aesthetic. But theres also a flaw with the world in this game too, its kind of linear, what i mean by this is theres nothing to do outside of the main missions. They give you the option for free roam after you complete a desk but it kind of sucks, the characters in these free roam missions are cool but besides that the missions can get kind of repetitive. Theres no restraunts to go to, no movies to see, no bowling alleys, ♥♥♥♥ theres not even a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ radio. But besides that i really dont have any flaws with the game world. Now with the main missions themselves, there pretty good, the best desks are Vice and Homicide. Each desk is different, this game even takes you into the investagation of the BLACK DAHLIA MURDERS!!! its pretty cool stuff. Now the funnest part of the missions in my honest opinion is questioning, but damn it can be frustrating too. So thats my review for LA Noire, i know it was long.LA Noire9/10Would doubt again

												At a time when narrative in gaming is constantly trying to find its own identity, L.A. Noire does a fine job of giving you the right amount of control amongst the very well acted cutscenes. The facial recognition tech hasn't been attempted since, and for good reason. L.A. Noire is constantly ranked amongst the most expensive games ever made - and it shows in the quality of the facial animations. I will say, though, that in large crowd shots, it is quite easy to tell which characters have the facial motion capture and which don't - and the ones that don't (i.e. equivalent of 'extras' in movies and television) do not look very good.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I've been looking for a game with good story for quite a while. After playing great titles like Fahrenheit, Mafia, and Alan Wake I wanted to touch up to those. L.A. Noire, even though an underdog in my book (was able to get it long time ago but decided not to due to bad optimalization for PC and some negative expectations from initial experience when trying it out). Despite all that I got it on the summer sale for 5 euro and it proved to be a great buy.Each case had a different original flavor to it, and I found myself feeling vibes of L.A. Confidential, True Detective (on Homicide department). I spent 24 hours on this game during 1 playthrough, and you could spend even more, if you completed all of the side-missions where you battle street crime. This game may be linear, but it sacrifices its freedom for great story-telling and immersion. So if you're into detective stuff (actual detective stuff, using wits, and intuition) then buy this game.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I've bought this game for the PS3 first and was caught up in its nice story and gameplay.Bought it again for the PC because of DLC's and coz it was on sale at the time being. Money well-spent, imo.You are Detective Cole Phelps who is working for the LAPD. Your job is to solve crimes by bringing in witnesses, suspects etc. You follow leads and tracks you find at the crime scenes and use them to arrest the criminals. What I like really much is the fact that the emotions and gestures etc of the characters you talk to are also very important to find out if somebody is lying to you or telling the truth. Motion capturing ftw.Can only recommend this game. It also has very nice plot twists and I just love the time it takes places in. (I'm in love with that era, so my review might be a little biased :P)7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												L.A. Noire is reminiscent of a lot of us. We’re decent people sure, but we’ve become bloated with wasted potential. Maybe I should go ahead and compare Noire to a high-end escort. Sure, her parents are disappointed but she’s certainly bringing something different and enjoyable to your evening. You should definitely play L.A. Noire but like me you may walk away feeling that it could have been much more. There are also a slew of problems both technical and performance but the experience is fresh, invigorating, and will keep you playing through the night.L.A. Noire is heavily influenced by film noire. If you despise that genre maybe this game isn’t for you. The story is smothered in a thick layer of atmosphere with character personalities practically picked from the classics. Sure, some of the characters are definitely cliché but this plays to the games benefit. It’s supposed to be reminiscent of film noire and it does a damn good job at it. I won’t go too much into the characters or story because that’s something players should experience firsthand for themselves. It’s good and you should play it. The story can be described as paced and methodical. Unlike other Rockstar titles you won’t be blowing through waves of armed baddies every moment of the day. You’ll play as Cole Phelps, a veteran of World War II turned by-the-book detective in late 1940s Los Angeles. Because you’re a detective you’ll spend less time in shootouts and more time investigating crimes, interviewing suspects, and driving around in style. The investigations continue to introduce diversity in their story and characters but the central process generally stays the same. You’ll interrogate witnesses, chase down suspects, and sort through crime scenes for clues. The most prominent game mechanic is of course the interrogation mechanic in whom you judge whether your witness/suspect you believe the person you are interrogating is telling the truth, you doubt them, or they are lying. This is where MotionScan shines the brightest. The depth of the character’s expressing is fantastic and you’ll have to use those expressions to figure out whether they are telling the truth or not. At times dissecting the truth from the lies is rather difficult but most of the time it wasn’t too hard. A lot of the character’s tells are regurgitated over and over and the facial expressions are generally overdramatized. Regardless it is a ton of fun to interrogate someone to get one step closer to solving the case. Be careful though, there are consequences to doing a bad job. Outside of the main storyline there is little to take part in. There are side missions called “street crimes.” Unlike the campaign they are more or less regurgitated and not at all worthwhile in my opinion. You can also drive around and find all of the landmarks or try to find hidden cars. For such a large world there really isn’t a whole lot to do with it. You're free to explore the world but there is simply not a whole lot to see or do. It's like a fantastic themepark tucked away in some beautiful place but with only one ride.I first played L.A. Noire all the way back in 2011 on the Xbox 360. I fancied another play and decided to snag a copy for the PC. The unfortunate reality is that the PC version doesn’t offer much more than the Xbox 360. The game is locked to 30fps and suffers from some of the performance issues that the Xbox 360 suffered. I feel as if the game must have been rushed for its PC release. I suffered the occasional stuttering and even tearing despite have vsync engaged and more than enough hardware to handle the stress. The draw distances appear to be as short as they were on the consoles. I feel as if the game could have been made to better utilize the PCs superior power. Unfortunately it appears that this wasn’t the case. While the game is certainly playable these performance issues can be distracting and I feel as if they shouldn’t have ever been there in the first place. The most glaring annoyance is the FPS limit which may be more than a mild annoyance to PC gamers. Now, I have heard that the FPS limit was for the benefit of the facial animations. Apparently there is a FPS unlocker created by someone but I have yet to see how the facial animations work at higher frame rates.I decided to play the entirety of the campaign using my gamepad. Like Grand Theft Auto the game, in my opinion, is much better enjoyed with it. The driving was on-par or slightly above that of GTA IV. The combat mechanics feel unrefined and clunky, a problem that was equally persistent in bothering me on the 360. Fortunately combat is not the focus of L.A. Noire. I would consider the controls functional but not superb. The audio including the voice acting and background audio are no less than top notch. While you’re driving you are treated to period music and commercials. The voice acting and music score are engaging and enjoyable. Everything works seamlessly together to make you feel as if you’re really a detective in 1940s L.A. The recreation late 1940s L.A. is impressive. It is evident that a staggering amount of attention to detail was applied in its accurate depiction of the time. This applies to everything from the clothes, cars, hairstyles, architecture, and interiors. The game used a technology called MotionScan to record and transplants real actor’s facial expressions into the game. Overall this brings a truly unique cinematic experience and supports the games interrogation mechanic. It is a thrill to see so much detail in a game character and brings the world and experience alive. MotionScan could certainly use some polish and refinement but the implementation of the technology is definitely a good one. A handful of character animations are strange wonky. I wish some more attention could have also been applied to the more action-packed cinematic cut scenes. I know the game was made all the way back in 2011 but there’s a few that look downright silly. The game does a fantastic job of getting you absorbed in the world but there’s moments when an unpolished visual moments pulls you straight out. There exists the occasional discrepancy between textures. Some texture is lovely such as those for cars and interiors. On the other hand the gun textures (and reloading animations) are poor at best. Despite flaws L.A. Noire is an enjoyable and enthralling adventure. The game introduces new game mechanics, a story, and an environment that truly sets the game apart from the rest of the pack. It doesn’t matter that it came out three years ago, give this game a play. 8/10.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												The game can be split up to 5 parts according to cases. Patrol, Traffic, Homicide, Vice and Arson. Patrol cases are like tutorial so there is nothing to add much. Traffic cases are about small time issues like hit-and-runs, stolen goods, injuries or fatalities. It is good for a start up and it let's you to warm up to game. Homicide is about murder as you can foresee. From my opinion it is the best part of the game (All murders are related to real cases). Vice is the hardest ever you can get. It contains drug traffic, mafia and some other serious♥♥♥♥♥♥ The last one, arson is about burned houses. Not much to add.So let's look at the criteria of this game:Music: Nice action and investigation musics. When you get close to a investigation area.Plot: Really realistic plot. You get Cole's, who the main protagonist by the way, background info and as you continue you get into Cole's deep feelings. As the game starts to end, whole plot is completing to connect to each other.Cases: Though i finished the game, i was really really bored at Arson. As the game continues nearly everything stays as the same, except plot. You can't get anything new as you play further so it may get boring. Same evidence tactics and same interrogation methods etc.Interrogation: Interrogation is the most important thing. It is as important as collecting avidence. It opens so much options early on in the case. While interrogating, you need to look closely in the faces of charachters to understand whether they are lying or not. After you conclude that charachter is lying, you need an evidence to pressure him/her. As you continue it gets harder to understand from faces. Afterall interrogation system/mechanic is really good.However it is too ♥♥♥♥in hard to connect to game as it requires Rockstar Social Club♥♥♥♥♥♥ I hate this system as much as UplayLauncher. Rockstar really gets ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about it. My only negative comment is about this.So if you like playing investigation games and hate Rockstar, 8/10 i would recommend you to buy when it's in sale.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												I got this game on sale with all the dlc for some ridiculously low price. I've heard good things, and the concept intrigued me, so that's the ultimate reason I pulled the trigger. I haven't played any of Rockstar's games in years, and I've never really been a big fan, so I wasn't too sure I would even like it. My favorite games tend to be first person, stealth, shooting / rpg type games like Fallout 3 / NV, Oblivion / Skyrim, Deus Ex, and Dishonored.With all that said, I would absolutely recommend this game to anybodywho has glanced at this game and been the least bit intrigued. It has something in it for everybody. Good dialogue and voice acting, interesting story, challenging action sequences, driving, shooting, invistigating. There's a lot going on here, and the game does a great job of bringing it all together.I'm also a sucker for the past and history, so I loved that the game is set in post WWII Los Angeles. The clothing, architecture, technology is all from that era, so for me that was really cool and also helped with immersion into the storyline.There is also a surprising amount of content. The story is long, and there are a ton of side missions you can do. I stayed away from the side missions because I was more interested in the story, which is unusual for me. I tend to do most or all side missions in games before tackling the story. Again, I feel like that says a lot about the immersion here. I was genuinely caught up in the storyline, and wanted to see what would happen next.With that said, my only major gripe about the game is that it gets really repetitive. They threw a couple new mechanics in here and there to keep you on your toes a bit, but for the most part, you end up doing the same kinds of things over and over aaand over. Another thing is that there don't seem to be too many (if any) real consequences for doing things badly, or straight up wrong. When interrogating, for example, it doesn't really seem like it matters if you get no answers or all of the answers.Even with those gripes though, this game was great, and I'm glad I gave it a shot. There's so much content here. I feel like I way more than got my money's worth even half way through the game. Like I said, if this game intrigues you at all, you should definitely give it a try, especially if you get it on discount.

												Had a hard time deciding if i would give this a thumbs up or thumbs down. but in the end i think i'll settle with a thumbs down. the game is a typical triple-A console release. with all good and bad that follows. i.e it has very good acting, writing, design and overall production quality. but it also have that typical handholdy wedonttrustourplayers kind of gameplay to it, which is a really bad approach to have in a game that seeks to be a clever and modern point and click-esque game. also, the game is also too f*cking long and the pacing is off. it was a blast to play for about 18 hours, after that it made me go "does this game ever end?!" and ended up being a drag, but it wasn't so painful that i wanted to quit though. another thing that is worth mentioning is that the game is locked at 30 fps and the pc port is sub-par. had to run it in singlethreaded mode to get rid of most of the performance issues and i have a pretty powerful pc all things considering.

Posted: August 14, 2016
												LA Noire is exactly as advertised, a dark gritty noire story. And thats great, this is why i love Rockstar, they never fail to impress. LA Noire puts you in the shoes of Cole Phelps, a beat cop who is working way up to detective. Now beat is pretty much the tutorial section, after this you earn Traffic detective. Now the story in this game is phenomenal, or at least each story (for the most part). Each desk you get a different partner, my favorite being Stefan. There is one flaw i have though with the partners though, they all have the same progression and personality. Like at first they dont really care for you too much but after your first case in each desk they think your the bees knees. The atmosphere in this game is great too, i love the 1940s feel and aesthetic. But theres also a flaw with the world in this game too, its kind of linear, what i mean by this is theres nothing to do outside of the main missions. They give you the option for free roam after you complete a desk but it kind of sucks, the characters in these free roam missions are cool but besides that the missions can get kind of repetitive. Theres no restraunts to go to, no movies to see, no bowling alleys, ♥♥♥♥ theres not even a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ radio. But besides that i really dont have any flaws with the game world. Now with the main missions themselves, there pretty good, the best desks are Vice and Homicide. Each desk is different, this game even takes you into the investagation of the BLACK DAHLIA MURDERS!!! its pretty cool stuff. Now the funnest part of the missions in my honest opinion is questioning, but damn it can be frustrating too. So thats my review for LA Noire, i know it was long.LA Noire9/10Would doubt again

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												The game is a bit strange, to be honest. Not just because it’s not the classic “runny gunny” variant of Rockstar games, but mostly because I have solved 4 or 5 cases and it feels like I haven’t really done much. I’ve unlocked outfits that look like repaints of the same basic thing (Watch_Dogs would later come to have the same exact problem), and I seem to be unlocking intuition points I don’t really need since I can just Shift+Tab to a guide that tells me when people are lieing.I don’t want to sound like a mouthbreather who can’t handle not having violence in my face every ten minutes. But after 3 hours and two gunfights, I feel there should be a /little/ more peppered around.My very first case I failed immediately when the perp ran away. I went to fire at him, just once, and actually managed to hit him in the leg. Instant “You failed” screen, “Man got injured” it said. No kidding? He was fleeing.So I find a street crime a little later, THINKING I shouldn’t be shooting the masked perp with a firing gun. Since I couldn’t figure out how to melee with my gun drawn, I just tried rushing him. Mission failed. “Officer down” it says.Christ, make up your mind.Another street crime was a more clearcut gunfight, which was enjoyable but the game CLEARLY didn’t emphasize the gunplay. The controls were a bit sluggish as my dude slowly gets out of cover and slowly figures out that I’m holding the shift button to sprint to a different piece of cover. I haven’t died yet, but I have taken a few shots because Cole won’t move his friggn’♥♥♥♥♥I will admit, first impressions were pretty decent. They’ve taken a slight (but only slight) dip due to the clunky movement. I also don’t feel like an “open ended” game is the right platform for the investigative style it’s going for. Indeed, it’s hardly open ended at all. I can’t really “stop” any investigation and wander. Sometimes my police car gets a call that I can generally divert and deal with, but there’s no ‘wandering’ available. I’m wondering why the world is this large when all I can do is “Investigation” and “shoot some Mexicans over here”. Even clothing is changed via the menu, no shopping to be done.Is a more open world “unlocked” later? Rockstar is sometimes fond of that. If so, that’s fair. I’ll keep playing it (though mostly in one-hour chunks so my computer doesn’t explode).

												L.A. Noire involves breath taking graphics and structure of the story so that as you play it, you have to constantly remind yourself to use the controller because you drift away thinking you are watching a 1940's detective movie. The facial expressions (animated by real actors and 32 different cameras to get every possible angle of the expression) , will blow you away. A great mix of clue finding, interrogating, and action, make this a game that I for one, had trouble stepping away from. The story line is intense and awe inspiring. A very recommended game for those who enjoy the action, adventure, and mystery genre.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												In L.A. Noire you play as Cole Phelps and begin with him joining the LAPD. During your game he rises through the ranks in the force. However don’t expect to see Cole react to his amazing progress in the police with anything other than a blank expression. This is indicative of on overarching problem the game has. While the story tries to make Phelps a compelling character there is a glaring disconnect between him and the player. You never see his family despite their existence being important to the plot. While you see moments from his time at war they never feel overly impactful. I didn’t care about Phelps which in a story like this is a deal breaker.The game focuses far too much on the technology that went into making it. While the facial recognition technology used is amazing that isn’t what makes a good game. The facial expressions are often laughably over the top (which is understandable when you think that it is actors being told to ‘look like your lying’) and destroy the immersive experience the game is trying to present. It often ends up with characters being too far inside the uncanny valley for them to be truly relatable However the game world is beautiful and represents 1940s Los Angeles very well. It’s obvious that a lot of time and research went into creating this world. It is full of landmarks, street crime and collectables to find. Yet the game lets you skip every driving section where you would have a chance at finding them. This feels like two games squashed together. One a detective based drama and one a GTA style action game in 40s LA. My issue is these two styles don’t fit as well together as they could and so the game feels split with neither mechanic living up to its potential.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												L.A. Noire is everything you expect and more. An honest detective simulation of the highest standard set in the open world of, you guessed it, L.A. Created by Team Bondi and published by Rockstar Games, I had a feeling this game was going to be fully fledged out, and they certainly delivered on that.You start off as a police officer with a strong justice driven ideological view, hellbent on making something of himself. You are given the opportunity to make your way up the law enforcement food chain, meeting new chracters and learning parts of the main character Cole's past life. I am only 6 hours in to the game as I write this but the cases so far feel very genuine. The game has a good sense of humour as most Rockstar games do but this one touches on some very dark material. I personally feel that this is a good thing and doesn't give the player the feeling that they are being babied. Although the game doesn't give too many incentives to go out exploring as some other open world games do, the world is huge and feels like a very authentic, and I'm not sure it would make sense in a game like this. The real draw to the game is the detective work afterall. There are some interesting side missions that you can get called in for but generally they all play out the same way. Bad guy breaks the law. Catch or kill the bad guy. Still, the setting is always interesting and it is something to do if you aren't satisfied by the campaign when you have completed it.My favourite part of the game was the interrogations. When interrogating a suspect/victim you are given the opportunity to decide whether you beleive they are lying or telling the truth. Using some impressive technology called "MotionScan" the faces of the NPC's in game almost feel real, albeit a tiny bit creepy at times. Thoug the system was fun and required thinking, I couldn't help but feel that sometimes it was impossible to tell if a character was being truthful or not. Maybe I'm just terrible at the game but it felt like sometimes I was required to guess rather than read the NPC's expressions.There are some cool ideas in the game that help keep you immersed in the game. An example of this are the doors in the game having golden handles when you may enter them, which means that you never run from door to door to check which are openable and which aren't. There is also no fast-travel feature in the game, but that doesn't mean you have to drive yourself everywhere. You're a cop, therefore you have a partner. You can tell that guy next to you to drive you from case to case which will skip to the area you need to go, but not before you and your partner's dialogue for the sequence is played to you. A particularly intriguing feature of the game is the ability to search crime scenes. This is a very fun feature that requires you to walk around the area and find clues. They are well explained to you as you find them so as a rule you should never feel like a clue is irrelevant. I did find that after a few consecutive crime scenes without breaks that finding the same beer bottle or cereal box on the floor became a little annoying, but completing a crime scene after finding all the clues in the area was a great feeling every time.Driving in L.A. Noire is fun but a little arcadey, which some people may like while others may not. I personally feel neutral towards it because I got my partner to drive me around everywhere after the first few hours and the is more about thinking intelligently than the actual gameplay mechanics. There is no lock-on system in L.A. Noire. Shooting can be a pain in the bum if you are using a controller to play the game, but you do it so briefly and so rarely that this should not prevent you enjoying the interesting gun scenes. In other words, guns are certainly not overused. Speaking of violence in this game, there is a boxing mechanic in the game that pops up when a suspect decides to engage you in hand to hand combat. This is as simple as blocking and punching and I found that mashing the attack button usually got the job done. I'm not too fussed about it because as I mentioned previously, the real gumption of the game is the detective mechanics.The main character of the game is interesting. He is quick witted and seems to be a very highly-principled officer, a nice change from Rockstar's usual hardstyled criminals we are usually made to play. I did feel that he could be a little spontaneously aggressive at times and he doesn't seem to treat his partners that well. The setting of the game is realistic. The game does not shy away from a lot of protruding themes of the time including racism, Nazi Germany and sexism. I will say that I feel Rockstar used these effectively to help you distinguish between the characters you are supposed to like and the characters you aren't even though for the time a lot of these things were considered "normal."Overall, I would certainly recommend this game to anyone looking for a good story and some engaging mechanics. The game requires you to think about what you are doing without punishing you too much for making a mistake. The game doesn't baby you and a lot of the content is certainly aimed for an older audience, but if you are interested in an immersive interractive experience look no further than L.A. Noire.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												LA Noire combines FPS, puzzle, and 'racing' (frequent car chases) mechanics to make for a unique twist on the mystery/detective genre. With a semi-open world environment reminscient of large-scale games like Saints Row or Grand Theft Auto, there is much to explore and unlock. Story missions are, however, the focus of the game, often relying on thoroughness, fine-tuned deductive reasoning, and a good deal of reading facial expressions well, which the game renders exquisitely, better than any game before or since its time, in my experience.At this point something of a classic, any mystery novel fan or puzzle game enthusiast would do well to pick up this game.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Well i will try to keep it short:Pros:-Very good atmopshere-Good voice acting-Game only in english-Good animations-Nice cases to solve, including the problems with corruption in the 40'sCons:-Horrible background story on the main character-Nothing at all to do. I know this is not GTA. But you just drive from case to case... -Stupid collect them all! Items such as cars, Newspapers, Police badges, etc-Some cases are so entertataining as watching a funeral or a chess game. -Random "Street crimes" which take 2 minutes to solve, are only inteneded to make the playtime longer-No background information on your partners, except of rusty being a little alcoholic.-You always do the same. 0 innovation.-Solving a case is like this: Check crime scene, drive to the place you intended to drive, talk with people, accuse them, case solved-You cant put yourself into the Protagonist because all we know is that he fighted in the war, is married and he is a hypocrit.-Making even a scratch to a car while on a case, doesnt allow you to get 5 star rating. -a brick is more intelligent than the AINow for the best: THE GAME DOES NOT WORK ON WIN7/10 etc, why ?  I dont know. Did rockstar patch it ? No. How to fix it ? Thanks to the community.  When finishing the game you are so glad its over.P.S I didnt pay the full price, bought it for 6,99 euro.The game is never worth 30 euro.  Wait for sale, but the smartest thing to do is not to buy it.4/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												This game is a pile of hot garbage. Unless it has some amazing reveal (like you've been in the animus or dreaming or delusional) after the first couple cases that sheds light on why the potrail of cops is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the basic gameplay mechanics are ridiculously flawed, I don't understand why it has any positive reviews. I see people compare this to a nega-gta, but honestly it just feels like playing gta from the prospective of a cop (who kills just about as many people as a side gta character). It doesn't do the "detective" experince well at all; the cases are either stupid simple or the pc makes ridiculous leaps in judgement about evidence and suspects. It's impossible to immerse yourself when the pc is soooo speculative, and you get no sense that you're in anyway stearing what he's saying. There are only ever 3 dialouge options, and none of them say anything about what happens when you choose them. Most of them cause the pc to explode completely unprovoked about something you wheren't even thinking of! I BARELY FEEL LIKE IM PLAYING AS THE PLAYER CHARACTER. Also, its racist as ♥♥♥♥, all of the cops are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s; it is litterly impossible to apprehend anyone without beating them to the ground or killing them. AND THIS IS NOT CALLED OUT AT ALL. There doesn't seem to be any tounge in check to the racism, not even time period awarness. There are moments of exteremely excessive police brutality AND NOT A WORD IS SAID, there is no undertone of acknowledgement of anything, its like the game just shrugs its shoulders and walks away without addressing it.  This game isn't even worth an in-depth review, so here's a comparative one: Imagine GTA but all the story is told through the worst designed and most historically ignorant Telltale game ever made.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												It's a good game but not a great one. I don't know you folks but I find it boring to do the same sh*t over and over again and in these days, a lot of gamers whine about this issue. I'm not saying this game makes you do same thing over and over again. Cases differ from each other in many aspects but basicly they are all the same to me. Go to crime scene, gather evidence, interview with some people, gather more evidence, interview with more people, then it comes to accusing. The game is actually based on gathering evidence and reading peoples faces correctly. But it's not enough, you have to bring up the right evidence in order to push the guy you are interviewing. And these things repeats itself in every case. So, about 11 hours of playing I asked myself, "Why am I even playing? Just to go gather evidence and interview people?" Well yes, that's basicly what the detectives do. So I shouldn't whine about this. It just bores me. Maybe you can enjoy it. Persnally, I think you should buy it when its on summer sales or else like %75 or more discount.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A different sort of game, L.A. Noire allows you to step into the world of James Elfroy's L.A. Quartet.  While a sandbox, it is a different type, rewarding inspection of the crime scene more than blazing away at bad guys.I typically play one case (which can last one to two hours) before giving myself a break.  A lot of friends have burntout on the game, which is a shame.  It can be a slower paced game, but it doesn't take away from the fact Rockstar created Los Angeles of 1947 in near perfect detail.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												La NoireGenre:  Action-AdventureType: Single-playerPlot: The story takes place in Los Angeles in 1947, and you play as Cole Phelps. The game follows him though his career in the Police. In the game you get assigned cases, and you're job is to solve them. That involves travelling to the crime scenes, look for clues, interrogate witnesses and chasing bad guys. The graphic in this game is the best. They have used a technology called Motion scan, which basicly transfers the actors every move into game animation.  This animation is especially useful when interrogating people, because you can read their body language. I liked this game very much and would definitely recommend this game to everyone. There is lots to do! If you don't want to do cases, you can drive around enjoying Los Angeles in the 1947, or you can answer distress calls.  I enjoyed this game very much, and its quite cheap these days!

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												First off: the cutscenes are unskippable. And pretty long.But don't worry, because the gameplay IS skippable. No, really.It's very clear Rockstar wanted to make a movie, not a game, here.In general, the crime scenes are either walk around spamming the interect buttons, accuse and backtrack interviews, and running after perps.The combat is pretty bad. NPCs on your side are pretty worthless and either hunker down doing nothing, or stand up and get killed after a hit or two. And you go down almost as quickly. And the NPCs you fight often have some pretty good accuracy.Which explains why they gave you an option, if you keep losing and having to restart at the previous 3 minute unskippable cutscene, to SKIP THE GAMEPLAY.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												So this game is an interesting one, being known for being the first game to use facial motion capture from actors and also being a game that got really hyped up before release only to end up bankrupting it's creator Team Bondi. This game was ambitious and to be honest it's a shame it didn't do better. It didn't quite live up to the hype but it's still a good game.You play Cole Phelps, a LAPD detective and decorated WWII vet with the game set in LA in 1947. The basic premise of the game is that you investigate various crimes and interrogate and question witnesses and suspects. So you'll show up to a crime scene and have to explore it looking for clues as to what happened and clues that might link to a suspect. Once you have your evidence you can question suspects. And this is where the facial capture comes into play. When your questioning a suspect they'll give you an answer to your question and then you can choose to believe they're telling the truth, doubt them or prove they're lying using evidence. You have to watch their facial expressions to figure it out as when they're lying they'll look visibly nervous or irritated. Guess correctly and they might spill some more useful info like a new suspect or evidence.It is a really interesting feature although it can be a bit difficult especially when choosing between doubt and lie. Also get it wrong and Cole just starts shouting at them for no reason, like he's some bipolar idiot.As for the rest of the game, well firstly the recreation of 1940's LA is brilliant. The look and feel of the city is amazing but   the big open world of LA is never fully utilized in the game and having this big beautiful city, most of which you'll never explore nor have reason to, feels a bit wasteful. You also have street crimes which come up as your driving between locations which are useful for getting experience points to rank up but get repetitive as they are all some combination of either pursuing a criminal or shooting them.The big feature of the game,the facial motion capture, is great and this game has probably the most detailed faces in any game. It also features a lot of familar actors from various tv shows, although sometimes the acting is a bit over the top but still good for the most part.The Good:- investigating crime scenes and questioning people is really enjoyable- the 1940's LA in the game looks and feels amazing and authentic- facial motion capture looks great- Most of the cases are enjoyable and interesting- Pretty good story The Bad:- a big open city that feels like a waste as there's little reason to explore most of it- street crime missions can be repetitive (although not compulsory)-combat sections aren't very impressiveOverall this game is a victim of it's own hype but don't let that put you off. It's still a great game and worth getting particularly if your the type that likes crime thrillers. I'd also recommend by the complete edition so you get the all the DLC cases as well. All the DLC cases are good, particularly Nicholsons Electroplating so it's worth paying a little extra for them. This game gets a 8/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												L.A Noire is a gritty crime drama set in the 40's of Los Angeles, where the player plays the role of Cole Phelps, Detective of the LAPD. The game sees you play 4 desks which are traffic, murder, vice and arson. The gunfights are seldom(ish) but are very fun and realistic. The game also has call-outs that may occour at any time whilst you are driving. Moreover, the game also offers landmarks that you discover by driving around the streets of LA. You can also collect vehicles, and this will earn you (approximately) 3 achievements on Steam, Xbox or PS3. A lot of people complain about having hardware problems, but the only problem I've ever experienced is the Checking for DLC problem. It is capped at 30 FPS, but that is to make sure every detail is in sync. In conclusion, this game receives a 9/10. I would score a 10/10 but the problems affect a large scale of people. However, it is nothing Google can fix. Definitely should buy.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												Awesome story alongside the most unique gameplay I've ever encountered make L.A. Noire one of the best games I've ever played. When you get all the questions right, find all the clues and make a perfect-5 stars case you get one of the best feelings you can get in a video game. It's really rewarding, but when you fail you want to punch yourself in the face.The post WW2 Los Angeles is a city full of crimes, so it will keep you busy for a while (besides the main-story cases, there are 40 street-crimes and a lot of collectibles to find - great ammount of content). The DLC cases are amazing, so I recommend getting the Complete Edition.This game is a masterpiece, 10/10.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												First off: the cutscenes are unskippable. And pretty long.But don't worry, because the gameplay IS skippable. No, really.It's very clear Rockstar wanted to make a movie, not a game, here.In general, the crime scenes are either walk around spamming the interect buttons, accuse and backtrack interviews, and running after perps.The combat is pretty bad. NPCs on your side are pretty worthless and either hunker down doing nothing, or stand up and get killed after a hit or two. And you go down almost as quickly. And the NPCs you fight often have some pretty good accuracy.Which explains why they gave you an option, if you keep losing and having to restart at the previous 3 minute unskippable cutscene, to SKIP THE GAMEPLAY.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												I can't recommend the game as I didn't enjoy it enough to finish it, I quit after 5 hours.The PC port isn't great, it's hard locked at 30fps (Widescreen Fixer allows 60fps), it's visually poor until you start fiddling with Nvidia Inspector, I added 16x AF, better AA, 2K DSR and more and then it became fine to look at but the game just ultimately bored me. I was expecting a more story driven game ala Life is Strange but L.A Noire is more of a GTA/Life Is Strange hybrid and I didn't enjoy it. In my 5 hours I basically did the same thing over and over just on different cases, there's no real overarching story so you feel absolutely no connection to any of the characters and I think that's what really killed it for me.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												The game takes place in 1947 in Los Angeles. The player acting as a detective of the Los Angeles police (eng. Los Angeles Police Department, abbr. LAPD) named Cole Phelps, to reveal a number of crimes. For this, you will need to see a place where they occurred, in search of clues, and all kinds of clues that may lead to the offender. The success of the investigative action, the player will depend on how will be fully disclosed to the picture of the incident.In addition to the story missions, players can receive calls on the police radio. In the game these tasks are called street crimes (eng. Street Crimes). Players can walk, and on different machines, which are opened along with the main character in the service. Besides the machines, the player is available for ten costumes for the character (4 of them are DLC). Some suits have special properties, such as increase of protection from damage or increase accuracy when firing.Unlike other games Rockstar Games Grand Theft Auto, players are prohibited from unrest and kill citizens, since the main character of the game is the detective police.IN THE «L.A. Noire» the emphasis is not on the creation of an open world, as it was in previous games «Rockstar» (in particular, Red Dead Redemption of series Grand Theft Auto), but quality of story line. According to the developers, their project must erase the existing border between games and movies». The main hero - patrol officer Cole Phelps, who, thanks to the diligence and seriousness of attitude is gradually moving up the career ladder. Translation into the new Department each time accompanied by «adaptation» to the new companion, which can not always find understanding. Among them and the police of the old school, working for the idea, and спивающийся detective, more worried about retirement, and Thrifty careerists with dubious connections. In some investigations Phelps will have to face not only with the criminal world of Los Angeles, and former colleagues, with whom he fought in the Second world war. However, his most dangerous enemy is corruption among police...Yes, the game does not actually be «sandpit». You will not be able to create your gameplay, because everything is subordinated to the plot. But the world will open review, and will be the mission, which will allow you to escape from the direct path to a climax. For example, going to a crime scene, you suddenly get a call that somewhere right now robbing a Bank. You can change the route and go there.P.S. In a free mode «Streets of Los Angeles, you can patrol the streets, the sights, collect videos and leave the challenges reported by the Manager.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is really what you make of it.  If you use the crutches in game options it's a fairly straight forward game with movie quality characters and story.  If you turn the crutches off, you'll ride the highs and lows of being a police detective in the 1940's, so much so that after a bad case you're gonna want to go on a bender and slug your wife.  Don't do it though.I used the crutches playing the tutorial cases and it seemed fairly easy getting all the clues with little music tones and hints where they are and the music stops you've found them all in an area, then it was a little challenging during interrogations trying to find the right approach and use the right evidence when catching them in lies.Then I discovered how to turn EZ mode off.  Go to game options and change "Clue Music" to ON so there's no music indicator for when you've found all the clues, and turn "Clue Hints" to off so there are no hints to where clues are.Once you take EZ mode off, the game is really fulfilling as the successes become oh so sweet, and the failures are absolute facepalm.  Without 100% certainty of finding all the clues, it gets REALLY frustrating as suspects lie to your face but you don't have the evidence to nail them, and the facial animations are so lifelike that you'll seriously want to backhand people as they roll their eyes and smirk during questioning.  Great game, well worth the money, and I'm only halfway through it.  (Warning: my play time doesn't reflect how long the game actually takes to beat because I've had to spend alot of time on the pause screen.)
